. The German papers handed in at this examina tion do not call for any special comment. The questions being very easy, the percentage of failures was consequently low. An examination conducted exclusively in writing, as we have it at present, however, forms hardly n test of the

It is hoped that the proposed introduction tional oral examination will supply this want,, and help to bring about the much needed reform in the teaching of French nnd German nt our schools, by .which the study of these languages should become mqrc interesting as well as more useful to tlie

scholar, /. I .

WALTER VON DECHEND.

article.heading: GERMAN POLAND. "TEACHING" GERMAN.
article.snippet: LONDON, December 1.—It is reported that Prussian schoolmasters flog Polish children who are unable to say the catechism and pray in German. Relatives who protest against this
article.articleText:
GERMAN POLAND.

'TEACHING' OERHAN.

LONDON, December .1. — It is reported that Prussian schoolmasters flog Polish children who are unable to say the catechism and pray in German. Relatives who protest against this treatment are arrested. In one case a mother who protested against the treatment of her child received a heavy sentence.

article.heading: GERMAN PRECEPT AND GERMAN PRACTICE.
article.snippet: The "Contemporary Review" for July publishes a translation of a pamphlet by Herr Meyer, a well known writer, it appears, on naval subjects, which has had a
article.articleText:
GERMAN PRECEPT AND GERMAN PRACTICE.

The "Contemporary Review" for July publishes a translation of a pamphlet Herr Meyer, a well known writer, it ap pears, on naval subjects, which has had it great circulation in Germany, and bubbles over with hatred to England, while claim-

ing for its writer an ample participation in that "inextinguishable enthusiasm for the Good, the Beautiful and the True," by which it is the peculiar privilege of his countrymen to be animated. His animosity to the mother country, its people and its institutions is so intense that he goes out into the street and "swears at large" in order to ease his mind. As to her land forces, heinforms us that "a couple of French army corps would suffice to drive the wonderful army of England, with all her Indian and colonial troops, to the devil." Whatever reputation it may have wrongfully acquired in former days has van- ished, he tells us. "English incendiarism in South Africa has tarnished the Iast re- mains of England's military glory, and branded her name as infamous for all time. It has revealed to the world the shameless- ness of the English character and an un- "scrupulousness which hesitates at nothing." Words almost fail Herr Meyer, indeed, when he endeavors to express his contempt for the British fleet, and his enormous ad- miration for that of Germany; while to those who are capable of holding up the former as a model for the construction of the latter, he sarcastically exclaims, "Eng- land, powerful at sea, and therefore on land — the land grabber and therefore the in- satiable; England, unscrupulous in her am- bition, and therefore breaking up in an ir- reparable decay; England is to be the edu- cator of Germany! Only he who is taken in by the deceptions conjured up by the Protean arts and duplicity of Britain can allow her to be capable of such a task." Finally, having exhausted his tolerably copious vocabulary of vituperation in ve- hement abuse of our countrymen, Herr Meyer winds up his pamphlet in these stir- ring words: — "Unite, German people, in the war cry of Germany, 'Los von Eng- land!'" — which may be read as a para- phrase of the elder Cato's memorable words, "Delenda est Carthage." Having listened to Herr Meyer's Anglo- phobic declamation against the "infamous" conduct of Great Britain in the Boer cam- paign, based, as a matter of course, upon the monstrous fabrications invented by Dr. Leyds, and circulated through the medium of the reptile press in Germany and else- where, it is amusing to turn to the very next article in the same number of the "Contemporary," and to read Mr. Auberon Herbert's narrative, mainly drawn from German sources, of the atrocities perpe- trated by the Germans during their occu- pation of France in 1870-71. "All movable property was subject to demands of German commanders to be transferred by the horses and labor of the inhabitants to any point directed. The penalty for imperfect com- pliance was fine. To ensure payment of the fine there was seizure of the chief inhabi- tants as hostages. If the village or town de- fended its property the penalty was burn- ing of the village. If any German troops al- lowed themselves to be surprised in any vil- lage, penalty— burning of the village. For injury to roads, bridges, railways — penalty, devastation of the district. For wearing a not recognised uniform — penalty, death." The French freeshooters and the followers of Garibaldi after their capture by the Ger- mans were shot down like dogs. "Every vil- lage in which an act of treachery has been committed," said Bismarck, "should be burnt to the ground, and all the male in- habitants hanged"; and when he heard of the capture of 1200 prisoners, many of whom were freeshooters, he angrily exclaimed, "Prisoners! Why do they continue to make prisoners? They should have shot down the whole 1200, one after another!" And yet our amiable critics in Germany stigmatise our soldiers as little better than barbarians and monsters, because when some of them approached a farm house, the inhabitants of which exhibited a flag of truce, and saw their comrades shot down in cold blood, they avenged this act of treachery, and pre- vented its repetition, by burning down the house in which it had occurred. In simi- lar circumstances in France thirty years ago every inmate of the habitation would have been put to death by the German soldiery.

article.heading: German Militarism.

title.title: The Braidwood Dispatch and Mining Journal (NSW : 1888 - 1954)

article.snippet: Most extraordinary evidence was given at the trial by court martial at Rendsburg of Sergeant Franzky, which ended in the sentence of five yeats' imprisonment and
article.articleText:
German Militarism.

Most extraordinary evidence was given at the trial by court martial at Readsbur^ of Sergeant Franzky, which ended in the sen teoce of five y eats' imprisonment and degra dation. One thousand five hundred and twenty cases of maltreatment of subordinates were proved against him, and in a large number nf ftARPK lh WAR isliniirn fhgt lio \\aA nnvnnoWot

private soldiers under him to lend him money which he never thought of returning. The same revelations were made as in preceding trials of this nature, viz., when the judges asked the men how they could put up with Buch treatment when they had the right to complain, they invariably replied that they were afraid to take this course owing to the vengeance that wonld be subsequently wreaked on them. DuriDE drill hours the recruits were in

mortal terror, for Frnnzky used to 6ay 'Now we are alone,' and then maltreated them with every possible refinement of cruelty. During these periods he posted two men outside the building with orders to report immediately the arrival of the lieutenant. One witness said he had been compelled to carry a heavy coalscuttle for half an hour rminn Ann round a warm mnm Arwitliat*

was compelled to stand in a bucket and then jump out aud in again till the sergeant tired of watching. Another confessed to having been beaten 300 times, perhaps more. Another was compelled to pnlish a bucket on his knees, and while in that position was repeatedly kicked by Pranzky. He was also ordered to go through exercises in front of a warm stove till he sank from exhaustion. Medical ex perts say that this witness will throughout hia life be subject to fits brought on by con stant and brutal maltreatment. Franzky spat in the men's faces at will, struck them in the face with bis fist and beat them, preferably when they were undressed, with a broomstick, which he named ' King Frederick Wilbelm.' When thia broomstick was broken by long service he procured an other, which he christened ' Frederick the Great.' Another witness swore that Franzky made him run his head sevBral times agaiutst a wall, which, said the man, ' hurt him severely. Another soldier who Was compelled

to perform the same operation had a bucket of water poured o;er his head afterwards 'to cure him of stupidity.' Every day the ruer were beaten, struck, or made to go through the most exhausting and unnecessary exer cise, merely evidently to gratify the sergeant's depraved desire to witness another man's pain.

article.snippet: Prior to the last solar eclipse, the Colonel of a German regiment of infantry sent for his sergeants and announced:—"There will be an eclipse of
article.articleText:
German Discipline.

Prior to tlio Inst solar eclipse, the Colonel of ft Gorman regimont of in fantry sent for his sergeants and an nounced:—"There will ho an eclipse of the sun to-morrow. The regiment will moot on the parade-ground in undress uniform, and I will come and explain the eclipse before drill. If tlio day is . cloudy tlio men will meet in tlio drill

shed as usual."

Thereupon the sergeants drew up the following order of tlio day:—"To

morrow morning, hy order of the Col onel, there will ho an eclipse of the sun. The regiment will assemble on the parade-ground, whore the Colonel will come and superintend the eclipse in person. If the sky is cloudy the oclinso will tako placo in tho drill shod 1"

article.heading: GERMAN ASPIRATIONS.
article.snippet: The Germans have, of course, a perfect right to enlarge their fleet, and we have none to prevent them doing so. What we have a right to do, and
article.articleText:
GERMAN ASPIRATIONS.

The Germans have, of course, a per-

fect right to enlarge their fleet, and

we have none to prevent them doing so. What we have a right to do, and what we shall do unless we are "drowned in security," is to watch the naval developments of Germany with the utmost vigilance, and to note carefully the growth of her as- pirations for world-power and sea- power-aspirations which cannot be fully realised without involving the weakening, or in the last resort the destruction, of the British Empire.

"The Spectator."

Annoyed because a doctor refused to certify him as insane, a burglar at Ber- lin jumped the dock railing and rushed at the magistrate. In the struggle a warder was injured

article.heading: GERMAN INTERFERENCE.
article.snippet: LONDON, October 18.—Dr. Morrison, the Pekin correspondent of the "Times," recalls that Germany in deference to Russia's wishes in 1901, affirmed that Manchuria was outside the
article.articleText:
GERMAN INTERFERENCE.

LONDON, October 18. — Dr. 'Morrison, the Pe kin correspondent of the 'Times,' recalls that Germany in deference to Russia's wishes in 1901, affirmed that Manchuria was outside the Anglo-German agreement. Now, for the pur

pose or embarrassing Great Britain, Germany has persuaded China that if the British treaty with Thibet is confirmed as it stands Germany may demand prescriptive rights in Shantung, France may make similar claims on Yunnan, and Japan on Fo-kien. Tang-shao-yi, the Chinese representative at Lhassa, has been instructed to seek at Cal cutta a modification of the treaty to save China's face. The Vienna correspondent of the 'Times,' says that Germany has possibly over-reached herself in exerting pressure on China at this juncture. Embarrassment, almost vexation, is felt at St. Petersburg, at Germany's proclaim ing at Pekin the solidarity of German and Rus sian interests in Asia. Her interference is intended to imply that Germany and Russia are united in their antagonism to Great Britain. Russia and Great Britain as great Asiatic Pow ers admit that they have a mutual right to speak with a view of adjustment of their own differences, and both resent the gratuitous in terference of a third Power having no claim to speak as an Asiatic Power. Russia has -informed the Court of Pekin of the clauses which she considers objectionable m the British treaty with Thibet, and has stated that these objections are not intended to imply the slightest animosity to Great Britain.

GERMAN EXPEDITION.

A German column, operating in the neigh bourhood of the junction of the Great Wall, some miles due north of Pekin, has had a sharp engagement with a Chinese force at a town twenty miles to the north-wost 'of the junction.

The Chinese force consisted of 3,000 men, and the Germans expelled them from the town, after a light laBting several hours, killing or wounding 200 of them. The Ger man casualties were only one killed and four wounded. v

article.heading: GERMAN "JUSTICE."
article.snippet: In contrast to the lenient punishment accorded to Ensign Huessner, who murdered an artilleryman in the street (and previously mentioned in the "The World's News"), the case
article.articleText:
GERMAN " JUSTICE."

In contrast to the lenient punishment ac corded to Ensign Huessner, who .murdered an artilleryman in the street (and previously men tioned in the "The World's News"), the case of a soldier who has been tried at Nuremburg is worthy of notice.

The man refused to execute a trifling ordef given by a non-commisioned officer, and was afterwards foolish enough to speak of the mat ter in barracks. In consequence he was court martialled, and sentenced to five years and six months' imprisonment, with hard labor.

While the average German in conversation condemns the injustice of these sentences, he dare not object, and the soldiers themselves adopt a fatalistic attitude, and merely remark,

"It must be."

article.heading: GERMAN SPREADEAGLEISM.
article.snippet: A prominent German newspaper bas opened out with another hysterical tirade against Great Britain. This instance of spread-eagleiem might well
article.articleText:
GERMAN SPEEADEAGLEISM.

A prominent German newspaper baa opened oat with, another hysterical tirade against Great Britain. This in stance of spread-eagleism might well be dismissed, as others have been, but that it acquires special significance

from tbe fact that the journal in which it appears is frequently the mouthpiece of the Government — which in international affairs really means the impetuous, ambitious Kaiser — and touches upon tbe vital question of what Power really controls the destiny of European politics. Great Britain is warned not to provoke a decision on the subject, because of the world wide significance and effect attaching to it. In other words Germany infer entially threatens that if the issue is

provoked Bhe will contest any decision adverse to her aspirations in that con nection. Tbe greatest of the Kaiser's many ambitions is unquestionably that Germany should gain that indefinite, yet all important, quality known as the ' balance of power.' Every move in policy, every increase of the navy and the army is conceived with that objective in view; it is almost, if not quite, an obsession with the Monarch. How far this spirit and the prepara tions which How from it can ba effec

tive, must remain iu uuuoi uum ?? test has been applied. In tbe interim Germany remains the cause of unrest amongst the nations, and because of her strenuousnesss in almost every part of the world has to be closely watched, even by the smaller powers. It can well be understood that a nation with such ambitions as Germany has chafes under the ' diplomatic net ' which has been woven around her, and for which Great Britain has to thank the late Lord Salisbury, whose apprecia tion of the importance of the Empire's relations with the other Powers has resulted in the creation of what is ad mitted to be the ablest diplomatic service in the world. That service has unquestionably checkmated Ger many, maintained Great Britain's

prestige and, by .the intervening of interests, made her position more secure and yet left an outlet for. the policy of 'grand isolation' which Lord Salisbury considered so essential to her supremacy. Germany may at tempt to capture the ' balance of power ' by a revolt against the tight ening cordon of diplomacy, tbe con tinued increase -of her naval and mer cantile fleets, and her army. Bat how long could such an aggressive nation, inclined to riding rough-shod over obstacles, maintain that power when in the high stirrups, assuming that altitude was attained 9 Not for long, we believe. So long as Great

Britain maintains the two-power de fence, the balance of power is likely to remain with her. But at Germany's rate of battleship construction that position is being jeopardised. It is probably Great Britain's realisation of that fact which the German semi official newspaper regards as provoca tion for testing the issue of supre macy, and for the spreadeaglelsm in which it indulges with reference to tbe capabilities of the army. Though hysterical, however, the declaration, emanating from what is frequently the mouth-piece of the Government, may or may not have official founda tion ; at any rate it is worth noticing.

article.heading: GERMAN FINANCES.
article.snippet: Herr Von Koenneritz writes:— Sir,—In connection with the "Economist's" statement regarding the position of the German finances, it may not be without interest to remind your readers
article.articleText:
GERMAN FINANCES.

Herr Von Koenneritz writes

Sir,—In connection with the "Economist's" state-

ment regarding the position of the German finances,

it may not be without interest to remind your readers

that, compared with the estimates for 1907, viz., 1,187,600,000 marks, the Empire's receipts during last year totalled 1,201,100,000 marks; that is, roughly 13,500,000 marks, or about 1 per cent more than had been anticipated. Compared with 1906, all sources of revenue, except two show increases, as, for instance, Customs duties, 643,000,000 marks, or 88,400,000 marks more than during the previous year. Tobacco and cigar-

ettes excise duties 23,600,000 marks, or 7,000,000 marks more, distilled excise duties 112,600,000 marks, or 7,800,000 marks more, brewing excise duties 51,100,000 marks, or 8,200,000 marks more, etc. The two excep- tions referred to are the stamp duties on revenue-pro- ducing stocks and on Bourse transactions, which together

yielded 22,900,000 marks less than in 1906. But against this it should be remembered that they had been un- naturally high during that year. All other sources of revenue together show an increase of 160,000,000 marks in round figures, so that if we deduct the lesser yield of the Bourse transactions, there still remains for 1907 an excess of revenue of 137,000,000 marks in round figures as compared to the previous year. Moreover, the fact should not be lost sight of that of the new duties passed in 1906, obviously none were able to yield their full measure of revenue in 1907. This will only be the case in 1910, and not before. This much, however, may safely be predicted—that the expecta- tions which led to the imposition of the new duties will be fully justified; in fact, in some instances, the yield has already come up to the estimates.

article.heading: GERMAN COMMENTS.
article.snippet: German comments on the four Dreadnoughts debate show a determination not to recognise the necessity for British supremacy of the sea. The
article.articleText:
GERMAN COMMENTS.

German comments on the four Dreadnoughts debate show a determin ation not to recognise the necessity for British supremacy of the sea. The Liberal members' proposals for a limi tation of armaments are interpreted as an attempt to maintain supremacy without incurring additional expendi ture.

article.heading: GERMAN INTENTIONS
article.snippet: The opinion formed by the Bishop of Salisbury as to the trend of thought in Germany about war with Britain comes opportunely by cable for
article.articleText:
GERMAN INTENTIONS

The opinion formed by the Bishop of Salisbury as to the trend of thought in Germany about war with Britain comes opportunely by cable for com parison with the mail brought views of some other observers and critics of Germany's warlike preparations. And

it is interesting to find that,' leaving out of consideration the question1 whe ther there is any -real desire for war on the part of the people of Germany, the Bishop's discovery of 'a consider able desire for the possession of such naval and military supremacy as might enable Germany -to dictate to Europe in a crisis, or, if necessary, to the

United States,' is very muchi in har mony with what Captain Mahan, an American thinker and writer of accept ed authority on such subjects, recently addressed to his fellow countrymen. In an article in 'Collier's Weekly,' Cap tain Mahan calls upon Americans to give their attention to the recent change in Germany's . shipbuilding capacity, as revealed by the British Prime Minister and Admiralty. He says : 'j[ believe an extraordinary situa tion ihas been created, and that hence forward, if Germany so will and can find the money, the two-Power ' stand ard of the Britisk Fleet, accepted by Liverals as well as Conservatives, can not be maintained. . - Few persons realise what the appearance of such a navy as that which Germany is build ing means in international affairs. The question, indeed, as not what she in-, tends; like other Governments, she may to some extent live from hand to1 mouth, though probably not eo much so as others. The question is: What will she be able to do with such a force? That is her meaning: the expediency of an unknown future, as yet contingent, and impossible to fore see. But though contingencies are beyond our ken, it is perfectly know able, and absolutely sure,, that, should they be unfavorable, 6he, with a decisively superior navy, will have the whip hand.' In 'The United Service Gazette' Captain E. H. James deals with the same aspect of Germany's naval operations, and points out that the British policy ihas been to fight, 'with absolute impartiality, for or against every great Power on the continent, as circumstances demanded,' to 'prevent any Power, or group of Powers, from obtaining domination over Europe.'' For, in other words; 'our sea supre macy depends upon our ability to main tain the balance of power in Europe.' In the 'Insurance and Banking Re cord' we find 'Jotter' advising those who would understand the situation of to-day to read Ellis Barker's great work 'The Rise and Decline of the Netherlands.' After* pointing to the warning of the fate of Holland, this writer says: 'Presently -we shall have to tighten our belts and set our teeth and go on short commons to repel a similar attack ; and, please God, with -the same result. - . . For the1

great law of the. gods is the Law of the Survival of the Fittest. The gods give victory to those who by self denial/ grit and a united resolution prove their right to it. Heaven iias no favorites, and never had. And unless moral excellences go hand in (hand with the qualities just mentioned, moral excellences — if these, indeed, be ours — will count for nothing.'

article.heading: GERMAN MOURNING.
article.snippet: LONDON, Tuesday Morning.—The Emperor of Germany has extended the Court's full mourning till March 8, and half-mourning till April 22.
article.articleText:
GERMAN MOURNING.

LONDON, Tuesday Morning.— The Emperor of Germany has extended the Court's full mourning till March 8, and half-mournine till April 22.

article.heading: GERMAN DREADNOUGHT.
article.snippet: It is announced that the battleship Bayern, the first Dreadnought built by the German Admiralty, will be launched at the Imperial Dockyard, Wilhelmshaven, at

comment.value: Stop correcting the text in the article to something that is not written in it. A note regarding the error should be made in the comments, but changing the details of the source material is incorrect.

article.articleText:
GERMAN DREADNOUGHT.

It is announced that the battleship Bayern, the first Dreadnought built by the German Admiralty, will be launched at the Imperial Dockyard, Wilhelmshaven, at the end of February. Particulars regard- ing the construction of the vessel have been kept secret, but it is reported that the work of building was not begun until early in 1906. The ship will have a dis- placement of 18,000 tons, and the guaran- teed rate of speed will be 19½ knots. The cost of the ship when completed is set down at £1,825,000.

In the beginning of the last century the Ger merino flocks were mostly of the old ' IVegre ani the famous ' Electoral ' (ribes, but time went ou tlie;e types bad become moro and i unprofitable until their former popularity was and they were gradually eupplantad by the diffe types of what the German breeders call ' Kat woll ' (Combine- TVool) meimo3 ani most not

The production of ' heavy woolled ' si from 1833 to 1&66, and 3. The ' Kammwoll ' (combing wool) per with muttou production, extending from 1S66 tc present time. During the first ' phase ' the aim was, as detinir.ion indicates, the production of ' high wools,' and under the favourable conditions the markets then existing this was puttied to sucl extent that everything else was made subordinate this end and tbe animals so produced lost their c atiluttonal vigour »nd the quantity of wool shorn iV.x individuals became diminutive. 'Nobility of fib1-, as it was called iu those days, waB all the rage, no one dared to thiuk scarcely of ' nobility of fori or much leis ' length of staple.' These fine w - were principally exported to England, and ?-?? German breeders enjoyed almost a monopoly in tl . ? production for many years, and consequeL ? obtained high prices, bat as the supply was cc p&rativeiy limited the manufacturers were force: f look for jther materials, which they found iu ' combing merino wools ' of the ** Delaine' c »? furnished by the tranB -marine colonies. it was not until about the year 1860 that : ? breeders of North Germany, considt . .- the breediug of tbe ' Hammwoll '' types - ?? equally eeuteel asl that of Hue woolled ahtv But after that the increase in popular favour of former was only paralleled by the correspond . decrease of the old merino typeB until at tbe pret time the number of the ' Kimmwoll ' flocks Germany ts legiou, while the number of the * style merino nosks has dwindled down almcs .? zero. It must uot be understood, however, that ?'?,? German ' Kammwoll ' herds are Rambouillers, ' -; this is not the case, and the sooner we Ameri ' ?' Kambouillet breeders understand this the better ?- ? are off. I am acquainted with at least two a flocks bath of whom have made splendid showiugi the late Pans exhibition and whose animals will cc - pare favourably with the genuine Sambouilfetf, ? - neither of these herds are of ftambouillet origin, are they claimed to be such, for the one is descen .- from a direct importation made from Spain m 1 ' and the aucestois of the other were brought from same place iu 1814 and bred pure ever hiuce. article.heading: German Colonisation.

article.snippet: The chief use that is being made in Germany of the splendid patriotism of the colonies is to draw the lesson that if Germany wants to make her voice heard in the
article.articleText:
German Colonisation. -

The chief use ilhiat lis being made in Ger many of 'the splendid patriotism otf the col onies Is to idiianv ithe lesson thalt i'f Geimany wants to make her voice heard in tlie Counsels cif the nfitions t?he onust have a big fleet. Everything is made to turn, on the fleet. Elminenit piOCtssors aire constantly drumming it into their students, and even r the bovs at Drimarv schools are taught the

economic value of colonies and fleets with this object in view. I was astonished the h'tihor d'a.y alt the skiil'l and pauJience with which a well-known schoolmaster was driving home to a class of big lads the necessity, for a large increase 'in the Ger man fleet. This result was obtained by tae use of a sort of catechism somewhat as if cl ients : — Does a country's greatness depend on agriculture or industries ?— No country can be permanently great in which agriculture is iCLtnahglCd. The iculliuivatlion of cereals oiit' the raising of stock is a vital necessity. What great power is there where agricul ture dwindles . away .and industries in crease ? — England. And is England decay ing ? — No. Why is this ? — S'he is supplied with food from . her. colonies and other countries. How is it she gets these supp Us? — Her enormous fleet suffices to protect -lier- commerce. What lessons do we learn from this ?— We must get colonies and' a big fleet to protect our commerce. . . This is no fancy sketch ; it is -what is being d'aily inculcate'd into the youth cf Germany.. Tt- get a big fleet so as to ba on equal terms with England— that appeals to he the ambition of very many of the Germans. Chagrin -that they have no col onies in temperate regions and disappoint ment at the failure of their African pos sesions, mingle with envy and jealousy' of

England. f X'ne uoioniai estimates ior xauu ? ?Show itihat £1,300,000 will have ito he pro-' , vided by the Imperial Exchequer, an in crease of over half a million on the esti mates for 1899.) There are, however, not a few who sorrowfuly admit -that English methods are best, at least in colonies, and in Shantung the administration is being modelled on English lines. Anglophobia ' gtows more intense, though officially dis-' couraged. Keen regret is felt at. the utter failure of any Power to intervene onbohalf of the Boers. . a .' ? ? -

article.heading: German Newspapers.
article.snippet: We learn that our German contemporary, "Nord Australische Zeitung." has been purchased by Messrs. Monsel, Lisehke, and Co., proprietors of the "Queenslander Herald,"
article.articleText:
German Newspapers.

We learn that our German Contemporary, "Nord Australische Zeitung," has been pur- chased by Messrs. Monzel, Lischke, and Co., proprietors of the "Queenslander Herald," and the first number of the amalgamated papers was issued this week in an attractive form. The Germans in the community will doubtless appreciate the existence of one newspaper instead of two.

article.heading: German Socialists.
article.snippet: ONE hundred thousand persons took part in the funeral procession of the late leader of German socialists. It goes without saying that the whole of those people were not
article.articleText:
German Socialists. .

'.One hundred thousand persons took part in: the funeral procession of the late leader of German socialists. .It goes without saying that the wholo of thoso peopld were notrooog-' liised supporters"' of .the sooialist movement, for 'tha, ranks of Tusoany doubtless were curious, . and ' showed ' themselves on the

occasion less to do honour to a departed rival than ' tb gauge his following. The inoident is significant. With . all the Absolutism of the Kuisor's iron- rule, there is, nevertheless, a large pro-- portion of what in most other countries would bo termed , " revolutionists " beneath his sway. Only a short timo ago a oivilian was done to death, in a German cafo by a German officer, becauso he happened to jostle against that military individual. . English demoorats stood aghast, at tho outrage, and cited Germany as the hotbed of despotism.- Now, a hundred thousand peoplo turn out to see a socialist's funeral! As we said bo- fore, -tho inoident is significant— significant as shojriag what a powerful factor individuality ever is. Doubtless this man, unable to formu late any really effieient plan or system tor the betterment of his race, simply swayed his followers by his own overhearing fonatioism. What good has ho dono ? What monument to liberty has he upreored? Amid his hundred thousand sightseers he passes completely from Bight and memory ; whilo a Hampden, who is hurried to an obsouro grave, lives for ever. There - is a great moral in this apparently small matter. Socialism is tho poorcst-of faotors in national progress ; if ever it conduces, in the smallest' degree thereto. '" '

article.snippet: A basket maker named Koch, of Gross Ramstadt, a little village of about 200 inhabitants, near Apolda, has been twice sentenced to death at Rudolstadt for the
article.articleText:
German Bluebeard.

A basket maker named Koch, of Gross Ramsladt, a liltki village of about 200 inhabitants, near Apolila, Ims been twice sentenced to death at Rudolslailt for the

murder of bis third wire aud a female lodger, named Zeiss, The accused, wan Is 61 years of age, was nnlv charged with two murders, but Hie gravest sus picions exist that ho has six other simi lar crimes to his account. For some lime wopicn have been disaii'icnring in the Apolila district, and last April Koch's wife was also missed, Koch himself re ported her disaiipearancc to the police, und shortly iifterwards somo workmen found in n nmari'v a woman's foot, which Pbi! man declared to lie that of his wife. On being charged with murdering her, Koch confessed that he killed the woman with un axe in n fit of rage at her re proaches, anil subsequently cut up the body, burying or burning the pieces. Ho also , admitted having murdered the lodger Zeiss with the same axo. The pri soner, who has served a term of nine venrs' pennl servitude for criminal as sault, received tlio death sentence with indifference.

article.heading: GERMAN POLITICS.
article.snippet: In the German Reichstag last night, Count von Bulow, the German Chancellor, was questioned about the Kaiser's recent visit to England. Von Bulow, in reply,
article.articleText:
GERMAN POLITICS.

In the German Reichstag last night, Count von Bulow, the German Chancellor, was questioned about the Kaiser's recent visit to England. Von Bulow, in reply, said: "We will live at peace with Eng-

land, but practically politics are depen dent upon the reciprocity of foreign poli tics, and are not affected by dynastic con siderations or ties of relationship."

article.heading: GERMAN METHOD.

title.title: Warialda Standard and Northern Districts' Advertiser (NSW : 1900 - 1954)

article.snippet: The British Consul at Stettin has been making inquiries into the German method of fattening cattle by feeding them on
article.articleText:
GERMAN METHOD.

The British Consul at Stettin has been making inquiries into the German method of fattening cattle by feeding them on mo- las2es mixed with peat dust, and the EeDort thai he presents on

he subject is practically an en dorsement of what may be justly called a truly Teutonic mixture. Having explained that, the mo lasses used is -t.lio article in the raw state, in which at least fifty per cent, of sugar is to be found, while the dust is obtained by passing the ordinary moss litter through a disintegrating ma chine, he proceeds to summarize the advantages of"_the mixture, in the following succinct order. I 1. It. is fifty per cent, cheaper' than the best fut-pr educing

food, and yet equal in nourish ment. 2. It tends to keep the animal in health, helps diges tion, and whets the appetite. 3. It is almost equal in nourish ment to,, and is a good substi tute for bran. 4. It prevents colic and other sickness. 5. It gives a glossy, h< althy appear ance to the skin. 6. When used for fatteniug it increases weight and improves the flavour of moat, &c. &e. On the ques tion of amount to be given to the animal, the writer slates that iu order to accustom the animals to molasses food give them first for a- week only a quarter of an ordinary ration (that is from half a pound to a third of a pound daily ; in the following week raise the amount to about three quarters of a pound, and the third week to the maximum amount — namely, one pound to

a pound and a hull.

article.articleText:

ships of the latest type. This provi sion, it is stated, is_ sufficient to enable ; the firm to construct gun mountings for six Dreadnoughts annually. In addi tion to this Krupps are laying down eight pits, which will enable them to fit out 11 Dreadnoughts annually. In concluding the article, the "Pall ; Mall Gazette" declares that the inten- j tions of Krupp with regard to the in creased construction of pits are »n- | known to the Imperial Government.

insican 01 imiigtiauon ni- inu iKJor nmroges at Vlakfanteiu, whuu tho wouudud were shot, it lias only aroused Anglophobia in thu German press. Tho Gorman newspapers doclaro that Croat Britain is reaping what it has sown,

article.heading: GERMAN EXPANSION.
article.snippet: In the consideration of "world policy, at the present time the dominant fact that has to be faced is this The vigorous and rapidlyincreasing German nation is finding its
article.articleText:
GERMAN EXPANSION. ,

vimmo" / writes fronvvLondoni--

i ' In the' consideration ot worm poucy ; ai. the present time the dominant fact that has to be faced is . tliisi Tiie vigorous and raidly- increasing German ' nation is ' finding' .its

European home too confined lor it, ana is seeking (is absolutely bent on securing) a territory of - suitable climatic character else where, into "which its "overspill" may pour without passing, under another ilag. All the temperate regions \of the earth, however; are now. occupied, and the Germans realise that what they require must be -obtained' (in the last resort) by force of arms. Hence these preparations. A glance at the map of the world will show that there arc three tracts of land in 't>he Southern Hemisphere which, by reason of their slight population, may bo regarded as possible objectives of German imperial enterprise. These are the two British colon ial States— South Africa and Australia— and the southern portion of South America: South Africa (the possession of which, we re cognise as- essentlul ; to our hold on India) is near enough to. England to lie readily de fensible without -an undue weakening. -of our available resources. The case of Australia, however. Is different. Relying on the ability t>f thv- mother (:ou»j/.vy to protect her, she has 7/Vjrsued a policy- of impossible ideals, and neglected to secure for herself the only roaf strength of a community— a large popu- lat'/m, and that settled on the land. Aus- trtilia is indeed a plum ripe: for flicking, but - ufffiRr-.' present ciretunsUMices we are pro bably 'strong enough to resist any predatory attempt successfully, though the problem may be a more serious one .in the near fu- . lure. .The third tract of land that I have men tioned—the south ol! South ' America — is spar sely populated by a mixed Spanish-speaking race, arid -has been preserved hitherto from -European aggression by the "Monroe doc trine" of the United States of America, which lays it down that any attempt to secure ter ritory in the New World will he strenuously -.resisted by the great Northern Republic. The Monroe doctrine has never given us any con- - corn, inasmuch as we have enough posses- - sions already: but it does concern the Ger mans very defeply, since it shuts them out " ' ' . from the only temperate region of the -earth that it. is possible for them to acquire witli- out coming- into conflict with the widespread Vind powerful British Empire. It seems to me, sir, that this is a fact of the very highest importance. May it not be ' that the German fleet is being built, not so much to challenge our present supremacy at sea as to render the Monroe doctrine of the United States . nugatory, by making her fleet powerless to enforce it? This, at any rate, would be a less dangerous policy for , Germany to pursue, and one more likely of immediate success: for in the matter of the Monroe doctrine the United States ' would stand alone, and coyld not rely on our sup port in a policy which has no pt'arfVal bear- ' lrtg on our own interests. On the cotftrary, T«e occupation by Germany of -the sputhern - part of South America would be of actual benefit to us, by providing a safety-valve for -- that explosive epergy of the Fatherlqnd - yitlvldA-Ia" bbvmtl, sooner or later, to find a — ---vent. It Is, indeed, a perfectly natural and a per- . fjcetly laudable ambition on the part of Ger- .. many' to acquire territory of its own, into which It may expand without loss of na tionality; and we shall be Ill-advised if we persistently hamper the attempts of our great neighbor to extend her borders. Our Own safety, let us remember, lies in a rea- . bonable concession to 'her aspirations, not in a rigorous suppression of them. Nor need It lie thought that the policy that have suggested is incompatible with our ' "genuinely felt friendship for the United Btfttes. In a few years the Panama Canal itirftl be open, and the east and west coasts North America will then be in direct '' icpmmunicatio> with each other, quite Inde- . ipendently of tne long voyage round by Cape QXbrn, so that the Monroe doctrine will cease Toy the action of the Americans themselves) to have any intelligible meaning as regards the extreme south. If in this matter our natural policy is one of strict neutrality we need not be wanting In a deflate exhibition 4>f friendship whenever the real Interests of tne United States are threatened, and any attempt to Interfere with the Panama Canal would necessarily provoke a combination of tne two great branches of the Anglo-Saxon - race. '

article.heading: GERMAN VOLUNTEERS.
article.snippet: The Government of Hong Kong have declined the services of the Germans who recently obtained permission from the Kaiser to volunteer for the defence
article.articleText:
GERMAN VOLUNTEERS.

The Government of Hong Kong have declined the services of the Germans who recently obtained permission from the Kaiser to volunteer for the defence of the island. However they are willing to employ them as special constables.

article.heading: GERMAN SHIPBUILDING
article.snippet: If anything were needed to testify to the really marvellous strides which have been made by Germany in shipbuilding [?]dring the last 20 years,
article.articleText:
GERMAN SHIPBUILDING

If anything were needed to testify to the really marvellous strides which have been made by Germany in shipbuilding cldring the last 20 year*, then the despatch with which the German shipbuilding yards can turn out battleships nowadays might be mentioned. Thus, 20 years or so ago, it took nearly eight years to build a battleship of the Sachsen class of 7280 tons; the Bayern was laid down in 1874, and finished in 1882; and the Baden was laid down in 187G, and fin ished in '1884, both vessels being of 7280 tons. But at the present day the German yards can turn out a battleship almost as large again as those of the Sachsen class in only a little more than a third of the time taken in building the battleships of that class. The four battleships of the Braunschweig class of 13,'200 tons, recently finished, have taken on an averuge 36 months for their complete construction; thg IVittelsbach class, of 12,000 tons, took 39 months, »r,.ietlic Kaiser class, of 11,180 tons, took t>s much ns 48 months; and ths !*rai.donburg class, of 9S40 tons, to A ll.e same time. Now, the German n:ivy has for use 10 large sqmidr-'in-b'ittleships, for last month the latest- products of the German yards the Hessen ami Kurfurst-Friedrich-M'ilhntra, entered on active service.—"London (;>i lie."

article.heading: German Animosity.

title.title: The Bligh Watchman and Coonabarabran Gazette (NSW : 1898 - 1910)

article.snippet: In a recent letter to the Sydney Press Mr. O. C. Beate gives a long and interesting extract from a leading German
article.articleText:
German Animosity.

In a recent letter to the Sydney Press Mr. O. C. Beate gives a long and interesting extract from a leading German newspaper which sets forth what it calls the reasons that their country should distrust Engiand. The arguments are of course terribly biassed against the British Empire, but they overlook one fact that should make up for all the sins of England's committing. Where ever the English flag floats the German colonist is as welcomo as the Britisher; the German merchant is given equal rights to trade as the British merchant; his life and property is protected, his religion is respected, his freedom absolute. When Britain opens up a tract of country in Africa, China or elsewhere, it is a distinct gain to £.11 the world. Can these things be said of Germany ? She owns a lot of territory in various parts of the world, but her citizens, as frugal as industrious, and as in-

telligent, as any people in the world, prefer to emigrate t o British territory. In German colonies the German merchant is given a preference over all other nations, German goods are not taxed like British goods are. When Germany secures a tract of country, that territory is lost to all the world, the exports thcreform go to Germany on German ships, the imports thereto must come from Germany. The country is administered not for its own good but to the benefit of its master, much the same as Britain used to have India administered over half a century ago. Britain's policy now is the " Open Door," and if all colony owing Powers worked en the same principle, it would not matter much who owned the world.

article.snippet: One of two men bought a German sausage. On the way home his companion reproved him for such foolishness, declaring that the sausage was
article.articleText:
German Sausage.

One of two men bought a German sausage. On the way home his com panion reproved him for such foolish

ness, declaring that the sausage was made of time-expired cab-horses. This the purchaser indignantly denied, but that same evening, going to his friend’s room, he apologised.

“You was right about that sausage, Bill,” he said. '

“Ah, I Knew I was. But how did

you prove it?”

“Whv, I cut the sausage up into five pieces, and set ’em out in a row, one behind the other. Then I pushed for ward the first on the rank, and the other four moved up!”

You may set it down as a truth which admits of few exceptions, that those who ash your opinion really I wait yetrr prai'tfe.

article.snippet: Twelve thousand unemployed met at Berlin, and demanded that the state should undertake building work at trades union wages, the removal of the
article.articleText: GERMAN UNEMPLOYED. Twelve thousand unemployed met at Berlin, and demanded that the state should undertake building work at trades union wages, the removal of the food taxes, and also the jimnediate Justi tution of municipal relief works. They repudiated the acceptance of charity. Armed policemen provoked some, dis order by unnecessary interference.. Think ing that some of the nemployed were try ing to force a passage over the'bridge, they drew their sabres and mercilessly slashed-anany, until there were pools of blood in the streets. The "Vorivarts" calculates that there are 60,000 unemployed in Berlin.

German Anti-German.

M. Paul . Lordon, who was recent ly sent by tho 'Petit Journal' of Paris to visit ; a, Hospital -in Picordy sot apart -__ for 'wounded Germans, narrates th!j following incident : In tho ward he was inspecting lte no ticed , a singular expression o£ hut red on th'e face of a patient who

mudo signs he wished to speak to tho1 Frenchman. Tho latter, upproach ed the bod. '.You are n, journalist,' Said tho wounded man in excellent French', .'-'will you interview mo ? Sit down and listen.' -With an awf'! expression of fury and hatred in his blue eyes the man, writes M. Lor don, 'exclaimed : passionately, 'I hato the Germans ; I hate tlie Bosches. as' you call them. 'Yes, monsieur,' Ho continued in reply to .the French man's marks of surprise, 'I hat? them, with all my heart, with, 'all nty soul. That astonishes you ; well, ?you r will soon understand ? mo b'ct- tsr. If 1 am. here in a hospital so badly wounded that' t-hero ia a sligh* hopo. of recovery, it is not a French bullet that brought it about. No, -I v.'as struck- traitorously from behind by a German officer. This was about thq- middle of Septemlier . in tho neighborhood of X, just at the mo ment whten wo wVo -preparing to ttilio ?the offensive. In ; one of . our trendies that your soldiers had justi reached, a French ofiicor had fallen, his legs crushed. 'Ve wero still there, a Handful of Germans holding but. A lieutenant orderod mo to run my (inyoriot through the wounded French officer's body. I refused with Horror to 'execute the ' order. - At ? tl*j same time -another German' ollicor passed behind : mo, and with his revolver strotchod mo* on the ground. I was picked up Uy your inon and coavoy ed to this antmilanco. Tho traitor ous bullet pierced my chest from front to backt. I know tho nairio : o£ my assassin.' Ho is called Karl Strunb'urg, and is a sub'-lieutonant.

What I pray for every day is that I may li\o till tho end of the war and then: -I .will revenge mysalf upon him magnificently. 'You now under stand, monsieur,' he concluded, rwhy I hate these cowards.'

article.heading: GERMAN SHOOTS GERMAN.
article.snippet: The High Commissioner reports:— "Since the last letter left general headquarters evidence has been received which points to the fact that
article.articleText:
?'? GERMAN SHOOTS GERMAN. .

The High Commissioner reports:— 'Since the last letter left general headquarters evidence has been re ceived which points to the fact that during the counter-attacks on the night of September 20 German in fantry fired into each other, the re

sult of an attempt to carry out a dangerous expedient of a conver ging advance in the dark. Oppo site one portion of our position a considerable massing of hostile forces was observed before dark. Some hours later a furious fusilade was heard in front of our line, though no bullets came over our trenches. On the 21st there was a, little rain, and the weather took a turn for the better, which has been maintained. The action was prac tically confined to die artillery, oui guns' at one point shelling and driving away any who were en deavoring toeon.struct redoubts. The

Germans expended a large numoer of heavy shells in a long-range bom bardment of the village of Oissy. Reconnoitring parties sent out dur ing the nights of the 21st and 22nd discovered some deserted trenches in the woods. Over 100 dead and wounded were picked up., together with a number of rifles and am munition and. equipment. There were various other signs that por tions of the enemy's forces had been withdrawn for some distance. 'The 22nd. although fine and with less wind,' was one of the most eventful days the British passed since we left the Aisne. There was less artillery work on either side, the Germans, nevertheless, giving the village of Paissy a taste of war. The spot thus honored is not far from the ridge where some of the most severe close fighting in which we !have taken mrt has occurred. All over this 'Roman's Land' between the lines bodies of German infantry are still Iving in heaps where they have fallen at different times.

article.articleText:
german kills german.

LONDON, Alonday, 5.40 a.m.— A report comes from Ostend that an altercation took place in tlio barracks at Etterbeek, a suburb of Brussels, between Prussian and Bavariau

troops. A light ensued, and ten soldiers were killed.

article.heading: GERMAN ANTI-GERMAN.
article.snippet: M. Paul Lordon, who was recently sent by the "Petit Journal," of Paris, to visit a hospital in Picardy set apart for wounded Germans, narrates the following incident:—In
article.articleText:
GERMAN ANTI-GERMAN.

?

M. Paul Lordon, who was recently sent by the "Petit Journal," of Paris, to visit a hos pital in Picardy set apart for wounded Ger mans, narrates the following incident :-In the ward lie was inspecting he noticed a singu lar expression of hatred on the face of a patient who made signs he wished to speak to the Frenchman. Tlig latter approached tho bed. "You are a journalist,*' said the wounded man in excellent French, "will you interview me ? Sit down and listen." "With an awful expression of fury and hatred in his blue eyes the man, writes Mr. Lordon, exclaim, ed passionately, "I hate the Germans ; I hate *theyBosches, as you call them." "Yes,*mon

sieur, '' he continued in reply to the French man's marks of surprise, "I hate them with all my heart, with all my soul. That aston ishes you ; well, you will soon understand me better. If I am here on a hospital bed so badly wounded that there is a slight hope of recovery, it is not a French bullet that .brought it "about. No, I.was struck traitor ously, from behind by a German'officer;. This was1 about1 tiie middle b£-">3eptember in the neighborhood of X, just at the moment when we were preparing to take the offensive. In one of our tr^gehes that your soldiers had just reached, a French officer had fallen, his legs crushed. ' "We .were still there/ a handful of Germans holding* oui-f A lieutenant or dered me to run my bayonet through- the wounded French officer's body. I refused with horror to execute the order. At the same time another German officer passed bo hind me, and With his revolver stretched me "on the ground. I was picked up . by your men, adn conveyed to this ambulance. 'The | traitorous bullet pierced my chest from front ' to back. I know the name of my assassin. He is called Karl St'runberg, iand is a sub lieutenant. "What-1 pray for every day is, that I may live till the end of the war and then'(I will revenge myself ,^pon hirri mag nificently. You now understand, monsieur," he concluded, why I hate these covvards."

that the German flanking columns uamtf'into collision with each other, and inflic ted heavy losses upon them selves bolbi-o tho discovery of the mistake. The Rus sians then attacked success fully, and expelled the Geiv mans.

article.heading: GERMAN V. GERMAN.
article.snippet: News of a disaster to German destroyers was published on September 4, and as there was no report of a naval action with either the English or Russian
article.articleText:
CERMAN V. CERMAN.

.News ot a disaster to German de. stroyers was published un September i. . and us there was no' report of a naval action with either the English or Kussian fleets, it was at first supposed that the damaged vessels were the csranccr. from

me i-umci iikih wi.ii me urimn lorpeao licet, from which some vessels, it wa- known, hud escaped in a broken condi tion, ft is now known that the vessels had been fired on by another detachment of the German licet, which had mistaken them for the enemy's ships; ..-? ' . The German torpedo flotilla was engag ed hunting for passenger /ships in the

in the distance. Concluding' that these were Russian ships, the flotilla at once engaged them, and a lively battle ensued. Before the error Was discovered, sevc ral..cru:sers and a number of destroyers had been badly damaged, and these all returned to Kiel together for repairs. A number of wounded were also landed. -

article.snippet: LONDON, Saturday.—German official: South of the Somme, we withdrew our advanced troops, thus [?] Essingy-le-Grand. The evening
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty.—Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Saturday.— German offi- cial: South of the Somme, we with- drew our advanced troops, thus evacu- ating Essigny-le-Grand. The evening gained a footing on the high ridges W. of Jouy.

article.heading: GERMAN.

article.snippet: LONDON, Wednesday.—German official: We withdrew from parts of our salient lines near St. Quentin. N.W: of Rheims and W. of the
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty.— Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Wednesday. — German official: We withdrew from parts of our salient lines near St. Quentin, N.W. of Rheims and W. of the Ar- gonne. The enemv obtained a footing in Ledgehem (S. of Roulers), but our counter-attack regained the eastern

part. On the fifth day of the Cambrai battle we repulsed seven assaults N. of Sancourt, and further south the enemy advanced beyond Abancourt, Bantigny, and toward Cuvillers. Our counter-attack pushed him back beyond Abancourt and Bantigny. Th enemy's xxxx broke down at and south of Cambrai. The enemy captured Rxxmilly and occupied St. Quentin. We withdrew from the Vesle, N. of Rheims.

article.heading: German.
article.snippet: We repulsed partial attacks in the region of Merris and astride the Ayetts River. The enemy strongly attacked our new lines northward of
article.articleText:
German.

We repulsed partial attacks in the region of Merris and astride the Ayetts River . The enemy strongly attacked our new lines northward of the Ourcq and on the wooded heights

south-westward of Rheims. We threw them back inflicting very heavy losses. Very heavy repeated attacks against the Hartennes-Fere- en-Tardenois front and also as far as the Meunssre Wood broke down before and at our lines, and some- times under our counter-attacks.

A Berlin communique merely stated:— "No change as far as German troops are concerned. The Russians covered 25 miles to Lutsk in three days through fortresses and marsh lands, and over battered de-

fences."

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The Border Morning Mail and Riverina Times (Albury, NSW : 1903 - 1920)

article.snippet: A wireless German official message says Southward of Thiescourt the enemy captured Attich Farm. The enemy suffered heavily in the fighting for Lassigny.
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

A wireless German official message says: Southward of Thiescourt the enemv captured Attich Farm. The enemy suffer- ed heavily in the fighting for Lassigny. We drove him back six times during the hours of heavy fighting. A German official message on Sunday says: We repulsed repeated attacks on

both sides of Roye, extending northward as far as south westwards of Chaulnes and southward as far as north westward of Lassigny. The enemy near Royencourt gained ground in the direction of Roye. Our counter-attack threw him back. Re- peated French attacks southward of the Avre collapsed. Allied airmen have dropped bombs on Darmstadt, the capital of Hesse-Darm- stadt, in Germany.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: An artillery battle has developed between Zborow and Brzezany. It is also lively at Zwyzyn, Brody, and Smorgon. A Roumanian preparation for an attack
article.articleText: GERMAN. An artillery battle has developed be- tween Zborow and. Brzezany. It is also lively at Zwrxyn, Brody, and Smorgon. A Roumanian preparation for an attack southward of Casinu Valley was dispersed under our fire. The enemy is restless along the lower Danube. Massed Russian assaults at Brzezany and between Zborow and Koniuchy broke down heavily.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article.snippet: LONDON, Sunday.—German official: We evacuated Bruges, Thielt and Kortrik. On both sides of Vouziers, the enemy established himself on the east
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty. — Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Sunday.— German official: We evacuated Bruges, Thielt and Kor- trik. On both sides of Vouziers, the enemy established himself, on the east bank of the Aisne.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: Herr Dernburg, the Kaiser's Press agent for America, and probably one of the most blundering and thoughtless persons in the world, has deemed it fit to deliver himself publicly on
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

Herr Dernburg, the Kaiser's Press agent for America, and probably one of the most blun- dering and thoughtless persons in the World, has deemed it fit to deliver himself publicly on the subject of — tact!

It was at a meeting of a league newly-form- ed in Berlin with a view to expanding German industrial interests in the South American continent. Herr Dernburg, who had been elec- ted president, said, according to a Reuter mes- sage from Amsterdam received recently: — 'Germany has only a few friends in the world. Feeling in South America is divided, and real neutrality in North America is also doubtful. 'It is not uninteresting to note how Lord Haldane at Manchester explained to British merchants that now a favorable opportunity had come to snatch away from Germany her commercial supremacy for ever. "For generations to come, we need not fear competition abroad, though, if the present war ,.?.'. Iasts a long time, commerce will, at last, be obliged to find new outlets, and the recapture of the ground now lost will become more dif- ficult. "For coal and iron South America will be dependent on the industrial States for a long time to come, and, therefore, the investment of more capital in South America will be well worth while for commercial reasons, and also in order to regain lost ground. ''Besides strengthening our economic influ- ence, the obtaining of a certain intellectual influence will be of an importance which, up

till now, has been greatly under-estimated. "We have not understood the soul of the South Americans, and not of them alone. For this reason, we find few friends among neu- trals. This is largely the fault of the Ger- mans, who must learn to understand foreigners and introduce German achievements in science and art with more discretion than heretofore. "Only too often the German merchant shows an absence of that friendly feeling towards merchants abroad which is of special weight with Southern people."

article.heading: German [?]
article.snippet: It is a mistake to suppose, when reading of peace talk in Germany, that the topic is a new one there. It is not. I heard the German
article.articleText:
German Ideas of Peace

By D. Thomas Curtin

It is a mistake to suppose, when reading of peace talk in Germany, that the topic is a new one there. It is not. I heard the German people talking peace a month after the outbreak of war—of a peace

to be sure which Germany would dictate and keep. When the Fatherland was winning I heard no discordant note. That was owing

to the general belief in and eager- ness for certain victory and vast annexation which prevailed then. To-day the Germans — with the exception of a minority of extreme Social Democrats — are no less united in their desire to get all they can, but they are not all united in their opinions as to how much they can get. Hence, after the French definitely blocked the German of- fensive at Verdun and the British Fleet grip more and more tightly the economic life of German, a

bewildering variety of Kriegsziele (war aims) was discussed by all classes of people. The National Liberal Party in Germany, as I have already in- dicated in a previous article on submarines, is backing a gigantic and aggressive plan for German world-domination through a colossal organisation and expansion of Ger- man commerce and industry. The great captains of industry who con- trol the party believe in the em- ployment of the German Army and Navy to further their ends — i.e., to secure permanently for Germany

the mining regions of Northern France and the coal and shipping of Belgium ; and to cripple rival commerce, not only as a means of winning the war, but also of limit- ing competition against them after wards. These are the men behind Tirpitz, and they are working, and will continue to work, to restore him to power. Dr Stresemann, one of the most influential National Liberals, is a dynamo of energy in German com- mercial plans. His eyes sparkling with zeal, reddish hair, a clear, metallic voice, he is a heavy man physically, wielding a tremendous and growing power in Germany to- day. He has a controlling interest in a recently organised combination of some two thousand manufactur- ing firms, and is practically dictator of the Sachsische Handelsgesell- schaft and the Deutsch-Amerikan- ische Wirthschaftsverband. He became one of theChancellor's most out-spoken enemies at the

time of the Danish concessions to America, and his fiery advocacy of relentless submarine warfare has earned him a reputation for fright- fulness, even in Germany. He be- longs to the Western School of pre- sent-day Germany — the school which believes in placating Russia (to be followed by a peaceful pene- tration of that country) and the smashing as far as possible of Britain and France. As his utter- ances in the Reichstag plainly show, he is passionately anti-American in general and anti-Wilson in par- ticular. Since he is one of the foremost Germans in the great campaign against Great Britain both during and after the war, Dr Stresemann's views should be of particular in- terest. His most recent utterances agree in the main with those he made in an interview which he gave me, and which I duly communi- cated to American newspapers through the Wilhelmstrasse. There are, however, some important dif- ferences which I shall point out

later. "How seriously do German in- dustrial circles regard the Paris Economic Conference?" was the first question I put to Dr Strese- mann. "If one is to attach great import- ance to the words of the political economists of the Entente," he be- gan, "then we must agree that we might have considerable anxiety and alarm about our industrial fut- ure; but, as a matter of fact, Ger- man industrial circles view these endeavors of our enemies with calm- ness of indifference. "Russia cannot emancipate her- self from German industry. As for France, she may look to a boy- cott of German wares. Yet that

will make no appreciable difference in our world trade, even though here and there we may drop a few million marks. We have but to consider France's tremendous losses in relation to her already falling birthrate before the war to realise that France must inevitably sink to the rank of a third rate Power. "After the war Great Britain will probably stand united against us, politically and economically, but we fear her just as little as we fear Russia and France. We rely first of all upon the peerless quality of our goods — just think of our chemical, textile, and toy monopo- lies, and the like — and, secondly, we rely on our unsurpassed mar- kets for consumption. "In 1913 we imported for ex- ample, from Great Britain and her colonies 2,109 ,000,000 marks (£105,450,000) worth of goods. Do you for a moment believe that our rival is going to sacrifice such a tremendous volume of business for the sake of a personal spite? Any tariff war which is waged against us can injure us, but it is bound to injure the side just as much. That will be realised all the more in England, since these threats drive us into a closer trade and industrial relationship with our allies, thus affording us a greater extent of united industrial territory to oppose the industrial chicaneries which our enemies have developed during the war. In this we shall undoubtedly be successful at the Peace conference. "With the United States we

shall resume trade immediagelyafter the end of hostilities. The war has caused both of us to become un- comfortably short in some. com- modities. Consequently, the first demands after our resumption of trade will restrict free competition, since both sides must limit them- selves at first to importing the most necessary commodities. You will need dyestuffs, for example ; we must have certain raw materials. "To be sure, trade rivalry will be keen in other markets, especially in South America. It is there where immense capital is necessary for extensive undertakings, and we fully realise your advantage over us for the present in this respect, for it is you who have made the greatest economic gain out from the world war, a gain which puts millions upon millions of ready money, while bleeding Europe will emerge from the struggle economi- cally weakened. "We Germans would not dispute your legal right if you would balance the munition deliveries to our enemies with raw materials and

foodstuffs to us." Dr Streseman then went on to explain that America did not really understand Germany because she looked at her through the "dis- torted eyeglasses Of Reuter." "It is only in British fancy," he said, "that we are going to wage war against Brazil or other South American States in order to establish colonies. "You look calmly on while Britain rules half the world, while she militarily controls the gates of the world in Egypt, India,

Cape Colony, Canada, and Gib- raltar. In your opinion that is all right ; but if in peace time Ger- many indicated that she wished a coaling station or two to protect her vast trade, then half the press of the universe rose in an outcry against the German lust for 'con- quest' and the 'world domination' she wished to establish. We stand second in world trade. In exports we are only 300,000,000 marks (£15,000,000) behind England, and we surpassed her by more than 3,000,000,000 marks (£150,000, 000) in exports, if we exclude British exports to her own Colonial Emgire, which buys 4,000,000,000 marks' (£200,000,000) worth of goods from her annually, she would long ago have been defeated by Germany in free world competition — defeated, however not by unfair methods, but by the superior qual- ity of German goods."' In the "Through German Eyes" column of ''The Times" recently is discernable a more anxious strain in Dr Stresemann's remarks concerning the Paris Economic Conference. Russia, in particular, seems to have considerably dis- mayed him. The meeting of the Russo-British Chamber of Com- merce at the Savoy Hotel, at which Count Benchendorff, the Russian Ambassador, presided, should prove further unpleasant news in the Fatherland. Note that Dr Stresemann now says:— 'We do not yet know the end of the struggle. We know that we are military invincible. But wherever an economic heel of Achilles shows itself England will make every attempt to bleed us to death. The peace must include the restoration of free competition in face of the resolution of the Paris Conference. When free com- petition is restored nothing can frighten us, because we know that in this freedom Germany can win the victory."— "The Times."

article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty - Per Wireless.}

LONDON. Thursday.— German offi- cial: English attacks this evening against Marquion and Havrincourt, and the canal sector failed. LONDON, Friday. — German offi- cial: Renewed English attempts be- tween the Arras-Cambrai and Peronne- Cambrai roads failed. The Franco-Americans attacked at the St. Mihiel bend. The fighting continues.

article.articleText:
German,

LONDON. Wednesday, 6.50 p.m.—"The French, by a strong thrust, in the direc- tion of Pinon, and southward of the Laffaux-Chavignon road, temporarily penetrated our lines, but our counter-

thrust drove them back."

LONDON, Thursday, 12.10 a.m.— "The Anglo-French attacked on a wide

front from Havrincourt Wood to the

Somme. Counter attacks are progressing. The enemy penetrated our centre be- tween Hargicourt and Emignon Brook. Elsewhere the attacks failed."

German.

LONDON, Wednesday, 1.45 a.m.— "We captured English and Portuguese positions northward of the La Bassee

Canal.

"We threw the enemy back across the Oise-Aisne Canal between Coucy le Chateau and Brancourt."

LONDON, Wednesday, 12.50 a.m.— "We captured Quincy, Landricourt, and Coucy le Chateau (south of La Fere)."

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The Gundagai Times and Tumut, Adelong and Murrumbidgee District Advertiser (NSW : 1868 - 1931)

article.snippet: Herr Denburg, the Kaiser's Press agent for America, and probably one of the most blundering the thoughtless persons in the world, has deemed it fit to deliver himself publicity on
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

Herr Dernburg,the Kaiser's Press agent for America, and probably one of the most blun- dering and thoughtless persons in the world, has deemed it fit to deliver himself publicly on the subject of— tact! It was at a meeting of a league newly-form-

ed in Berlin with a view to expanding German industrial interests in the South American continent. Herr Dernburg, who had been elec- ted president, said, according to a Reuter mes- sage from Amsterdam received recently: — 'Germany has only a few friends in the world. Feeling in South America is divided, and real neutrality in North America is also doubtful. 'It is not uninteresting to note how Lord Haldane at Manchester explained to British merchants that now a favorable opportunity had come to snatch away from Germany, her commercial supremacy for ever. 'For generations to come, we need not fear competition abroad, though, if the present war lasts a long time, commerce will, at last, be obliged to find new outlets, and the recapture of the ground now lost will become more dif- ficult. 'For coal and iron South America will be dependent on the industrial States for a long time to come, and, therefore, the investment of more capital in South America will be well worth while for commercial reasons, and also in order to regain lost ground. ' ''Besides strengthening, our economic influ- ence, the obtaining of a certain intellectual influence will be of an importance which, up till now, has been greatly underestimated. 'We have not understood the soul of the South Americans, and not of them alone. For this reason, we find few friends among neu- trals. This is largely the fault of the Ger- mans, who must learn to understand foreigners and introduce German achievements in science and art with more discretion than heretofore. 'Only too often tho German merchant shows an absence of that friendly feeling, towards merchants abroad which is of special weight with Southern people.'

article.heading: GERMAN [?].
article.snippet: In the Legislative Assembly yesterday the Minister for Education (Hon. H. F. Hardacre) informed Mr. Cart[?] that German pastors were given th[?]
article.articleText:
GERMAN PASTORS.

In the Legislative Assembly yester- day, the Minister for Education (Hon.

H. F. Hardacre) informed Mr. Carta that German pastors were given the same facilities as other ministers of re- ligion in regard to religious instruction during school hours. No discrimination had been made, no complaints had been received from German pastors in regard to such religious instruction, and the de- partment had no desire to make any discrimination.

article.articleText: German. (Reuter.) . Tuesday's German communique says:— "Gigantic reciprocal artillery fighting continues north of the Somme, being es- pecially bitter between Le Sars and the road from Ligny-Thilly to Flers. article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: Maryborough Chronicle, Wide Bay and Burnett Advertiser (Qld. : 1860 - 1947)

article.snippet: Kocnigen Luise, mine-layer, 10,735 tons. Built 1896. Sunk by the British destroyer Lance, near the mouth of the Thames, 4th August.
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

Koenigen Luise, mine-layer, 10.735 tons. Built 1896. Sunk by the British destroyer Lance near the mouth of the Thames, 4th August. Torpedo boat exploded and sunk in Baltic, 5th August.

U15 submarine. Sunk by British cruiser Birmingham in North Sea. Spindhaven, steamer, on Lake Ny- assa. Captured by British steamer. Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, auxiliary cruiser, 14.350 tons. Sunk by British cruiser Highflyer off the African coast, 27th August Magdeburg, cruiser, 4.550 tons. 12 4-inch guns. Built 1810. Ran ashore in

Baltic Sea and destroyed by Russian warships, 27th August. Goehen, battle cruiser, 23.000 tons 10 11-inch and 12.6 inch guns. 28\ knots. Built 19110. Took refuge in Dardanelles and sold to Turkey. Breslau, cruiser, 12 4-inch guns. 28 knots. Built 1910. Took refuge in Dardanelles and sold to Turkey. Mainz, light cruiser, 4.300 tons. 12 4-inch guns. 20 knots. Built 1905. Sunk in engagement Heligoland Bight, 21st August.

Koln, light cruiser, 4.350 tons, 12 4- inch guns. 26 knots. Built 1908. Sunk in Heliogoland Bight, 21st August. Ariadne, light cruiser, 2.650 tons, 10 4-inch guns, 21 knots. Built 1897. Sunk in Heligoland Bight, 21st August. Cap Trafalgar, auxiliary merchant cruiser, sunk off South America by Car- manin, 14th September. Spierwald, auxiliary merchant cruiser 3.899 tons. Captured North Atlantic September 20. Two destroyers, numbers not given. Sunk in Heligoland Bight, 21st August. Hela, small cruiser, sunk by sub- marine, September 16th.

article.heading: GERMAN
article.snippet: The pocket-book of an officer of a Saxon regiment has been found to contain particulars of outrages by his own troops.
article.articleText:
^GERMAN

The pocket-book of an officer of a Saxon regiment has been found to contain particulars of outrages by his own troops. A German cyclist at one village pretended to have been shot at. For this tho village was lired, and all the inhabitants were thrown into the flames. At Leppes 200 civilians were killed, the writer stating that the commander who was responsible could have prevented the pillaging and destruction.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: The following German ships were put out of action. BATTLESHIPS AND CRUISERS. Two Dreadnoughts sunk.
article.articleText: GERMAN. The following German ships were put out of action. BATTLESHIPS AND CRUISERS. Two Dreadnoughts sunk. One of Deutschland type (13,200 tons) sunk. Battle cruiser Lutzow (28,000 tons) sunk. Dreadnought severely damaged, pro- bably failed to reach port. Battle cruiser (ditto). LIGHT CRUISERS. Five light cruisers (one of large size) sunk. DESTROYERS, ETC. Six destroyers sunk (possibly nine). One submarine sunk.
