GERMAN.

(Admiralty— Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Friday.— German official: The enemy has captured Havricourt. Fresh enemy attacks between Moe- uvres and Gouzencourt were repulsed. In anticipation of an attack, the

evacuation of the St. Mihiel salient, which has been under consideration for years, was commenced a few days ago. The French advanced to the heights E. of Maas, and were repul- sed. We temporarily lost the Com- bres height, but it was recaptured by the Landwehr. Austro-Hungarians, S. of Combres, by their strong resist- ance, assured the retreat of our divi- sions at St. Mihiel. The enemy gain- ed ground neair Triacourt. The eva-

cuation of the salient was completed at night undisturbed. LONDON, Saturday.— Official: Our advance and the enemy advances led to violent fighting about Moeuvres and Havrincourt. Enemy attacks be- tween the Ailette and the Aisne fail- ed. The enemy felt his way forward E. of Combres and N.W. of Thiaucourt (in the St. Mihiel salient).

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: SUNDAY NIGHT.—We repulsed English local attacks, which entered our foremost lines westward of Locon. We repulsed enemy attacks on
article.articleText: GERMAN. SUNDAY NIGHT.--We repulsed English local attacks, which entered our foremost lines westward of Locon. We repulsed enemy attacks on Dom- miers and Villes Cotterets.

article.heading: German.
article.snippet: A Berlin communique reports- "General Hindenberg continues to storm the forfeited bridgehead at Leunewaden, north-west, of Friedrichstadt.
article.articleText:
German.

A Berlin communique reports: —

''General Hindenberg continues to storm the forfeited bridgehead at Leunewaden,

north-west, of Friedrichstadt.

"The Russians north-west and west, of

Vilna attempted to stop our advance, and failed with heavy losses.

"Our troops near Grodno, by means of a quick action, succeeded in crossing the Niemen and occupied Grodno town after street fighting. Four hundred prisoners

were taken.

"General von Gallwitz, on the road to Alekszyee, south of Adelsk Wiloz, broke

down the resistance of the Russian rear-

guard, taking over 3000 prisoners and 18 machine guns.

"General von Mackensen has reached Jasiolda, near Sjelec.

"General von Bothmer is approaching the south district, in Galieia, and is fighting without interruption."

Another Berlin communique states:—

"We stormed the bridgehead and road, taking 3325 prisoners. The enemy on both sides of the Vilna has abandoned 800 pri-

soners, besides dead and wounded.

"The whole fortress and forts at Grodno are in German hands. The Russians are

retreating fast, and are being pursued.

We captured six heavy guns with 2700 pri-

soners.

"The enemy evacuated his positions on the Niemen south of Grodno.

"Prince Leopold is fighting for the swamps and narrows north and north-oest. of Brzezanv, in Galicia."

article.snippet: News of the proclamation of a Rhenish republic caused much agitation in Berlin and fears for German unity. Herr Leinert one of the German peace delegated to
article.articleText:
GERMAN FEARS.

News of the proclamation of a Rhenish republic caused much agitation in Berlin and fears for German unity. Herr Leinert, one of the German peace delegates, to Versailles, says he attributes the Hano- verian movement to British diplomacy, as Great Britain desires to gain a foothold in the seaport of Bremen.

article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Reuter's Service).

A wireless German official mes- sage says:—

"We stormed Vlengelbroek Hill, northward of Bailleul. We repulsed English attacks westward of Bailleul and frustrated the strong defences north-west of Bethune."

article.snippet: LONDON, Sundny.—German official: Everywhere along the battlefront we are in our new positions. South of the Peronne Cambrai road, the
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

{Admiralty. — Per Wireless.) .

LONDON, Sunday. — German offi- cial: Everywhere along the battle-front we are in our new positions. South of the Peronne-Cambrai road, the ene- my attempted to approach them, and our rearguards yielded to a numeri-

cally superior enemy, and repulsed vio- lent attacks W. of Gousaucourt, Epehy and Templeux. South of the Ailette River, the ene- my reached our line B. of Vauxaillon.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article.snippet: LONDON, Tuesday.—Official: We repulsed attacks W. of Chaulnes and N.W. of Roye. We repulsed French attacks, after
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty— Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Tuesday.— Official: We repulsed attacks W. of Chaulnes and N.W. of Roye. We repulsed French attacks, after bitter fighting, between Bouvraignes and the Oise; also between Carlepont and Souvron. LONDON, Wednesday.— German offi- cial: The French attempted to break through our line between the Oise and the Aisne. The first assault broke down in our battle positions after a bitter struggle.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article.snippet: LONDON, Friday.—German Official: We repulsed partial attacks E. of the Meuse, the Austro-Hungarian specially distinguishing themselves.
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty — Per Wireless.) LONDON, Friday.— German Offi- cial: We repulsed partial attacks E. of the Meuse, the Austro-Hungarians specially distinguishing themselves. The Franco-Americans, advancing W. of the Aisne and E. of the Ar- gonne, employed numerous tanks. Our advanced posts, in accordance with orders, retreated fighting to their allotted defence lines. The enemy reached the heights N.W. of Tahure and Fontaine-Notre- Dame, where our reserves stopped the enemy's local attempt to break through. The enemy's attacks between Aub- erive and S.E. of Semmeny, also northward of Cernay, broke down. Between the Argonne and the Meuse, the enemy reached Mont Blainville. Montfaucon and the bend in the Meuse, N.E. of Mont- faucon, where he was brought to a standstill by our reserves. Fresh battles are imminent.

article.articleText:
GERMAN.

LONDON, Monday.— German offi cial: Sunday's fighting resulted in complete success for the Germans. Enemy attacks S.W. of Soissons and S.W. ot Hiirteunes broke down. Wo threw back tho enemy N. of Ville -liontoire, and we defeated an assault astride Oulchy-le-Chateau. Strong enemy attacks N. and N.E. of Chateau-Thierry broko down with heavy losses. Wo sanguinarily repulsed Anglo French attacks between the Marne and Ardre Rivers.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: The social which was held in aid of the Tennis Club was a marked success. Although the weather was very threatening about thirty couples
article.articleText:
GRAMAN

The social which was held in aid of the Tennis Club was a marked success. Although the weatber was very threatening about thirty couples were present. During tbe evening a presentation was made to the worthy

secretary, Mr. W. L. O'Brien. Mr. A. Lowe mads the presentation, and in a few fitting words said that the Club was indebted to Mr. O'Brien for his untiring efforts in furthering its interests. Mr. M. Robson endors- ed the last speaker's remarks, and said be hoped that although Mr. O'Brien was not actually in harness he hoped the CIub would not lose one of its most energetic members. Mr. O'Brien in responding, said he tried to do his best in the interests of the Club, but through pressure of busi- ness he was unable to do it justice, so he thought it better for the Club if he allowed some one else to fill his place. He again thanked the mem- bers, and said he would continue to do his utmost to advance its interests. A tennis match was played between Bannockburn and Gratnau last Satur- day. The game was very evenly and keenly contested, and was won by Bannockburn by the narrow margin of 4 games. We have experienced several frosts during the last few weeks, and of course everybody is wishing winter

over, and the nice warm days in its stead. Last Thursday at the School at 9 a.m. it was 32 degrees, a record for this year up to the present. By the way, the local school garden at the present is looking in tip top order, although it cannot boast of a garden equal to "Andersons" it will in the near future eclipse many so- called gardens. At the present time the local school is half-time, but it is to be hoped that before long it will be made into a provisional. REX.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article.snippet: LONDON, Friday.—German official: We repulsed attacks on the front on both sides of Ville-Mont-Soire, as far S. as Hartennes. Strong Franco-British
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

LONDON, Friday.— German official: We repulsed attacks on the front on both sides of Ville-Mont-Soire, as far S. as Hartennes. Strong Franco-British forces attacked from a line N. of Grand Rozoy and Fere-en-Tardenois, and their tanks on both sides of Brug- neux crossed our front lines, and reached the heights N. of Brugneux, but were ultimately shot to pieces. We sanguinarily repulsed infantry attacks. Enemy attacks N. of Cierges also failed.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article.snippet: LONDON, Monday.—German official: The enemy, who first gained ground on the Somme Canal, towards Essigny-Le-Petit, was pressed back on
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty— Per Wireless.)

LONDON, Monday.— German offi- cial: The enemy, who first gained ground on the Somme Canal, towards Essigny-le-Petit, was pressed back on Sunday as far as Remauckurt. The Americans continued their vio- lent attacks between the Argonne and the Meuse, and were beaten back on the heights E. of the Aisne.

article.heading: GERMAN.

title.title: Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate (NSW : 1876 - 1954)

article.snippet: Germany's luck has been out To understand this we want to read history. Hed there never been a great Empire of Germany, then possibly there would now be a
article.articleText:
GERMAN. Germany's luck has been out. To understand this we want to read history. Had there never been a great Empire of Germany, then possibly there would now be a great German Empire. We want to realise that the old German Empire was one made up of nations, and that some of these did great pioneerlng work which circumstances linked with their individual selves. If Australia were to take all New Guinea, and England approved, it would be an Imperial work, and our language being the same, the latter would stand even though ultimately we separated. Some of the work of Spain was done as part of the old German Empire: that is to say, the King of Spain was also the German Emperor. The old German Empire came too soon in last, albeit it did last

in one form and another for ages. Permanent Empire is dependent on rapid transit and quick intercommunications. Without the stcemboat and the telegraph, and also railways in conjunction, the present British Empire would be as impossible as was the former one. 1t is forgotten that there was an Anglo-French Empire, even though not that the thirteen American Colonies dissolved, the Anglo-American one to the extent that they were responsible for the title. German is the vernacular of a territorially small section of the world's surface. It is filled in solid in the little map. German is read or spoken to some extent in the shaded sections, for the following reasons— in parts through old control and the continued virility and influence of the strain, and over all through present Germany's commercial and flinancial relatlonships. To these we may add strain derivations, no matter of what date, and the face that German has been responsible for a great literature. Nevertheless partial use is not sufficient. Partial use in Germany's case means that in many spheres the language is merely classical. There is no domain for the vernacular to establish itself outside of Europe and spread.

article.articleText:
GERMAN.

(Admiralty: Per Wireless Press)

A wireless German official report states: — "Despite violent resistance south- eastward of Noyon we pressed back

the enemy to the wood from Carde- pont and Montagne. We captured the heights eastward of Moulin- soustouvex and lines westward of Nouvron, and attacked astride Ourcy, throwing back the enemy over Savieres sector, capturing the heights of Passy and Courchamps. The situation on the Marne is un- changed. "We repulsed violent French counter-attacks north-eastward Verneuil, astride Ardre. We cap- tured an enormous Franco-American depot near Fereen Tardenois." VANCOUVER, Sunday. A Berlin official message says: — "The Marne situation is unchang- ed."

article.snippet: Messrs T. Boss-Walker Ltd., of Hobart, have received from the International Frucht Import-Gesellsehaft, in Hamburg details of the sale of their
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

Messrs T. Boss-Walker Ltd., of Hob- art, have received from the Inter- nationale Frucht-Import-Gesellschaft, in Hamburg details of the sale of their shipments of Tasmanian apples ex- R.M.S. Comorin and Narkunda, tran- shipped from London. A portion of the

fruit suffered somewhat from detention in London and in the course of tran- shipment; but taken as a whole the shipments were delivered in very fair order. The best of the fruit sold as under, other parcels and portions of parcels inferior in quality or condition or of "plain" grade or under 2¼ inch, realised from m. 6.25 to m. 17.40, four cases wasty m. 400 and three cases very wasty down to m. 3.000. The mark is worth about 11¾d.

article.articleText:

Dr. Sonnenscheln tola a pr»*^ man the big problem In Germany was the payments under the Dawr' Scheme. 'Ten years after tbe war.' he said, 'wo don't know what we nus- pay. We do know that we have to pay two and a half milliard gold marks a year, equal to El!6,O00.O0-'. but we dont know what the total l- to be.' 33r. SonnenBcheln sola th* money had to be paid, but Germany did not get much chance to trade and raise it. Tariff walls were raised on all sides, and tbe building up of ex ports was difficult.

article.articleText:

At the general meeting of the! Limbless and Maimed Soldiers' As sociation in Sydney, regret wrb voicod that, at the annual conference of the Chambers of Commerce, ait ting in Hobart, a proposal to defer the resumption of trade with former enemy countries was defeated. A motion was carried unanimously, ex pressing abhorrence at tlic decision to resume trade with Germany so soon, "which, in the opinion of the limbless and maimed soldiers, shows a willingness to place greed of gold before the high principles that im bued the soldiers to fight for their country, and especially tho return ed soldiers wlio are still suffering severely."

article.heading: FORMERLY GERMAN.

title.title: The Tumut Advocate and Farmers and Settlers' Adviser (NSW : 1903 - 1925)

article.snippet: An advance copy of the mandate granted to the Commonwealth Government for the administration of former German territory in New
article.articleText:
FORMERLY GERMAN

An " advance copy of the mandate granted to the Commonwealth Gov ernment for the administration of . former German territory in New Guinea and the former German Is

lands in the Pacific lying south:of the. .equator, has been received by the, Prime Minister. It follows closely the main provisions of Article 22 of the Covenant of the League of Na tions, but differs slightly in its lang uage. The mandatory is to have full power of administration and legisla tion over the territory as an integral part of the Commonwealth of Austra 1 Jia, and may apply to it the laws of | the Commonwealth, subject to such

local modifications as circumstances

I require. The mandatory must pro j mote to-the utmost the material and

moral well-being and the social pro gress of the inhabitants, .must; see | that the slave trade is prohibited, and ! no forced labor permitted (except for | essential public works and services,

! and then only for adequate remunera ! tionj, and must also see that traffic

in arms and ammunition is control

[ led. The supply of intoxicating | spirits and beverages to the natives, I and the military training of the nat ! ives other than for tho purpose of in j ternal; peace and local defence, 1b pro-; hibited, and no naval or military I bases are to be established or fortifi j cations erected in the territory. The !. mandatory . must ensure freedom of

conscience and the free exercise of all forms of worship, and allow all missionaries and nationals, of any member of the League of Nations to enter into, travel, and reside in the territory for the purpose of prosecut ing their callings. An annual report is to be made to tho Council of the League of Nations, whose consent is required for any modification of the terms of the present mandate. If any dispute should arise between the man-; datory and another member of the League of Nations relating to the in-, terpretation or the application of the provisions of-the mandate, if it can not be settled by negotiations, it must be submitted to the permanent court of International Justice.

JAPAN'S DECLARATION

An official copy of the declaration made by the Japanese Government on the occasion of the settling of the mandates in regard to all; the man

dates in class "C" (German South-, west Africa, German Samoa, Nauru, the New Guinea territory, arid the is lands north of the, equator) .has also reached . Mr. Hughes. It .is as fol lows :-"From the fundamental spirit of the. League. of Nations, and the question of interpretation of the Cove nant, his Imperial Japanese Majesty's Government has a Arm conviction in the justice of the claim it has hitherto made for the inclusion of a clause concerning the assurance of equal op

portunities for trade and commerce; in "C" mandates. But from a spirit' of conciliation and co-operation and its reluctance to see the question set* tlod any longer, it has decided to ag ree to the issue of the mandate in its present form, Thet decision, however, should not be considered as an ac ial japaueaQ Majesty's Government .:n the BubmiSsieil of Japanese sub jects to a discHffiinatoiy aiid disad

vantageous tr6atiii6nt in the iiiah- 1 dated tcirriiorifes. Nor lias it tiifireby discarded Its filaiih that th6 rights and interests enjoyed by Japanese subjects in these territories in the past should be fully respected." The mandate conferred on Japan in re spect to the former German posses sions north of the equator is in the same terms as that for the New Guinea territory.

A message from Spa states that Herr Gessler, the German Minister far War, said that he Intends to retire from the Conference unless more fav orablo terms were granted. He would not Insist that Germmy should retain: an army of 200,000 men, but a strong force was necessary.

At the beginning of this month the Iritfer.e-Allied Military Commission, whijhs ias been supervising German dlsarmsament during the past six or seven.years, completed its labours In accrdance with the agreement reakhed :by the governments concern ed some little time ago. Wllatever supervision is necessary will now be, exeirclsed under the authority of the League of Nations. Thus Germany is tree at last of a humiliating sltuatlon, and one other cause of strife In Europe Is remoied. Naturally France regards thie change with some suspi cion, but it is within Gemmany', power, if her statesmen can rise above the petty satisfaction of "get ting even," to show that she is ma igned by those whose excuse for military preparattons Is her supposed determination on revenge. Germany is now a member of the League of Nations,. She has resumed her proper i~i?e tn international councils, and she can, ,r she will, help materla'Iy In the 'solution of some of the world's most 'pressing problems, for, ,n the nature of. things, she must depend not on might but on right

article.articleText: GERMAN OPERA. An nudionce as brilliant and numer ous as In the old days, assembled at the Covent Garden Theatre at the open ing of the German opera season, when Wagner's "Rhelngold" was performed in German for the first time eince 1914. Critics comment on the strangeness of tile sensation of listening agaipl to the correct slow German templ, and witnessing again of all the organlsod gestures of Wagnorlian drama, but agree that the performance was a most notoworthy one, going as far as to say tlat there must have beeoon a vocol as well as a political revolution In Germany', for the standard Is high 'r than ever. article.heading: GERMAN REBELS.

title.title: Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate (NSW : 1876 - 1954)

article.snippet: Herr Lipinski, an Independent Socialist, who is Saxon Minister of the Interior, made a remarkable speech in the Diet.
article.articleText: GERMAN REBELS. Herr Lipinski, an Independent Social Ist, who is Saxon Minister of the Inter jor, made a remarkable speech in the Diet. He declared that there were several notorious anti-Republican organisations. These were financed by the Saxon indus trialists to promote a conservative Pan German Government. One organisation, known as the Brethren of the Rock, he declared, was operating in Eastern Sax ony. Another was called the Ilohenzol lern Knighthood. Its headquarters were at Leipzig, The authorities confiscateu 700,000.marks, which had been collected by these organisations, whose functions included a secret fighting organisation, and a court to punish and-even sentence to death those obstructing the work.

article.articleText: GERMAN OITRAGE The railway bridge at Duren, in Rhen ish Prussia, was blown up by bombs a few minutes before the Brussels-Cologne express was duo to pass. Scnegalese soldiers warned the driver, who stopped the express in time to avoid disaster.

article.articleText: GERMIAN POLITICS The diiculties in regard to the form ation of a Ministry In Germany are not overcome. Horr Cuno Iabandoned his attempt owing to the opposition of poll tieal parties, but IHerr IEbert, the Pre sident, has requested him to make a further attempt with non-politicians. It was previously stalted tlhat Herr Cuno's chief diflculty would be to bal ance himself between the People's Party and the Socinlists, the latter, In ex change for their support, demanding the Homre Ofice and Economy portfolios, Ilerr Stinnes, whose ambition it is to become the industrial dictator of Ger many, Is not favoured by the Hamburg Sh?!ppin nabobs. Hterr Cuno is a direc tor of this line. He is personally ac quainted with President Harding, and is believed to hIold biroad and tolerant views on international affairs. Conse quently it is thought that ihe has the character and mentality necessary to grapple with the Reparationrs problenm, which cannot be solved without l3ritish goodwill and AmrericrL gold. article.heading: GERMAN CRUELTIES.

title.title: Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate (NSW : 1876 - 1954)

article.snippet: The hearing of the evidence of British war prisoners who were unable to attend at Le[?]psig in respect of the charges against the Germans of cruelty in prison
article.articleText: SGERMAN CiRUELTIES. The hearing of the evidence of Mritlsh war prisoners' who were unable to attend at Lelpsig in respect of the chargee against the Germans of cruelty in prison camps, began yesterday at Bow-streee, when German lawyers attended to cross exnamine the witnesses. The first charge was against MIuller, commandant of the Flavelemartel prison camp, of cruelties practised in April and June, 1918, where there were 500 dases of dysentery In a month, with an average of'six deaths a day. The evidence of the witnesses showed that there was no doctor at the camp, and the 'naccused habitually rode through the camp scattering the prisoners, whom he photographed in' their agonies. Dr. Stewart Melghen: ex-chaplain, and a war prisoner, stated that 90 sick Brit ish prisoners arriver at Stondahl oamp in June, 1918, from Flavelemartel. They were terribly emaciated, were verminous, and had undressed sores. A number of them died. Another witness stated that *between 50 and 60 of those died from lack of food and from ill-treatment.

article.articleText: GERMAN INDUSTRIES. The Derlin correspondent of thhe "Dally Chronicle" states that German in mustries are rapidly reviving, despite the heavy taxation, extensive and costly rye pairs, and tlmo renewals of plant. Examination of the balance-aheets of 161 comr.panies, published in September, lealong with Iron, steel, coal, textiles, hrew.erle, paper-making, glass and porce lain, shows that 168 paid increased dIvi lends, as compared with 1918-19, 59 paid sImIlar dividends, 13 paid decreased divi dends, and 19 ao dividends.

article.articleText: GERMAN REPARATIONS. It is reported from Berlin that as the result of the German delegation which is negotalnting with the Reparations Com mission in Paris, Germany has agreed to hand over to the Allies 1,740,000 fowls, 27,000 goats, and 15,350 pigs. She will surrender within a half year 30,000 horses, 1,250,000 sheep, 60,000 bulls and oxen, and 30,000 cosrs and heifers.

article.heading: GERMAN SHIPBUILDING.

title.title: Daily Commercial News and Shipping List (Sydney, NSW : 1891 - 1954)

article.snippet: The capture by a Swedish yard of the order for a motor tanker by the Hamburg firm of Albrechts was a very bitter pill for German shipbuilders to
article.articleText:
GERMAN SHIPBUILDING.

? The capture by a Swedish yard of the order for a -motor tanker by the Hamburg dm of Albreclits was a very bitter pill for German shipbuilders to swallow, for with their experience in the construction of this type of vessel they have been very successful in se curing Scandinavian orders, and cer

tainly did not expect to lose the con tract for an 8500-ton ship for native owners. The Swedish Government is willing to grant a certain amount of assistance to yards building for foreign owners, (tut not nearly, so much as when the ships are Tor native firms, while the rate of interest Is much higher. The German Government is now being persuaded to grant additional benefits to shipbuilders, with the recent order as the basis of campaign.

In view of the, fact that German cars may enter Australia in August' next it is interesting to note tho des- j tination of cars exported from Gm*-! m-iny last January. j

Then followed Bel Blum, 17 per cent.: Sweden and Spain. 9 per cent, each; Denmark. 8 per cent.; South-east Asia, G.G per cent.; South America, 2.7 per cent.; Switzer land. 1.6 per cent.; and Austria. 1.5 per cent. article.heading: GERMAN' FRIENDLINESS.
article.snippet: The principles of the foreign policy of the new German Cabinet, as enunciated by the Chancellor (Herr Mueller), reflect the neighbourly spirit which has recently
article.articleText:
GERMAN' FR-IENDL1NESS.

Jiic principles of the loreigu policy o! the new German Cabinet, as enunciated by the Chancellor (Herr*Mupller), reflect tlic neighbourly spirit which has. recently brought Germany nearer to friendly rela tions with other European nations llian she has been siiicc 1918. , As.the bitter ncss of the war period1 fades with the merciful passage of time, enmity is giv) ing place to "goodwill in Northern Europe; but while Germany strenuously repudiates* the idea of revenge) she loses no opportunity to protcslagainst foreign occupation. Co-operation for the poli

tical and economical consolidation ol Europe, ishc urges, is impossible 'without the immediate evacuation of Allied troop; from German territory. Germany is drilling to be friendly, but resents having to~ bear the brand, and. burden of the conquered. Although she can honestly claim to have attempted to make the reparations plan work, and. tc be a fviHing partner, in the Locarno treaties and a respected member of the League of Nations, she is not unmind ful of. the strength of the .opposition still offered " to her restoration, ; to ' inter national equality. Traditional French suspicions have'not been entirely allayed and Herr Mueller has taken a coura geous istand in unequivocally demanding complete relief from military oversight He challenges the other nations to give practical effect to their professions ol friendship. The challenge may not be answered as promptly as lie would like; but it will doubtless assist in the inevit

able readjustment of European relatione, j The plea is firm; yet it is significantly j

dispassionate, and bCars no trace-of the: aggressiveness which has marred the

effect of previous similar pronounce-j ments. In tliis respect, it confirms the I signs of the new spirit of reason mani fest in recent developments in German politics. : The members of the last! Government adroitly resisted the impor-: trinities of militaristic extremists; and,

although unable to retain office as the j Republic swung away from the Nation alists towards the Socialists, they have the satisfaction of noting the reaffirma tion of their friendly foreign policy. The German people have clearly turned theu faces away from the "mailed list" of. the old monarchy, and, 111 striving to estab

lish the Republic on the firmest founda

tion, they arc seeking the international harmony essential, to the recovery of domestic prosperity, as well as to the "whole economic situation of Europe.

CHILD ENDOWMENT.

Some time ago, the Public Service Asso- ] ciatipu appointed a committee to go iiito the .question of child endowment being in-, troduccd into the public services, and this committee, furnished a report 'at the last meeting of the council.' Inter alia the report stated:—"This council is of the opinion that' the 'only system of 'child en

dowment likely to find acceptance.by the i Government would be one in which the: costs are' borne by the service, such us the Commonwealth Public'Service scheme, and that the council -be 'recommended to authorize the committee to prepare a re

port as to the cost apd effect of 6Uch | scheme1 upon the State service, with a view

to obtaining; an opinion from members by meaus of a referendum." The report of the committee was adopted by tbe cpuncil and action taken along the lines suggested.

that the Government desired them to con clude-their enquiries at ^the earliest pos sible date consis'tent' with; a proper dis . cliargeof theduties allotted to 'them.' The | Tesult wbb that for the year 1927-28 tlie ex penditure under that heading was reduced to . Still further "effect had been

given to that. particular .ecoiiomy, until

now' the remarkable fact had to be re corded that to-day tbejrc was not'one royal [commission in existence in South Australia,

It would take much patient research to 'get. back to th'c period.,'When a similar condition of. affairs -existed in the State.

[ Of course, the establishment' of royaT com

missions in some circumstanced was'a wise'"

course, but it was the intention of Lis* Government "to exercise a much -etrieter J check upon such, appointments than had been the custom in the past.:

article.articleText:
GERMAN AMALGAMATIONS.

Four Public Service unions, affilia ted with the General Federation of German Trade Unions, arc planning to amalgamate. Railroad, transport, municipal, and flre-flghter unions, with a total .membership of a million, are Involved. A committee of 16 is to present a plan to be voted on by the membership.

Among the difficulties is the prob lem of- convincing the white-collar n-.cn ■within the unions of tho need for common action with workers on the docks, power stations, and rail and motor transport.

Thirty-seven national organisations ore affiliated with the German Federa tion of Trade Unions, with a member ship of about 4,000,000. Since 1925 four of the 41 national unions have amal gamated.

Forty-four muscles are called into play in the production of the human voice.

article.heading: GERMAN REALISM
article.snippet: "Winter," by F. Griese. Translated from the German by Adler Hobman Published by Longmans, London. A book as powerful as it is gloomy
article.articleText:
GERMAN REALISM

"Winter," by P. Griese. Translated from tbo German by.Adler Hobman- Published by Long mans,- London, >

A book .as powerful as it,is gloomy has been written by a German school* master who..has found his metier as a novelist, Griese. is a realist, with vivid »pen which is used with the - sparing economy of the artist and the imagina tion of the poet. Ilis picture of an obscure and.isolated farming village through a summer of drought followed by an early winter of phenomenal severity will not readily fade from the 'mind of those who absorb his pene trating chapters. The people upon whom this natural affliction is visited arc purely of the soilt simple, superstiti ous, self-centred, almost primitive >in their' loves and • hates. • The stark tragedy of that awful winter which left the farms desolate and deserted Is matched by the grimness of the per sonal histories unfolded. Men and women alike have the stolidness com-? mon. to the uneducated and specially characteristic' of the German rustic, and from this quality the author has weaved material that has all the elements of social drama. The hero Jona is the illegitimate offspring of a farmer's daughter and an . alien labourer who had been turned from the farm- when his attentions to .the girl became apparent. Jona has all the in articulateness .of the countryman and withstands every effort to induce him to set about getting a wife. Clearly he likes Grita, a neighbouring farmer's daughter, but hesitates to speak, and a less unwilling wooer in his cups forces his attentions on her with a crudity which leaves Grita in her unr sophisticated simplicity with no alter native but to marry" the man. But she determined to be wife . only in name and a grim scene on her wedding, night is only averted by the worse tragedy of the discovery that a wronged younger sister has killed herself under stress of taunts at the wedding supper table. Grita and her Thord in their estranged relations presents a "strange commentary on village heroics, -and the tense situation is ended by Jona fighting him to the death. Out of the village in which relentness snow storms had wrought despair and star vation the victor and Grita pass "into some shadowy prospect of a happier future. The story is a masterpiece .of fiction and carries the commendation of having won two literary prizes. •

article.heading: GERMAN REPARATIONS
article.snippet: What should Germany pay? In theory, the whole cost of the war which she provoked. But the bitter truth was long ago recognised—first
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPARATIONS

What should Germany pay? In theory, the whole cost of the war which she provoked. But the bitter truth was long ago recognised—first by Britain and last of all by exasper ated France—that neither Germany nor anyone else could possibly foot the whole bllL Moral obligation had to give way to potential fact, and the question became not what "should' but what "can" Germany pay? That

matter was closely studied through long years, averaging and calculatin; on a basis entirely business-like, ant' fixed amounts were determined, fai below the fair but touching only the possible. No one expected the Germans to welcome this minimum, but at least it was thought that they would feel that they had done pretty well in comparison .with what might have been insisted on (and what they themselves would have exacted, if victorious, from others). Acceptance of the Inevitable should surely have been their proper course. Instead of this, however, we find ourselves face to face with new demands for further remissions. An Insidious campaign 'in forma pauperis" has been steadily afoot Against-this, the French have unceasingly .protested, though in England a certain degree of sympathy has at times been mildly shown. British opinion, however, has now been considerably stiffened by the Parker Gilbert report That document, apart altogether from its highly convincing business side, merely puts into words the justifiable conviction of the average Briton, who, not at all disposed to kick even the most ruthless enemy when down,. Is nevertheless quite tinable .to see why the losers of a wanton and deliberate war should suffer from its effects In a less degree than those who ltchleTed a defensive victory. Forthatwas all that the Allies gained br,could gain — successful resistance,to ^threatened destruction.: In gaining: tt^toiey';«^p)£nitned themselves, nonejnoreso than Britain. And It certainly the TOrr Climaxof unreason that reparations (there Is no question ol ^nflemnitles) which have already bpen^ifeed flown to tar betow &e st&3ard i>f :«hat would have been : righ^i^ jMtlce should t>e the iBeonans . gome-

what inconvenient All tiie evidence suggests that Britain is even yet bear ing heavier burdens than they, having lost some of her markets even to the Germans themselves. At present: most of Britain's sympathy and concern are sorely needed for lier own family, and -what there is over and to spare may well be extended rather to Germany's victims than to Germany. This is cold justice, not hot vindictiveness. Britain does not bear ill-will. Hp to almost the outbreak of the war, Germany had her friendship, for the mass of our "people disregarded all warning. That friend ship she deliberately destroyed though even already, after all that has happened, there arc signs that she may gradually recover it if she conducts herself with ordinary sense. She won back a certain amount of respect from the discerning by her refusal tc go Bolshevik at a time when temptation pointed to that course as s possible escape from all debts whatever. Having resisted that, her pose of mendicancy comes with all the poorer spirit. Nor •will it be accept ed. The mere proposal has united the Allies more closely again, drawn Britain nearer to the French point "of vie. Germany has hitherto been remarkably lucky, not through deserv

ings but by force of circumstances She ought to recognise that, and not to lodge appeals which border very closely on presumption.

article.heading: German Reparations
article.snippet: The fifth and most important year for the payment of reparations under the Dawes plan began on September 1. The annuity for 1928-9 amounts to
article.articleText:
German Reparations

The flfth and most important year for the payment of reparation? under the Dawes plan began on September 1. The annuity for 1028-9 amounts to £125,000, 000, and constitutes the so-called "stand- ard" payment. It represents an increase of £37,500,000 over the fourth annuity The whole of this increase has to.bo ob- tained from the German Budget, the con- tribution of which rises from £25,000,000 to £62,500,000. The transport tax will again contribute £14,500,000, the German railway bonds £33,000,000, and the Ger- man industrial debentures £15,000,000 In future the standard annuity Is subject ti modifications only through the applica- tion of the index of prosperity, which may serve to Increase It, or It may be in- creased or decreased on account of changes In the general purchasing power of gold. The German Budget contribu- tions nre taken from the controlled re- venues (i.e.. Customs, tobacco, sugar, beer and spirits monopoly), by the Com- missioner of Controlled Revenues as re- ceived and aro paid over monthly to tho Agent-General, payments being mnde about the fifth of the month; but in view of the larger nmounts to be paid in the fifth year it has been arranged that the payments in 1928-9 shall be mado on

| three occasions during each month so as

. to avoid an undue tying up oí funds, .

article.heading: German Census.
article.snippet: The provisional results of the census of June 16 show that the population of Germany is 62,500,000, or about the same as in 1908, as
article.articleText:
German Census. , —

The provisional results of the census of June 16 show that the population of Germany is 62,500,000, or about the same as in 1908, as compared with 68,000,000 at the outbreak of the war. It is estimated that Germany lost 7,000,000 by the cession of territories under the Peace Treaty, 2,750,000 from deaths in wartime, and 2,500,000 by the decrease of the birthrate in wartime; therefore, but for tho war the population would have been 75,000,000. Nevertheless, the population has increased 3,333,000 as compared with 1919, and Berlin is the second largest city in Europe, with a population of 3,900,000.

article.heading: GERMAN INDUSTRY.
article.snippet: Sir Philip Gibbs gives a remarkable account of the new spirit and the renewal of industry in Germany. "Her people are working harder than
article.articleText:
GERIAN INDUSTRY. Sir Philip Gibbs gives a remarkable account of the new spirit and the re newal of industry in Germany. "Her people are working harder than any others, at lower wages, and with more efficient organisation. They have been braced by defeat, whereas the victor nations, and above all Great Britain, have been slackened by victory," he writes in the "Review of Reviews." The Change in the People. "When I went first into Germany after the armistice the people seemed stupefied by what had befallen them. All their faith had been shattered by the downfall of their armies, and they were afraid of revolution, and hopeless. ly uncertain of the future. Many of them, ;especially the women and chil dren, were still suffering from the effects' of long under-feeding, ,prices of food, clothing, and other necessities of life were above the reach of working folk, demobilised soldiers were not yet assimilated into civil life. and the spirit of the people was dejected and de spairing. "Now, in Berlin the general' appear ance of the people is not miserable but cheerful, not dejected but alert and con fident. One does not see crowds of listless unemployed men hanging about labour exchanges or rattling collecting boxes in the faces of the passers-by. One sees crowds of men stepping out briskly, obviously employed, well-dressed, well-fed, keen" on their jobs, doing good business. Krupp's 5s. Day. "The German working man in Krupp's factories and others, is paid 60 marks a day. At the old value of the mark that would be £3. At the present value, inside Germany itself, I reckon it as five shillings. "For an eight-hour day it works out at 74d. an houi compared with 1s. 9d. to 2s. 6d. an hour of the mechanic in \Great Britain. "The German working man on 60 marks a. day gets almost enough to eat (never enough meat), almost enough to support a wife and small family, almost enough to make himself satisfied' with his job. By strict attention to economy, he can squeeze out a few marks for the simple pleasures of his leisure hours, which consist mostly in light beer and light music in some public garden or beer-hall. "The professional classes, and the clerical classes (city clerks, typists, etc.) are not so well off relatively as the mechanics' and labourers. Whereas the cost of living has increased from eight to 10 times, the salaries of professors, teachers, civil .servants, and others have only risen from 4 to 6 times. It is they who are most pinched 'and reduced to desperate straits in order to 'keep up appear ances. . A New Industrial Organisation. "Now, upon the great mass of cheap labour German capitalists are building up a new and intensive sytem .of indus trial organisation, beyond anything the world has previously seen in efficiency and driving power. Hugo Stinnes,and his'great Trust, controlling a vast mo nopoly of coal, iron and steel, of whom there has been much talk, because he re presents most powerfully 'this new phase of German energy, is only one of a score of other magnates who prac tically control the whole industrial life of .Germany, and are the real rulers of. the State. "Their method is what is described as the creation of 'vertical' trusts. That is to say, by a combination and pool ing of many companies in possession of raw material and industrial plant they build up an immense production .of manu factured articles which have that raw material as their basis. Krupp's Peaceful Output. "Thus the great munition works of Krupp, entirely engaged in, the produc tion of guns and armaments during the war 'bon a colossal scale, read the lesson of defeat, and within a few months after the Armistice, adapted their plant and their organising genius in a marvellous way to the requirements of peace. They are now making engines and machinery of all kinds, agricultural implements, cash registers, safety razors, and any kind of article in iron and steel for which there is a world market. The General Electric Company is also de veloping its energy with gigantic strides, reaching out to 'neutral' countries and absorbing many industrial concerns of which the basis of activity is coal and iron and electrical power, in Austria, Hungary, and other countries.. "These great Trusts, are already cap turing the world's markets, and have already succeeded in recovering some of the pre-war. prosperity of German trade-which is almost a miracle con sidering the ruin of the German economic system by the exhaustion of a bloody and unsuccessful war, the loss of colonies, shipping, and foreign pro perty, the loss of man power, and the deterioration of machinery, railways, and rolling stock. Imports Falling Off. '¶masing as all this is, however, one must not exaggerate the actual results. Germany is not rolling in wealth, as some observers have reported. Apart alto gether from her international debts leaving on one side altogether the gigantic payments of the indemnities which she has undertaken-her industry and com merce are about two-thirds normal com pared with the pre-war standard. Her imports of cotton amount to nearly half of thcse in 1913. Her ioal output during the first four months of this year was 44,500,000 tons compared with 57,000,000 toxas in the same period of 1913. "Half the amount of pre-war tonnage (largely under foreign flags) is now coming into the port of Iamburg.

If They Pay! "All this is a sign of industrial and conmmunercial recovery, astoundmg as a proof of cnergy, industry, and organised efficiency, after the shock of national de feat. But those German people who have put up such a tremendous fight for their old place in the world are now confronted with the necessity of paying indemnities to the victor nations which will test their power of recovery to the uttermost and demand new and unpre cedented efforts. It is not going to be easy for them to pay. If they suc ceel, it will be the greatest industrial adventure ever undertaken by any people in the world. To succeed they must in crease their volume of exports by at least fotir times, which would be an achievement unrivalled in the industrial history of the world. Con they do that. and if they do what will be the effect upon other nations? "It has already been asked by Mr. Reginald McKenna. What will happen to British trade if Germany pays her indemnities in the only way possible by an immense increase of exports? The very fulfilment of her pledges will ruin the countries receiving payment by the destruction of their own export trade. .o we reach the monstrous para dox that in shouting *Make Germany pay!' we were insisting upon our own ruin. The only aure for the present sickness of world trade is to return to normal canditions of imports balancing exports, and of a free and natural flow of trade. "Condensing very briefly the results of my visit to Berlin, it will be seen that in my opinion Germany will make a serious endeavour to fulfil her pledges, and is in a fair way (if she retains the resources of ,her raw material in Upper Silesia and elsewhere) to capture the industrial supreieny of Europe."

article.heading: GERMAN WOOLS.
article.snippet: "During the last few weeks several Bradford houses have received offers of fair-sized parcels of "German-grown" wool in the grease, and this unusual
article.articleText:
GERMAN WOOLS.

"During the last few weeks several Bradford houses have received offers of fair-sized parcels of "German-grown" wool in the grease, and this unusual develop- ment has occasioned some comment," re- marks the "Wool Record and Textile World" of July 24. "At one time, of course, large weight« of German wool were imported, but for many years past the comparatively small quantity grown in Germany has been disposed of in that country. In 1824 we imported 44,000 bales of German merino wool and 25.000 bales from Spain, those countries being [ the chief sources of supply. The relative ! importance of the then wool-exporting ! countries may be gathered from the fact . that, in the same year, we imported ? from Sydney 972 bales, from Tasmania ' 619 bales, and from the Gape 43 bales. A recent estimnte of the number of sheep in Germany gives the total at just over Si millions, so that it is obvious that the amount of wool available is very small. The significant thing is that Ger

man. (firms are finding the financial strin- gency so acute that they are offering their "domestic wools in a market where there is some prospect of realising sterling, the natural inference being that their usual customers at home arc un- able to pay cash."

One of the most heavily hit of the German in dustries at the present moment is the automobile trade/ wiiick before the war had quite a considerable export business. Since the war, not only has its expert become almost negligible, but a consider able amount of foreign competition, espe ciaDy from the United Sratcs, has had to be faced in the home market. article.snippet: The correspondent for the "Petit Parisien" at Berlin says that German Government circles have abandoned the idea of seeking an immediate foreign
article.articleText:
GERMAN DECISIONS.

Thc correspondent for the "Petit Pa risien " at Berlin says that German Government circles have abandoned the idea of seekuig an immediate foreign loan of 20,000 million gold marks.

It lias been decided to seek 500,000, 000, together with a three to four years' moratorium in order to stabilise the finances and enable a larger loan

to be raised later.

article.heading: GERMAN NAVY
article.snippet: President Von Hindenburg last week reviewed the first German naval parade since the war. The whole fleet, except ships on service, took part. It
article.articleText:
GERMAN NAVY

President Von Hindenburg last week reviewed the first German naval parade since the war. The whole fleet, except ships on service, took part. It consisted of four armored battleships, three cruisers, the first and second torpedo flotillas, and three new de- stroyers. There were no seaplanes or submarines, the construction of these being forbidden by the Treaty of Ver- sailles. The same manoeuvres were carried out as at the battle of Jutland.

article.heading: GERMAN POLITICS.
article.snippet: THE NEW CABINET. Following: the recent election, the new Prime Minister (Hermann Mueller) selected a new Cabinet. Seated—Dr. Erich Koch-Weser, Minister of Justice; Herr Hermann Muller, Premier; General Groener, Minister of Defence; Herr Wissel, Minister of Labor. Standing—Herr Hermann Dietrich, Minister of Food Supply; Dr. Hilferding, Minister of Finance; Dr. Ernst [?], Minister of National Economy; Dr. Karl Severing, Minister of the Interior; Herr von Guerard, Minister of Occupied Territories, and Dr. Schaetzel, Minister of Communications.
article.articleText:
GERMAN POLITICS.

THE NEW CABINET. Following the recent election, the new Prjme Minister (Hermann Mueller) selected a new Cabinet. Seated — Dr. Erich Koch-Weser, Minister of Justice; Herr Hermann Muller, Premier; General Groener, Minister of Defence; Herr Wissel, Minister of Labor. Standing — Herr Hermann Dietrich, Minister of Food Supply; Dr. Hilferding, Minister of Finance; Dr. Ernst Curtius, Minister of National Economy; Dr. Karl Severing, Minister of the Interior; Herr von Guerard, Minister of Occupied Territories, and Dr. Schaetzel, Minister of Communications.

article.heading: GERMAN CARS
article.snippet: The Permanent International Motor Manufacturers' Bureau in Paris has agreed to the principle of readmitting Germany. It is therefore (states a
article.articleText:
GERMAN CARS

The Permanent International Motor Manufacturers' Bureau in Paris has agreed to the principle of readmitting Germany. It is therefore (states a Lon don motor journal) highly probable that German cars will be seen at the Olyni pia Show next year.

article.heading: GERMAN REVOLUTION.
article.snippet: Official circles in London consider there Is now a good prospect of order being completely restored in Germany. The British diplomatic representative
article.articleText: GERMAN REVOLUTION. Official circles in London consider there Is now a good prospect of order being completely restored in Germany. The British diplomatic representative congratulated the Constitutional Government on Dr. Kapp's overthrow. He warned the Government that the Allies would only supply foodstuffs provided order prevailed in the country. The Parts "Matin" learns that Admiral Evers has been appointed Governor of Keil. The disarming of the troops there continues. The workers in Leipzig, where fighting has been resumed, shot down an aeroplane. Seven hundred people wore killed in Dortmund, and 400 around Essen. Correspondents estimate that the number of killed in Germany during the week exceeds 2000 One thing the revolution has achieved has been the increase of the German people's hatred of millitarlsm, which will result In a stronger democratic control of the army. The lynching of 20 officers of the Baltic Contingent it a Schoneberg suburb was due to their arrogant attitude causing the mob to pull them from a motor lorry, one by one, and beat and kick them to death.

article.snippet: PARIS, Monday.—Replying to Herr Cano's protest against the occupation of Mannheim and Kalrsruhe and the workshops at Darmstadt and

article.articleText: GERMAN REPARATIONS. MEILBOURNE, Fri.-Sir Jo0oliah Cook, in the House of Representativca, laid on the table a telegraphed sneu mary supplie' by the British Govern ment, of the precise reparation terms accepted by Germany. Tile summar; shows that the total amount payable under articles 231 and 232 of the Treaty of Versailles, without prejudice to ab ligations unrder article 238 and other: had been fixed at £6,600,000,000. lseo the amnonunt already credited Jn eas pcet of sums paid or State property in ceded territories. This amount is in addition to the amount of the Belgian debt, duo to tile Allies, and will tre liquidated by means of the issue of several series of bonds, eecured on ti:e whole of the assets and revenue of the German Empilre. Germany is to pay eaclh year until the redemption of thtr bIonds-firstly. £ 100,000,000 sterllhg, and secondly 25 per cent. of the vaue of German exportas, as determinesd by the ]loparationa Commission, or all equivaleot amount as fixed and agreed on. Germany must also on demand,. provide material and labour for tte restoration of devastated areas.

article.heading: GERMAN PRESIDENCY.
article.snippet: The election of Marshal Von Hindenburg to the German Presidency will occasion a good deal of misgiving in Europe, and particularly in France,
article.articleText:
GERMAN PRESIDENCY. The election of Marshal Von RLin dsburg to the German Prelsidency will occasion a good deal of misgiving in Europe, and particularly In France, where every action of Germany is re garded with the gravest suspicion. It is hardly likely, of cource, that there will be any immediate change of Gcr. man Dolicy. Even the supporters of the now President, Jubilant as they must be, would not dare to take the jisk of provoking civil war. At the same time the victory of HiIndenburg, who is tihe figurehead of the Monarchists, is sug gestive of the growing strength of that element which would turn thle military defeat of the Great War Into a diplo matic success, or at least a draw with out penalties. There was a time when the aged marshal's name was one to conjure with., iHe was the Idol of a deluded people, but when the "im pregnable" imne which bore his name was broken, when the Australlans participated in the smashing blow that crumpled up his armies, ficktle fame deserted him. Since then he Ilas tasted the sorrows as well as the sweets of public eminence. A hero and a butt, a national saviour and a na

tional scapegoat, a great soldier to whom a war fired people paid bound less homage,. and a reputed failure bowed down beneath popular derision, all these vagaries Von Hindenburg has experienced: and now he has emerged from obsburity into triumph. He has becomen the leader of tile German na tion with. power to mould its progress to his will. Through all the conflict of opinion that filters through the calbles it is difficult to gauge with any degree of accuracy the trend of th'ought in Ger many. Tile statements the new PrCs dent has m'ale frops time to tintme have in them the elements of confu sion; but it seems reasonably certain that the nation as a whole is by no means irrevocably coninitted to' tile republican form of government. Nor is there .any sound ground for believing that .the nation Is prepared tio accept the consequences of the d~feat of her reckless bid for world power. It has been well sald thatthere is no sign of 'disarmament of the intellect in Ger many," and the Allied Military Mis sion has discovered disturbing signs of purposeful evasion of treaty obliga tions. The same spirit has been en countered in other directions. The schemes of successive governments to outwit theAllies and hscape financial burdens ruined tile countr.y's .cur rency'and shattered its credit. Sonme months ago we pointed out that * the trouble seems to be the persistence of tile Prusslan military caste, backed by the war profiteers and imperiallaistic intellectuals. German democracy is being trampled upon by thle wcr lords, and there is little prospect of real peace until the yoke of the Juinkers has been removed front their necks. There is dome consolation. in the knowledge that the Republican vote is still a force to be reckoned with in tile constituencieo. In tfact some of tihe election figures which have just been published suggest that there are more Republicans thaAl Monarchists. and whether their preference for Dr. Marx indicated a belief that the Replublican form of gpvernment was the ideal, or merely the best expedient for mollify ing publlec opinion in othler countries, tile result is much thle same. Von -in denburg cannot afford to isgnore that feeling entirely. The Reiclhstag,. too, is still committed to Republiceanisl. biut the new President has power to dce the Government and the public ser vice a pronounced Monarchist colour In any cas.e the realnt damange will coute from anxiety as to what Hindlenburg may do. There swill aleae's be a sus picion that whalever tee iintiy any or do to allay foreign fea.s will be nlere ly a prelude to stln le lore SPeiiou. plan. France in lierticular wilL le thrown back into that state of nel': ous agitateon frla whvich Biritisth ler ucasion and tle pr:lomirse of t?iE Di.:cs llin liae] ,]riwn her. For a time at h":ot Iiinielenburg will has:e .o altecr Ialv'? but to resplect tle pely. !to:h Is '?liii to ir?l?lar ollie cIIi in re .:i.i to tile reetiric: lti.n of frlo tlti?. , the iCle'rnan CGovernmeni his alreedy adopltedi. lie maiy Ie coltelt to pursui ithe liFttl tow'er i , , he.eel'fl coeitrrll ?e sn which the couitry liea hesitantly se.t feort, llt all thin time there still ibe fear that lsiouarchi.et truculence may lireak thIlrolugh tle thini crust of pDrtl lelsl and Dluntge Etrelllie once niore illto thli.t atmltsllelre of suspicion which is fitah to the reslornatlion of nonel: .on dit ices.

article.heading: [?] [?] GERMAN
article.snippet: The [?] Perfect Love," by St. [?] of [?] choir [?] arrival of [?]

comment.value: Ancestry.com BDM has Agnes Freda Freeman to John Frederick William Luckie

article.articleText:
WEDDING

LUCKIE—FREEMAN.

The singing of "O, Perfect Love," by St. Augustine's Church of England choir, heralded the arrival of Miss Ag- nes Freeman on Tuesday evening last for her marriage to Mr. John F. W. Luckie, of Booleroo, N.S.W., and form- erly of Inverell. The bride is the youngest daughter of Mrs. A. Free-

man, of Inverell, and the late Mr. A. de M. Freeman, and the bridegroom is the only son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Luckie, of Mendooran. Rev. E. H. Stammer officiated and Miss Patt pre- sided at the organ. A veil of Brussels lace, over a beau- tifully cut gown of silver tinsel satin, was worn by the bride, who looked radiant on entering the church, accompanied by her brother-in-law, Mr. E. Hargrave, who subsequently gave her away. The bride carried a bouquet of blue lillies and cornflowers, tied with silver streamers. Miss Mona Delbridge was bridesmaid

and wore a frock of blue embossed satin, which was made with chiffon shoulder drapes falling to the hemline. She wore a head-dress of blue tulle, with a coronet of cream roses, and carried a bouquet of cream roses tied with blue streamers. Mr. A. D. Freeman, brother of the bride, attended to the duties of best man. The church was beautifully decorated with roses and snapdragons, and was the artistic work of the brides many girl friends, who also attended to the decorations in the Masonic hall, where the reception was later held. Here the color scheme was carried out in blue and white, a large horse-shoe of white and silver predominating at the back or the bridal table, presenting a picturesque setting for the occasion. Large bowls of sweet-peas, roses, and

aquelegias graced the tables, whilst the beautifully-decorated two-decker cake held pride of place. About one hundred guests were re- ceived by Mrs. Freeman, who chose a lovely gown of black velvet with black toque, and carried a posy of Tal- isman roses. Mrs. E. Hargrave as- sisted, wearing a gown of blue georget- te. Harding's orchestra was in at- tendance and rendered numbers ap- propriate to the occasion, and later when the guests indulged in dancing. When leaving for the honeymoon, which is being spent motoring on the South Coast, the bride chose a smart tailored costume, with navy accessor- ies. The young couple, whose future home

will be at Booleroo, N.S.W., were the recipients of a beautiful array of gifts, which were displayed on tables in the hall, and received much favourable comment from the guests.

article.snippet: The London "Daily Herald," in a leading article, comments on a statement by a contributor to Field-Marshal Goering's newspaper, the National
article.articleText:
AUSTRALIANS AND WAR

German Opinion

The London "Daily Herald," in a leading article, comments on a state- ment by a contributor to Field-marshal Goering's newspaper, the "National Aeitung," that the British Empire

would not hold together in time of war, and that Australia would keep out of the firing line. The "Daily Herald" quotes the as- surance of the Australian Prime Min- ister. Mr. Menzies, (that "Australia will be there." "Such false judgments as those of the "National Zeitung" are made be- cause their originators do not realise that brothers and sisters need not make pacts to ensure that they belong to the same family," it adds.

article.heading: GERMAN CARS FOR GERMAN PRESTIGE

title.title: New Call and Bailey's Weekly (Perth, WA : 1934 - 1940)

article.snippet: Before an 80,000 cheering crowd of Britishers a German car won the Donington Grand Prix race again. Tazio Nuvolari, the 48 year-old
article.articleText:
GERMAN CARS FOR GERMAN PRESTIGE

Before an 80 000 cheering crowd of Britishers a German car won the Donington Grand Pr'x race again. Tazio Nuvolari, the 48 year-old Ital ian driver, was at the wheel of the winning car.

The wonderful speed spectacle of the German cars has spoiled the interest oi the public in other racing events in Brit ain, in which only British cars partici pate. Last year the Germans arrived, with their 200 m.p.h. cars and won the first four places in the Grand Prix race. Since then gates at British motor races have dropped alarmingly. The German Government spends from £50.000 to £100,000 annually on their cars. British manufacturers feel that they cannot afford to spend such huge amounts. Unless the British Government is pre pared to follow the example of the NaxI Government the visiting German cars will win every time. The German ears are not built for public ues, but solely for increasing German prestige. /

article.heading: GERMAN AMBITIONS. Czech-German Animosity.

title.title: Kyabram Free Press and Rodney and Deakin Shire Advocate (Vic. : 1894 - 1955)

article.snippet: The latter half of October 1937 was marked by a revival of bitter antiCzech propaganda in the German Press, The outbreak had as a
article.articleText:
: GERMAN AMBITIONS.

Czech-German Animosity.

(Contributed by the Longue of , ('■ ’ Nations Union).1

' The latter half of October 10-3« wna !

marked by a revival of bitter anti Czech propaganda In the German Press, The outbreak lmd ns a pre text a’clash with the Czech police and

members.of the Sudetan Doutch party nt Toplltz-Schonau, In Czechoslovakia. Knrl Frank, deputy leader of the party and others, came in^conflict-.wlth ..the ‘police, as^ they were making way for him and other leaders to get to their motor’cars after having addressed’a political meeting that had been for bidden by the police. The incident followed the arrest, a few weeks earl ier, of another prominent member of tho'party, Hans Rutha, on non political charges concerning public

moralB.

. The Sudeten . Doutch comprise the majority of the large Germun minority in Czechoslovakia. Unlike the mod erate - minority of Germans, in that country, the Sudeten Doutsch refuses to co'-operato with the Czech Govern ment. • They are Nazi in outlook, and favour the establishment of "MU tel Buropa” under the influence of the Tfhird Reich. As an outcome of the Teplitz-Schonau incident their leader Konrad Hcnlein, in a letter to Presi dent Bones, has demanded “autonomy" for" all Gormans living in Czechoslo vakia,

The German Press accused the Czech police of “serious excesses,’* de claring that “Sudetlc Germun patience is at an end. The ntmosphere is laden-with, thunder, and a single spark might' be ' suillclcnt to, turn this Incident into u^ftre of revolt." V''The National Zelturig of Bsson (Gen. GoerJng's paper) declared that the in cident was an Insult, to 70,000,000 Germans.

It turned again to accusing the

Czech government of conspiracy with Soviet Russia against Germany, de claring that dt was under Russian ■ patronage that the Czechs oxerclscd their ’barbarous" rule. The Czech Press, without regard to political party, strongly condemned the activ ities of the Sudctic Germans, and re fused to. publish Henloin's letter to President Benes, -and Herr Henleln’s paper, in which Ills letter appeared, was confiscated.

Meanwhile, Dr. Mastny, the Czech Ambassador, made an oRlcial protest in Berlin agaiinst the attitude of the German press, blit the German Foreign Minister rebuffed ’ the protest' as misplaced. \r • ‘

Tlie real significance of the out break lies deeper, and is part of a long-continued effort by Germany to get Czechoslovakia to break off treaty connection with Soviet Russia. Ger man press propaganda to this end has continuously alleged the presence in Czechoslovakia of Russian aviators and military officers, and the erection of Soviet military aerodromes on Czech territory, ns well as the build ing of a strategic railway which will link Czechoslovakia directly to Russia through Roumania.

Behind, this again lies the German dream ~of “Mlttel Buropa,” In which nil the German-speaking people of Central 13urope are to be united into one ’‘Grenter Germany,” which will

dominate Central and 'Eastern Europe: politically and economically. Ger many thus seeks a free hand In East ern Europe, and feels she might achieve it if she could discredit -Czechoslovakia In the eyes of the Western .lSuropean nations, particu larly England. It is significant, therefore, that opinion in England is already divided. Thcrp arc thosq who would defend the integrity of Czecho slovakia at all costs,. and those who would readily sacrifice the Czechs if they thought they could keep war from Western Europe.

At the- same lime, another move ment Is growing in Central Europe among the small nations who fear tlm they might be swallowed up by Ger many. Relations between Czecho slovakia, Austria and Hungary are more cordial than ever before, and might led to something like n defen sive alliance. Germany, on the other hand, is countering by economic pene tration of Yugo-Slavla, Bulgaria and

Roumania.

article.articleText:
G&tjnArr SUB SINKS GERMAN

CRAFT.

While the German armed merchant cruiser Bahlken was being taken into port niter capture, .by a British prise crew, it was attacked and torpedoed in the North Sea by a German sub marine. The whole , of the British crew escaped, the only victimB being four German seamen on board.

article.heading: GERMAN FILMS AND GERMAN JEWS
article.snippet: At the moment Germany is acting like a many-headed hydra. With one mouth she is crying peace; with another she is giving orders for general conscription. A third mouth is singing Te Dennis and Magnificats to Woden and Thor alternately with anathemas to the Jews, while the fourth is
article.articleText:
' GERMAN FILMS AND GERMAN JEWS

At the moment Germany is acting like a many-beaded hydra. With one mouth she is crying peace; with another she is giving orders for general conscription. A third pnouth is singing Te Denms and U&gnificatB to «Woden and Thor alternately with anathemae to the Jews, while the fourth is be moaning the fact that the Jews have been hurled out of the motlon picture - ininstry. There never .was such a babel. V. ?

Concerning Germany's military aspirations enough has been mitten for the present. All the -world knows she wants to possess anot^. ^rp^ llke that of W14. But her volt; face with regard to the Jew* wiwm she iitti ' harassed from the country momentarily relieves .the tension by its touch of piquant comedy. Herr Hitler has found that his policy of 'banning all Jewish film technicians and actors, among the best in Europe, has antagonised the big cinema circuits in other countries, thereby jeopardising the prin cipal markets which were formerly jOpen to German pictures: ' It .Is now reported that there is reason, to belilve that Dr. Goebbels has decreed tha.ti the German studios shall discontinue producing Nazi propaganda- films, and that Jewish artists, including directors,' and camera-men, shall be allowed to work in Germany again. ' ' But what of the noble Aryan stock— the proud Nordic JiiigoeB Atfho a few months ago spat on the shadow of a Jew and refuse^ to riib BhonldCffS with him? Will they climb .down from their pelf -made pedestals and con sent to work side by side with their former countrymen? Thp desire for gold and a flourishing picture industry has apparently overriden ! Dr. Goeb bels' horror cf Jews. He, as the chief German -mouthpiece, is trying to hush the anti-Semitic chanting of the 'Aryans. It appears (that whichever of the hydra heads can shout the loudest will have the final voice. Dr. Goebbels' plan, it seejms, provides £or the return to Ge«nany of only those Jews whose artistic talents or financial assets promise a revival in the German film trade — not of the great bulk of the Jews who were frightened out of the country. By these means he hopes to win back the favor of the big film renting houses in other countries. Including- Great Britain, which, if not all controlled by Jews, are of strong. Jewish sym pathies. - Surely Herr Gioebels is an optimist! i Before he can succeed in his scheme the Jewish pidture actors and artisans will have to make the choice between pride an£ profit— juBt as the Germans are doing at present — and profit will have to win in both cases. Doubtless, however, the great majority of Jewish motion picture people have already obtained lucrative positions outside Germany, an6 may not be in a hurry to throw up their jobs and return to the shaky, insecure pands of the Fatherland, whose history since medieval times is speckled with periodic pogroms. ,'tj | !'- ): | |V{IM i A few months ago the Aryans told the Jews they Were particular with whom they associated. Now, maybe, the Jews will answer, 'And so ftre we.'
