article.heading: GERMAN COURTESY.
article.snippet: A motorist who has [?] [?] from a holiday in Germany, was particularly impressed by the courtesy extended to him throughout his tour.
article.articleText:
GERMAN COURTESY.

J\ U1UIOITSL VVI1V JtA.SL

from a holiday in Germany, was par ticularly impressed by the courtesy extended to him throughout his tour. One thing which he noticed particu larly was the ready assistance forth coming from passers-by, particularly in larger towns and cities. On more than one occasion, he tells us, no sooner had he pulled up to take stock of his surroundings than a passer-by, notic ing the foreign registration of the car, came up to enquire whether he could be of any assistance to guide the traveller to his destination. German frontier authorities hand the visiting motorist a booklet giving full illu strated details of the German traffic signs and a list of the principal rules of the road, the latter being printed in German, French and English.

article.heading: GERMAN DEBTS.

title.title: Daily Commercial News and Shipping List (Sydney, NSW : 1891 - 1954)

article.snippet: When Germany, a month ago, placed an embargo upon the import of wool, amongst other raw materials, it was noted here that this situation had been arrived at as part of a German programme to bring pressure to bear upon her
article.articleText:
GERMAN DEBTS.

When Germany, a month ago, placed an embargo upon the import of wool, amongst other raw materials, it was noted here that this situation had been arrived at as part of a German programme to bring pressure to bear upon her debtors in regard to the payment of the debts owed by that country overseas.

For some two years now Germany has not been paying the interest upon her debts, whilst instalments of principal long ago ceased. A crisis has now been reached with the refusal of Germany, through the mouth of Dr. Schacht (president of the Reichsbank), to pay interest or any proportion of interest upon her debts, includ ing the Dawes and Young loans. This step amounts to repudiation. The requests, polite enough in all conscience, of the British and French Governments for further information on the situation, are declared by the Nazi organs to be. 'mere bluff' and the principal Nazi newspaper states that, should England take any active steps against Germany in regard to these debts, Germany would 'retaliate against the whole British Empire which sells considerably more to Germany than it buys from her'. 'Whilst it may be true that Germany buys more from the British Empire than that Empire buys from her, the thought might occur even to the Nazi intelligence that it is no benefit to sell to a country which does not pay. It is better to be without the business. . Ever since the AVar period, German national finance has been a stumbling block to Europe. After the inflation period the Dawes loan was floated, for the purpose of putting Germany upon her financial feet and restoring her currency. When the final reparation settlement was arrived at, the Young loan was floated to assist in that settlement. Germany had the money but reparations have been done away with. At every turn Germany has scored, and she proposed to crown her victories of the past by an open repudiation of her international obligations. It may or it may not be surprising that Nazi finance should in the end come down to the same level as the finance of the Bolshevists, to whom the Nazi spirit is alleged to be so opposed. The affair may prove to be a further lesson, and it may be hoped a lesson which will sink home, to those who for so long have argued that the reconstruction of world trade can only be, or chiefly be, accomplished by the financial reconstruction of Europe. Hun dreds of millions of pounds have been lent to the countries of Central Europe for reconstruction purposes, with the consequence that, with one exception (Czechoslovakia), they are all to-day as bankrupt as they ever were.

article.heading: GERMAN SHIPPING.

title.title: Daily Commercial News and Shipping List (Sydney, NSW : 1891 - 1954)

article.snippet: Herr Lindermann, chairman of the recent Meeting of Shareholders of Deutsche Lloyd, reviewing conditions during the
article.articleText:
GERMAN SHIPPING.

Herr Liiidermanii, chairman of the recent Meeting of Share holders of Deutsche Lloyd, re viewing conditions during the past year, pointed out that the Company had lost in 1933 no less than 2S, 000,000 Reichsmarks net

on exchange, and for the year 1934 would lose no less than 30,000,000 Reichsmarks. In other respects, however, the position of the Company had improved. It had been able to withdraw, with out further loss, from the finan cial entanglements of the J. Schroeder Bank, the Nordwolle (North German 'Wool Co.), and the Municipal Savings Bank. The subsidiary companies are all 'be- ing- placed on an entirely in dependent financial basis, with satisfactory results. He held out some hope of improvement in the comparatively near future, indi-, eating that, in his opinion, the world was thoroughly sick of the shipping subsidy business and nations were, beginning to recog nise the disasters which it pro duced. He believed that within a short time an International Conference would be held to con sider the same.

article.heading: GERMAN AFFAIRS.

title.title: Daily Commercial News and Shipping List (Sydney, NSW : 1891 - 1954)

article.snippet: On Sunday last a plebiscite was held in Germany, by which it was supposedly intended that the people of Germany should have an opportunity of expressing their opinion of the amalgamation of the two offices of President
article.articleText:
GERMAN AFFAIRS.

On Sunday last a plebiscite was held in Germany, by which it was supposedly intended that the people of Ger - many should Have an opportunity of expressing their opinion of the amalgamation of the two offices of President of the Republic and Chancellor in the person of Adolf Hitler, the Chancellor.

Previous to the plebiscite an intensive campaign had been under taken by microphone, through the press, by every sort of emotional excitement, to ensure that the result of the voting should be in the affirmative. Considering the circumstances of government in Germany to-day, there could never have been much doubt upon this point, because it is an acknowledged rule of Nazidom, expressed many times by Herren Hitler, Goering and Goebbels, that there can be no opposition, no other way of thinking in Germany to that which these gentlemen dictate. The result of the plebiscite was in the affirmative, and it has even been described as a victorious result. Upon examining the figures, however, it is quite clear that the Nazi Government is by no means as popular as might appear from the figures. About 10 per cent, of the population had the courage to vote 'No,' whilst almost as many again either spoilt their ballot papers or did not vote at all. It is to be assumed that those who spoilt their papers and did not vote were definitely opposed to the present regime but had not got the courage to say so. After all, the present circumstances of Germany are particularly unhappy. The country is on the verge of bankruptcy; the restric tions upon food, clothing and raw materials are reminiscent of war time measures: the Roman Catholic Church is deeply dissatisfied, and the Protestant Church not less so ; the great Industrialists view with horror the swing of Nazi economic doctrine towards Com munism ; even in the ranks of Hitlerdom there is certainly great unrest. Foreign observers in the country regard the situation internally with considerable apprehension. The events of June 30, when a number of Storm Troopers were shot out of hand, when General von Schleicher and his wife were assassinated, and an unknown number of persons disposed of, have left a very sour impression in Germany as to the future. The re ception accorded to the Chancellor, when he addressed the Reichstag a fortnight after those events, was cool in the extreme. The per sonal accounts of eye witnesses are now available in Australia, and confirm in every detail and strengthen the observations which were cabled to this country at that time. The position has been summed up as representing the end of Nazism as it has been in the past, and the beginning of its end altogether. The internal position in Germany is of the first importance, not only to Germany, but to the rest of the world, because, whatever happens in that country must seriously affect affairs in other parts of the world, particularly the present stage of economic recovery. This has been seen in Australia by the fall in the wool market, fol lowing upon the embargo laid by Germany upon the import of raw material. It is the continued uncertainty as to what will eventuate in that country which still dominates the wool market, and indeed, all other markets for raw materials. It is not until Germany becomes stabilised under one form of Government or another, and until what Shakespeare calls 'the alarums and excursions' in that country cease, and its unhappy people can settle down to internal peace and internal development, that the general situation can right itself.

article.heading: GERMAN PORTS.

title.title: Daily Commercial News and Shipping List (Sydney, NSW : 1891 - 1954)

article.snippet: The total amount of goods handled in German ports during 1935 was about 40 million tons, an increase of 1.78 million tons
article.articleText:
GERMAN PORTS.

The total amount of goods handled in German ports during 1935 was about 40 million tons, an increase of 1.78 million tons compared witli 1934 and 8.61 mil lion tons compared witli 1933. The total already exceeds that of 1930 and is eciual to 93.2 nor cent,.

of the 1929 figure. Goods pass ing between the ports and the in terior have increased by 11.6 per cent, and trade with foreign coun tries by 10.4 per cent., compared with 1934. Imports from abroad fell by 3.2 per cent. The increase in goods traffic in the North Sea ports only amounted to 1.4 per cent., compared with 16 per cent, in the Baltic ports. The latter 's share of the total, has risen from 24 per cent, to 32.5 per cent, dur ing the past year.

article.heading: GERMAN COURTSHIP.

title.title: Warialda Standard and Northern Districts' Advertiser (NSW : 1900 - 1954)

article.snippet: Courtship in Germany is a very business-like affair. All the love- making is done in public. Even a highly-born en traced couple walk
article.articleText:
GERMAN COURTSHIP.

Courtship in Germany is a very business-like affair. All the love- making is done in public. Even a hichlv-born en traced counle walk

about arm-in-arm or hand-in-hand. They embrace in public, he sits with his arm round her waist at dinner, and everyone encourages such ver- flowing evidences of affection. The German, however, who made love so madly before marriage allows his ardour to cool after a few years of wedded life are passed. Army officers are regarded as ideal husbands-for well-to-do girls, but the father-in-law generally has to pay the soldier's debts. A youth may be only a penniless lieutenant, with nothing to recommend him but his debts and his uniform; but, provided he comes of a good family, he can propose for any daughter, no matter how well-to- do or exalted a personage her father 'may be. Herr Papa pays the lieu tenant's debts and provides everything for the household. The girl is probably already pos sessed of some furniture and much household linen, as in many families these goods and chattels arc accumu lated for daughters from the day of their birth. They arc given as birth day and Christmas presents, as the chief object kept in view during a girl's earlier life is matrimony.

article.heading: German Defeat.
article.snippet: THE former Crown Prince Rupprecht of Bavaria, commander of the German sixth army on the Western Front, has recently published, in
article.articleText:
German Defeat.

THE former Crown Prince Rupprecht of Bavaria, commander of the German sixth army on the Western Front, has recently published, in some-

what condensed form, his wartime diary. Bupprecht was a competent soldier, not a merely decorative army chief like the Crown Prince of Prussia, writes a Berlin correspondent. He exercised actual command, and was re garded with respect by the real di rectors of German operations, the men In control of the General Staff, and the High Command. He also possessed an independence of judgment which enabled him to see the errors committed by his superiors and to sense the German military failure at a time when the highest military authorities were still deceiv ing the public with predictions of vic ton and a profitable peace. An article in the "Vossische Zeitung" notes and comments on some of the diary's more striking entries. It says: '"More than a year ahead I saw coming everything that did come/ he wrote on November 1, 1018, to his father, to whom during the war he had imparted his hopes and cares in a long series of very detailed letters. He recognised the causes of the break down—the declining strength of an overtaxed and decimated army, and the numerical superiority of the Allies, due to decisive American reinforce ments. In these frank letters-to his father there is no talk of a 'stab in the back.' "On the contrary. The bow was bent so far that it finally broke/ he wrote on September 30. 1918. Already, on June 1. 1918, when Ludendorff stlH hoped to break through the French front with his offensive, the Crown Prince advised peace in a report to Chancellor Hertling: Now we have trumps in our hand—later we -shall hare none.' "He was not deceived by the initial successes of the Boissons-Rheinvs of fensive in July, 1918: 'In the horn* Press these last few days the battle* near Rheims and Boiasons are pictured as great German successes, on the of fensive and on the defensive. I iind such deception of public opinion in excusable/ "On September 4 he saw thai only an immediate peace proposal could stave off the catastrophe. Re wrote: 'The general situation Is more critical than ever. The battalions of the regi ments coming out of battle often num ber between 40 and 4O? men. It is also to be feared that under some cir cumstances the enemy may succeed within a few days in breaking thepugh our front. An immediate peace pro posal—even with great sacrifices—is urgently required/ "On September 30 he saw that all was lost, although, as he stated out, 'every one who expresses hia opinion is regarded as a slacker and pessimist a weakling, and an inferior person/ He said: ~ • . " "What I have long feared has hap pened sooner than I expected—the de cisive defeat. In two days we have lost 800 guns, and the troops have no more power of resistance. They arc tired out. and no longer a match for the enemy's superior forces. AiscT things are going badly on the ether fronts, and we must be prepared for the very worst. It is urgently necessary to con clude peace at any price, for we are as good as defenceless/ " The Crown Prlace also criticises both the Weimar and fee Bismarckian con stitutions for giving too much power to Prussia. He says on this point: •*With all the North's services it cannot be denied that under its polit ical leaderahin Germany suffered the greatest political catastrophe in her history."

article.heading: GERMAN REFUGEES
article.snippet: The German freighter, Lahn, which arrived at Sydney to-day from Antwerp, brought 13 passengers. All were Jews, and they refused to state
article.articleText:
GERMAN REFUGEES

The German freighter, Lahn, which arrived at Sydney to-day from Antwerp, brought 13 passengers. All were Jews, and they refused to state their occupations or to say what they intended doing in Australia, fearing that their relatives in Ger many would be harmed.

article.heading: GERMAN COURTESY.
article.snippet: A motorist who has just returned from a holiday in Germany, was particularly impressed by the courtesy extended to him throughout his tour.
article.articleText:
GERMAN COURTESY.

A motorist who has just returned from a. holiday; in Germany, was particularly impressed by the courtesy extended to him throughout his tour. One thing which he noticed particularly was the ready assistance forthcoming from passers-by, particularly in larger towns and cities. On more than one occasion, he tells us, no sooner had he pulled up to take stock of his surroundings than ą passer-by, noticing the foreign registration of the can came up to enquire whether he couM be of any assistance to guide the traveller to his destination. German frontier authorities hand the visiting motorist, a booklet giving full illu-. strated details of the German traffic signs and a list of the principal rules of the road, the latter being printed in German, French and English.

article.heading: GERMAN BARTER.

title.title: The Wheatbelt Wheatsheaf and Dampier Advocate (Merredin, WA : 1930 - 1939)

article.snippet: The German barter system should have a solid check in the guarantees given to European countries by England and France. Direct barter of
article.articleText:
GERMAN BARTER.

The German barter system should have a solid check in the guarantees given to European countries by England and France. Direct barter of certain definite bulk lines needed for immediate consumption in the countries concerned in the interchange may prove practical* but the German policy is loaded against the buyer of ^ei'man goods. . • In many instances where payment y Germany has been by various lines, the quality, modernity and other features of the articles have been found sadly wanting and in South America and Eastern Europe, the sharp practices of German exporters have led'to the cancellation of the agreements. There u, however, a more serious factor for consideration. In most instances German purchases are of primary products. Having secured supplies of such goods the German authorities instead, of taking the goods into home consumption, have thrown them on to.certain markets points, evidently with the double object of breaking the market standard and at the same time securing forr eign credits. This has been done repeatedly with butter purchased from neighboring countries and then resold to their detriment. It could easily be the same with wool, and in this direction South African woolgrowers are becoming nervous as to the real merit of the agreement which gives Germany wool at a world price, and helps to destroy other purchasers trading power ,by the distribution of bartered manufactured goods in which the political aims of the Nazi authorities have

jnore consideration than the welfare • ^ concerned in production. The entry of Dictatorism into marketing, a natural sequence to Govern ment interference in trade and production, has had startling lessons. German manipulation of produce and other like markets has been disastrous, but how much heavy fluctuaitons in stocks and bonds have been due to premeditated war scares, will make a pretty story of gangsterism cn a national scale when the full hiscriminality against suppliers of goods tory of the last few years is revealed. A nation without character in its national transactions with other coun tries, a country whose currency has been manipulated to a last degree of j and whose history is a continuous one of broken faith, cannot be accepted without some solid proofs of return to honesty and good faith. Barter or dealings with Germany under present conditions is only playing with fire and invitation for a burning.

article.heading: GERMAN ELECTIONS.
article.snippet: Monday’s general election to the Reichstag has merely perpetuated the deadlock which existed in the late House, which was elected on July 31.
article.articleText:
GERMAN ELECTIONS.

Monday's general election to the Reichstag has merely perpetuated the deadlock which existed in the late House, which was elected on July 3:1. The Government of Captain von Fapen, which was appointed without reference to Parliamentary party sftrength by President von Hindenburg after the fall of Dr. Bruening early in the year, and which exercised a virtual dictatorship by authority of the President and the power of the Federal army, is still faced with a tremendous hostile majority. Though its supporters slightly increased theii strength it is computed, on the official

provisional returns of Monday's poll that it can muster only 74 votes against 507 in the new House of 581 members. In view of the continuance of the deadlock, which was generally expected, the von Papen Government will continue in power.

article.heading: GERMAN DEMOCRACY
article.snippet: ANYTHING like an intelligent criticism of the speech of Herr Hitler is impossible on a first reading, and without some
article.articleText:
GERMAN DEMOCRACY

ANYTHING like an'intelligent

criticism ; of the speech of Herr Hitler is impossible on a first reading, and without some guidance of opinion from those; who are more closely in touch with conditions. Just as a first thought, we are inclined to say that there is much fuss and fury, and very little of solid fact or real- ity. ' Throughout the speech we seem to hear the clashing of arms, but with a mediaeval flavour, as though some ancient chivalry under the stress of emotion were

banging swords and maces against shields for'the especial purpose of terrifying their enemies. But the initial remarks regarding German democracy sound (strangely in Australian ears. Herr Hitler be- gan by declaring that Germany has a democratic constitution,

which is responsible to the people through a single Deputy, elected by the votes of the people. This indi vidual is expected to. harmon- ise his actions with his conscience

to God, and his duty to the people

he serves. We think that no one

in this period of. experience will doubt the sincerity of Herr Hitler nor the reality of his belief in his mission. But that very sincerity makes him the more dangerous. Democracy as represented by the consolidation of full power of. Government in one man, with-an appointed bureaucracy to carry out his orders, does not seem to fit in with any ideas gathered either from the past or the pre- sent. And! a democrat who is an autocrat, and who while passion- ately declaring the futility of war, organises his people on a war basis, must be regarded as a men- ace. Perhaps Herr Hitler's de- finition^ German democracy may stimulate thoughtful people in other countries to consider whether, in practice, there is such a thing.

article.heading: GERMAN PROGRAMMES.
article.snippet: Official figures analysing the contents of the German programmes during the first quarter of 1934 have been published. The percentage of programme time devoted to
article.articleText:
GERMAN PROGRAMMES.

Official figures analysing the contents of the German programmes during the first quarter of 1934 have been published. The nercentace of nrotrramme time devoted to

music has increased to bO.7 per cent, com pared with 55.5 per cent during the same period of last year. The time occupied by talks, on the other hand, has fallen from 14 per cent in the first quarter of 1933 to 9 per cent for 1934. Political reports and news, etc., are practically the same at 10.8 per cent. The fact that the total num ber of broadcasting hours has increased from 12.000 during the first three months of 1933 to 14,500 during the same period of this year is owing to the greater activi ties of the German short-wave station. Only -2.9 per cent of the programme hours, was devoted to outside broadcasts.- Foreign countries contributed 0.1 per cent. r

article.heading: German Gluttons.
article.snippet: MUNICH, July 17.—Dr. Wirz, a Nazi health expert, said in the course of a speech here today that food gluttons in Germany were guilty of "high treason."
article.articleText:
German Gluttons.

MUNICH, July 17.-Dr. Wirz, a Nazi ¡ health expert, said in the course of a j speech here today that food gluttons in , Germany were guilty of "high treason." ,

Dr. Wirz said the consumption of meat ] had increased 400 per cent and the con- sumption of butter 100 per cent since 1933, and this was responsible for the existing shortage. Apart from health deterioration any German immoderately consuming meats and fats endangered the nutritive independence of the nation and thus attacked its political security. Therefore he was guilty of high trea-

son.

article.articleText: German Repayment A Basle message says that the Bank of International' Settlements an nounces that Germany has repaid £2,000,000 as the required five per cent. of her credit. The remaining £18,000,000 is renewed for three months.

article.heading: GERMAN MINES
article.snippet: GERMANY'S RUTHLESS and indiscriminate use of mines is plainly intended to frighten all shipping away from Britain. Since she has no friends to lose she has thrown
article.articleText: GERMAN MINES GERMANY'S RUTHLESS and in discriminate use of mines is plainly intended to frighten all ship ping away from Britain. Since she has no friends to lose she has thrown all the laws of warfare overboard and is prepared to sink the ships of any nation in a desperate attempt to blockade Britain as she herself is blockaded. It is a campaign of ter rorism that will serve only to hasten the alignment of nations in active opposition to Germany in this war. Apart from the way in which the mines are being used, the terrific explosive content of some of them is proof of Germany's hope of in timidating all shipping movement in English waters. The charges are far stronger than necessary merely to sink a ship. The vessels that strike them are blown almost to pieces, making heavy loss of civilian life in evitable. The sinking of the Japanese liner, Terekuni Maru, will cause great anger and perturbation in Japan, and may have a profound effect upon Japanese foreign policy at a time when Nippon's international rela tions are in a state of flux. It will be useless for Germany to blame Mr. Winston Churchill for the mining of this vessel. Surprisingly enough, the Nazis have now admitted that their mines have been responsible for the loss of the neutral vessels sunk dur ing the last few days. "Germany re grets it if the results are rather sad for neutrals, but can do nothing about it," said a broadcast from Hamburg. Perhaps she would not have been so frank had she known that within a few hours a crack Jap anese liner was to be sent to the bottom of the sea by her agency. Japan will consider this disaster in conjunction with the report that Germany has bought from Russia twenty submarines for operations in the Far East and the Indian Ocpan. The risk of total war being extended by Germany to these seas cannot be dismissed. So far as Britain is con cerned, it is extremely unlikely that the new German frightfulness will be successful in cutting her off from the world and starving her into submis sion. The mine menace was dealt with in the last war, and there is no reason to fear that this success will not be repeated.

article.snippet: Germany is clearly determined to perpetuate in her Re[?]chsmarine the best traditions of the former Imperial Navy (writes "Peterborough" in
article.articleText:
German Warships.

Germany is clearly determined to perpetuate in lier Relchsmarine the best traditions of the former Imper ial Navy (writes "Peterborough" in the London "Daily Telegrfljpli")

Her second pocket battleship, which was commissioned recently, is named after Admiral Scheer, who so ably commanded the Fleet at Jutland. The third ship of this type, now completing, bears the name of Admiral Graf von Spee, who went down with his nagship Scharnhorst, at the Falklands. The fourth unit, shortly to be laid down, is expected to commemorate Admir al von Hipper who won renown by his gallant leadership of the Ger man battle cruisers at Jutland.

article.heading: German Universities
article.snippet: Sir,— Would you permit me to make comment on Sir James Barrett's letter, which appeared in Saturday's magazine section under the heading "German
article.articleText:
German Universities

Sir, - Would you permit me to make comment on Sir James Barrett's letter, which appeared in Saturday's magazine section under the heading "German Uni- versities." The writer states that 2,000 non-Aryans and others have been dis- missed from'the German universities be- cause their outlook did not commend Itself to the German Government, and hopes this is due only to a passing emotional phase. To this I would like to add that not only the universities, but the Press, cinema, theatre, musical world, publishing houses, art world, schools, and professions -in short, all spheres which are able to influence human thought in a large way -have been relieved of the influence of people who were known to have used their positions to spread the communistic ideol- ogy by methods that were so ably exposed in a series of articles in your paper quite recently. This was done in order that Ger- man culture would be able to advance within the framework and in the direction laid down by Goethe, Schiller, Lessing, &c., whom Sir James Barrett mentions so wistfully. The German Government holds that a people's culture derives its direc- tion from its past, and can only develop in the direction laid down by that past; and that alien influences can only destroy

it.

- Yours, &c, F. A. BUETTNER.

South Yarra, June 26.

article.heading: German Figures

title.title: Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate (NSW : 1876 - 1954)

article.snippet: The figures for the so-called German election are surely astounding. Allowing for the possibility that the Nazi appeal caught the imagination of
article.articleText: German Figures The figures for the so-called Ger man election are surely astounding. Allowing for the possibility that the Nazi appeal caught the imagination of the German people to a much greater extent than on the occasion of the election for the Roichstag in March last, it is impossible to accept the suggestion contained in the figures that the people, forgetful of former divisions, have pooled their strength for the purpose of supporting Herr Hitler and his friends. The more rea sonable. view is that. though the appeal to unity sounded emotional depths to a greater extent than for merly, fear operated to prevent a true expression of opinion. For the Nazis are known In their own country as the upholders of force. and of any method to secure what they regard as the welfare of the State. Taking the referendum. the question was-"Do "you, German man, and you, German "woman, approve of the policy of your "Government? Are you ready to ye "cognise it as the expression of your "own views, and will you solemnly "pledge yourself to it?" The question is important in considering the figures, for only 2.055,000 voted in the nega tive compared with 43,464,000 in the affirmative. If the vote is a true reflex of opinion, the world is told that 7.000,000 Social Democrats and 4.000,000 Communists who were against the Nazis last March have been. converted by a brutal terrorism into enthusiastic admiration for the Nazi regime. The relatives and friends of thousands of men who have become outcasts. and thousands of others who have been thrown into concentration camps, are so grateful to the Government that they went en thuslastically to the polls to testify their opinions. It is certainly difficult to believe. However. Hitler has secur ed his triumph. Enthusiasm and fear combined to produce acceptable effects, and he may talk before the world as the leader of a united people lifted up by noble purposes.

German and Austrian doctors nre to he allowed to practise in New South Wales for the (Irst time for nearly 20 years. A ban which was placed on them carlyi in the war is to be lifted.

The Medical Practitioners' Act pro hibits German and Austrian subjects nnd nil persons who graduated from German and Austrian universities, from obtaining registration as medical prac titioners. British and German boys will probably scon be plnying it together in friendly rivalry.

article.heading: GERMAN CREDITS.
article.snippet: Sir,--Under date of 12237, writing from Hobart, Tasmania, and duly published in the "Daily Examiner," Mr. William Ager states.--
article.articleText:
GERMAN CREDITS.

Sir, — Under date of 12/2/37, writing from Hobart, Tasmania, and duly pub lished in the "Daily Examiner," Mr. William Ager states.— It is reported that Germany has a rlpht. nf £90(100 000 nf loan at short call.

mostly on England, and .which she states she is unable to pay. It is also- rumored that efforts are being made to make the United States receptive towards another loan to Ger many, such loan to be made jointly by British, French, and United States in terests. It must be clearly, understood that when a nation secures a loan from another nation no money is inter changed. Goods or materials are taken to the amount of the credits extended. : Since 1918 credits have been extend ed to Germany through the control re serve franking system in America and England, and Germany as a conse quence has become so completely or ganised in air, field and naval arma ments that she is able to ignore the League of Nations, defy the world and .hop over and win unopposed conquests, and the prevaricating, subtle, under mining diplomacy stills prevails to draw further goods and materials to the strorighold. Blatantly denying the responsibility for the last war, she may yet blame Britain for the next be cause the world is not willing to hand over mandated territories upon demand. It must be clearly , understood that the world is not dealing with German people, who are a very fine race. A gang of fiends who are organising world wide mass murder, hide behind all this vast camouflage and the German people are . hungry because their resources, energy and hundreds of millions Of pounds of their wealth are absorbed annually in the maintenance and fur ther development of the mighty war organisation. The bluff about being unable to pay has continued all too long. The people of the world in general, and Great Bri tain in particular, should rub their sleepy eyes and realise what is hap pening by the international money sys tem controlling and extending credits. When Great Britain needs armaments for defence, made necessary by such gigantic and, advanced preparations in Germany, she is told by the same inter national money monopoly that she must provide her defences from taxation. It is to be regretted that there is an absence of such writers on national and international affairs. In substantiation of Mr. Ager's con tribution, I quote a broadcast speeclFby Dr. Goddard on Sunday night, February 14, on international affairs from 2BL recorded in "The Book of Time." Per chance many listeners are aware that Dr. Goddard is an authority on inter national affairs. He said: Germany in her race for armaments is depriving every individual population of £160 of food yearly. -From time to time the cables flash across the world some startling arith metic, but unfortunately the country press only receives a brevis . account -in a condensed or mutilated 'form. Since

1914 to 1927 it has been my hobby to devote my leisure to national and in ternational affairs published monthly in the magazine "Life." Some newspaper writers, -of course, if only by force, of habit, reflect and exaggerate the mood ; of the moment, and they change with the mood. They are not so closely in touch with actual facts. .DISTRACTED GERMANY. Germany, to the hasty observer, might well seem to be on the point of bank ruptcy. In 1923 Sir Phillip Gibbs, thei noted war correspondent, visited . Ger- 1 many, and gave a graphic story of what: he saw there. He said, however, that with the mark at 5uo,000,000 to the Eng lish pound note there was still no out ward sign of poverty or rum in Ger many." He could not make head or cail of this wild melodrama of paper money which, fell .In value by tens:, of millions between the "soup and the xoffee of his midday meal. It seemed to make "no difference " tOtKe people. They still thronged the restaurants and cabarets and though .prices rose. auto matically as the exchange falls, thev .eemed to get enough of this f\ntastic currency to pay f 0 c. their pleasure as well as their necessity. "But," he added, "this is the way in which mod ern civilisation ' masks for a time the decay and the disease which are eating at its vitals like a spreading cancer." Even to the cool Australian mind looking across the sea at the distrac tions and tumult of what we call "Ger many," it seems .that.it offers a spec tacle of ruin such as Europe has not seen since the Forty Years' "Vvar. Yet the ruin is not brought on Germany by

the sword of its enemies, but by the insane policy of its own rulers. They were too proud to accept defeat, and have tried to evade; its just conse quences. The German currency has been deliberately ruined— and ruined on a scale unknown;.in history— as part of the plan to make the payment of the reparations for the wrongs done to the nations it attacked. We have but to contrast how Germany treated France in 1870. For six months' war she exacted a fine of £200,000,000 — and Alsace-Lorraine! And her troops were quartered on France -till this penalty was paid. .Or we have but to contrast the policy since defeat adopted by Austria with that of Germany to realise that Germany has. brought' upon itself the suffering which now almost theatens it with destruction. Austria accepted its defeat, and has honestly paid, as far as possible the price of defeat! As a result, it has the sympathy and help of Europe, and is back towards prosper ity. It is cruel, perhaps, to say that ' Germany has tried to cheat its creditors, but has it honestly tried' to pay them? THE DANCE OF THE GERMAN MARK. Only a mathematician accustomed to deal with what- may be called astrono mical magnitudes can keep touch with the performances of the German mark; but a record of its gyrations during, say, a single fortnight, may be attempt ed. The week before the issue of the Baldwin-Curzon note, the German mark was rated at 4,000,000 to the dollar, a'rid under the influence of the British letter

it went up a few points and reached 2.500,000 to the dollar. Then came the blast of Poincai-e's reply, with its twin document from Brussels, and the mark tumbled down with meteoric speed till it touched about 7,000,000;: and then 8,000,000 to the dollar. On.: September 5, 1923, it had gone almost completely out of sight, as it descended to 20,000,000 to the dollar, and continued its downward flight till it actually reached 44,000,000 to the dollar. The mark, it must be remembered, .before the Great War, was equal in I value to the British shilling; at the point reached it was equal to a forty- millionth part of a dollar, a value which only a microscope of the highest magni fying power could do so much as see. It was expected then to fall tc 100, LOU, 000 to the dollar", which is about zero, and at that stage "not only cities, towns and Villages, but State railways, banks, manufacturing co-operations, business houses and even . individuals have been printing and issuing their own flat money during tnc I shortage." Now, how can civilised existence continue under such con ditions? And since then the mark has fallen to yet lower depths!— I am, etc.,

PETER KNIGHT. -

article.heading: GERMAN SETTLERS.
article.snippet: Sir,—According to Press reports, German agriculturists desire to resume migration to Australia. It is said, a number of them possessed of capital
article.articleText:
GERMAN SETTLERS.

Sir,-According to Press reports, Ger- man agriculturists desire to resume migration to Australia. It is said, a number of them possessed of capital from one thousand to three thousand

pounds each, are ready to come, pro- vided Australia is willing to receive them. It is to be sincerely hoped that the Federal Government will not miss the opportunity of securing as many as possible ol those industrious people. For if we do not secure them, Canada or Argentina will gladly welcome them to their shores. Few people, I think, will deny that the German settlers of former years proved themselves second to none as pioneers of Australia. Their activities were not confined to one

crop, or one district. They spread

themselves throughout the land, and embiaced all branches of the agricul- tural industry. As citizens tliev were honest and law-abiding. Australia has everything to gain by welcoming that kind of migrant in thousands at all times. Because, In spite of all tariffs that may he given to our secondary Industrie.1! it will still remain for the primary industries to pull Australia out of the financial bog which she is

in to-day.

-I am, sir, &c.

1 W. BATES, ,

Olive-street, Nundah, February 2.

article.heading: GERMAN ARMY
article.snippet: The biggest manoeuvres held since the war, which Germany officially describes as "the turning point in the history of the German Army," are being carried
article.articleText:
GERMAN ARMY

The biggest manoeuvres held since the war, which Germany officially describes as "the turning point in the history of the German Army," are being carried out.

The manoeuvres at Luneburg and Hanover will include combined Army and Air Force exercises designed to stem and throw back an advancing enemy of double the strength of the army taking part. They are watched by Reichsleader Hitler and the Minister for Defence (General von Blomberg). imposition of the Versailles days, Ger many can show again a large Army equipped with weapons of modern "For the first time since the shameful i war," says the official statement.

article.heading: GERMAN HAND
article.snippet: KISCH SEES IT IN BAN BY FEDERAL GOVERNMENT
article.articleText:
GERMAN HAND

KISCH SEES IT IN BAN BY FEDERAL GOVERNMENT

ADELAIDE, Sunday. — Declaring he was convinced that the Hitler Government was responsible for the Federal Government's decision not to allow him to land here, Egon Kisch,

Czechoslovakian author and lecturer, who passed through the Outer Har bor in the Strathaird, said it was significant that Australia was now attempting to re -open trade channels with Germany. When the ship reaches Melbourne he intends to jtry, through the Con sul- General for Czechoslovakia, to have the ban removed. He said that unless this was done he intended to disclose In his future writing the treatment meted out to him by the Federal Government. He was not an agitator, but was a pacifist. BISHOP LENDS WEIGHT TO PROTEST MELBOURNE, Sunday.— The pro test against the exclusion from Aus tralia of Herr Kisch, the novelist, and the New Zealander, Mr. Griffin, dele gates to the All- Australian Congress of the Council against War and Fas cism, is supported by the Bishop of Goulburn, Rt. Rev. E. H. Burgmann. He has sent a statement to the Kisch reception committee. "I understand that these men were to speak at an anti-war meeting at Fort Melbourne," says the Bishop. "If this is the reason why permission was refused, It is an altogether inadequate one. deputation to minister The Minister for Defence, Mr. Parkhlll, told a deputation at the week-end that he would refer its protest against Herr Egon Erwin Klsch's exclusion to the Minister for the Interior, Mr. Paterson.

article.heading: GERMAN DEMANDS
article.snippet: HISTORIANS in years yet to come, when they will be in a position to look back, and make a fairly unbiassed review of the War, and
article.articleText:
GERMAN DEMANDS

HISTORIANS in years yet. to|

come, when they will be in a position to look back, and make a fair- ly unbiassed review of the War, and its consequences, may conclude that the Treaty of Versailles can rank with the Treaty of Vienna a century earlier, as indicating a total absence of under- standing. No doubt a great part of the muddle was due to the insistence of President Wilson that the adjust- ment of conditions must be delayed until his own special, fad was dealt with. Certainly that insistence was responsible for the hasty creation of the League of Nations, but since America at once repudiated the under- takings of her President, nothing was gained. The history of the world since has been a sad one. Some of the clauses of the Treaty of Versailles have been ignored, and the financial clauses of this and other treaties have been changed, and changed again, un- til they are unrecognisable. And now Germany is in a condition of practical revolt against the conditions of the Treaty limiting her right to arma- ments. For this spirit, we arc sorry to say, France has some responsibility. In spite of the fact that Germany has been left practically helpless for ag- gression, France refuses every sugges- tion for a substantial reduction of armaments. Perhaps this consistent refusal, and the examples of chauvin- ism, are more directed against Italy, but, in order to avoid complications, Germany is held up as the potential enemy. There has been much adverse comment as to the failure of Great Britain, through the League of Na- tions, or otherwise, to bring about a settlement. This criticism is not just. Great Britain has, during and since the War, pulled so many chestnuts out of the fire for others, all of whom were ungrateful, thal suggestions of further burning of fingers in the cause of al- truism are not welcomed. If France really reduced armaments, probably Germany would not make any demand for equality.

THE ZIMMERLEIN FAMILY of Kups (Germany) is now six strong. The quadruplets were born at the end of last year, and, as the picture shows, are in the best of health. The town in which they live is of 1700 inhabitants and lies between Kronach and Lichtenfels. The quadruplets have made it famous.

article.heading: GERMAN CREDIT
article.snippet: OWING to the total failure of all efforts to make arrangements with Germany for the payment of private debts, the Lancashire cotton
article.articleText:
GERMAN CREDIT

OWING to the total failure of all

efforts to make arrangements with Germany for the payment of pri- vate debts, the Lancashire cotton mill- ing companies have decided definitely that they will not expoit any more of their goods to that country. This means a serious interruption to an old established trade. But the manufac- turers are faced with a difficult posi- tion. Already there is a great deal of money owing for goods supplied, and the German Government has not only authorised but has practically com- pelled repudiation of the debts. It must be noted that this has nothing to do with the public debt, whether owed to Governments or to private in- dividuals or companies. It is purely a matter of private obligations incurred as between trading concerns. German merchants have bought, at prices fixed by mutual consent, quantities of cotton goods from manufacturers in Lanca- shire, who have paid for the raw ma- terial, the wages of the persons em- ployed, and other incidental charges Their customers are men with whom

they have had dealings for many years, j and there has not been any suggestion of doubt as to their ability and willing- ness to meet their obligations. Now these are set on one side, and it has not been possible even lo secure the pro- mise of an arrangement for future payment. In the circumstances there can be no other course than to refuse further business. But the position is extremely serious. Wholesale repudia- tion by a nation of its public and pri- vate monetary obligations tends to shake the whole foundation of inter- national credit.

article.heading: GERMAN GIRLS

title.title: Papuan Courier (Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea : 1917 - 1942)

article.snippet: Every German girl must in the future “serve the people” for a year. Hitherto only those engaged in certain occupations were liable for labor service. Now the
article.articleText:
GERMAN GIRLS

Every German girl must in the future "serve the people" for a year. Hitherto only those engaged in certain occupations were liable for labor service. Now the order is extended to all unmarried girls under the age of 25, which affects 300,000 to 400,000 annually, who may be employed in industry, agriculture or household work. The measure is due to labor shortage, which is also leading to the compulsory closing down of small shops and unprofitable factories.

article.heading: GERMAN SHEEP.
article.snippet: Germany’s flocks of sheep have been increased by a third in the past three years in the great drive for economic self-sufficiency.
article.articleText:
GERMAN SHEEP.

Germany's flocks of sheep have been increased by a third in the past three years in the great drive for economic self-sufficiency. An official census shows that Germany now has 4,400,000 sheep, which is 1,100,000 more than at the time of the 1932 census. The increase is due to the Government's efforts to free the country as much as possible from dependency upon imports, a goal, however, which experts doubt can be ever attained. How far Germany has progressed along the road to general self-sufficiency has been shown by recent official figures, which showed that the value of food imports had declined from 3,900,000,000 marks (£325,000,000) in 1929 to 1,100,000,000 marks (£91,700,- 1 000) in 1934. It is further announced that Germany's requirements of grain, flour, meat, potatoes and milk can be almost entirely provided by home production this year, while 87 per cent of the butter demand can also be riiet.

article.heading: GERMAN COLONIES.
article.snippet: LONDON, Sunday.—Mr. Avery, a former Secretary for Dominions, has expressed relief that the German former colonies had not been returned
article.articleText:
GERMAN COLONIES.

LONDON, Sunday.—Mr. Avery, a former Secretary for Dominions, has expressed relief that the German for- mer colonies had not been returned to that country, otherwise they would have been converted into naval and military bases for use against the Allies.

article.heading: GERMAN “INVASION’
article.snippet: The British Government has been asked by motor manufacturers for additional protection against the importation of German cars.
article.articleText:

article.heading: German Ruthlessness
article.snippet: The ruthlessness of Germany's machine of aggression has been shown to the world during the first days of the war. Hitler, whose sorry record of broken
article.articleText:
Gorman Ruthlessness

lnc ruthlcssness of Germany's nuicbinc' of aggression lias been shown to the world during the first days of tho war.

Hitler, whose sorry record of broken promises lias proved that-his word can not be trusted, recently promised not to bomb the civilian population during his criminal invasion of Poland. Yet,

unfortified Polish towns have been' bombed from the air, and defenceless civilians have been killed and maimed.

Tho wanton torpedo attack on tho Athcnin was another black chapter in the history of disgrace which Hitler is ■writing for Germany. In this case, an .unarmejl merchantman vyas sunk, al

though' no suggestion that it was carry ing troops or war maerial could have been made.

Many of . the passengers were neutral American tourists returning from Europe •to their homeland. The fact that the ship left England before a state of war existed between Britain and Germany will add to the horror with which the decent pcoplos of tho world will view the conduct of Nazi-ism. .

The slaughter of defenceless women and children and the sinking of un armed ships carrying nationals of a nculrul country are things which the

world will never condone.

The incidents have Bhown already the extent of ruthlessnoss to which Hitler is prepared to go. No doubt, British and Australian opinion will bo more than ever convinced that the in decencies of Hitlerism must be stainpod out, and the people will work with all possible courage and determination to win the war at all costs.

article.snippet: BERLIN, Dec. 8.—With reference to Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the House of Commons, the "Berliner Tageblatt" declares that the British Government is
article.articleText:
GERMAN COMMENT.

BERLIN, Dec. 8.— With reference to Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the House of Commons, - the 'Berliner Tageblatt' declares that the British Government is

laying the foundations of a strong and second post-war England. 'The first,' it says, 'was dominated by the Poincare in fluences, which are now ended. article.heading: GERMAN REARMAMENT
article.snippet: While it appears to overlook the provocation under which Germany laboured before she reached her recent decision to undertake
article.articleText:
GERMAN REARMAMENT While it appears to overlook the provocation under which Germany laboured before she reached her recent decision to undertake com aplete W'earnmament in defiauce of the provisions of the Versailles Treaty, the article written by the British Prime Minister, Mr. Ram say MacDonald, and published in the National Labour Party's maga zine, in Which he declares that Ger many has "broken up the rnad to peace' is entitled to be read with particular respect and attention be cause the .writer is and has heen for many years the world's foremost

pacificist, and he could only make such a declaration out of the bitterness of his heart, induced by the situation into which Germany's action has plunged Europe. Mr. .MacDonald Went on to say that Germany was the most secure nation in Europe until" she aroused sus picion by her own demands, in cluding an army which would be the greatest in Europe, an air force already equal to that of Bri tain and a navy equal to that of France and superior to the Italian navy. The Germans were asking too much when they expected acceptance of their objects and methods without fear and suspicion, in the face of ominous revelations of the ultimate intentions and spir:it animating them, and Germany's military expansion must inevitably force the sound and pacific prin ciple of general collective security into the dangerous form of military alliances. Coincidental with this pessimistic outburst from a statesman who is the very antithesis of a militarist or alarmist, interesting information has been published concerning the actual significance of the state ment made by the German Presi dent-Chancellor (Herr Hitler) to the British Foreign Secretary (Sir John Simon) during the Berlin conversa tions recently, that Germany had already achieved air parity with Britain. This was perhaps gener ally assumed to mean that the Ger man establishment of military air craft was equal to that maintained in the British Isles-a total of about 480 machines, but it is now statged on apparently relialle authority that' Germ?rny's strength in the air is equivalent to that of the British Empire, or a total of about 1020 first-line 'planes, thus placing Britain herself in an in feriority of more than two to oe. During the Great War Germany was the initiator and principal ex nonent of the policy of air fright fulness against the civilian popula tions of the countries of her enemies, and even after nearly twenty years there are still a sufficient number of Britons. particularly Londoners, alive, who well renimember the Ger man air raids, when bombls were dronpnd ruthlessly on the great metropolis, with no distinction be tween strictly military and ourely nonr-military obiectives, for the dis b.losuire of Germany's preient

superiority to produce an irrestist able demand for muc'h greater ac :eleratiou of Britain's aerial arman rnment than was provided for in the recently passed Estimates. The German demand for a navy ,:iuivalent to that of France, or approximately one-third the size of the British Navy, will also be very hard for Britain to accept, for in addition to the fact that as the whole of Germany's war-time naval strength was surrendered at the close of the war and then scuttled at Scapa Flow, thus ensuring that any new German navy will consist entirely of the most modern ships, whereas most of the units of the British Navy date from war or pre war years. Britain's naval craft are so distributed over the seven seas that the force sought by Ger many would approximately give her Iarity with Britain in the North Sea. As Germany has no colonies, and a comparatively short coast line, it is difficult to see that she has any legitimate claim to a navy as big as that of France with her extended coastline on two oceans and her somewhat spread-eagled African colonies. When Britain's sufferings at the hands of German aircraft and sub marines during the Great War are rmemembered, it will not be surpris ing, in view of these disquieting trends of German rearmament, if the Prime Minister's declaration about Germany having "broken the road to peace" meats with a re sponse from the British public which will materially stiffen Britain's attitude towards Europe's pressing security problem. Germany appears to have a strong case for a substan tial measure of rearmnament, but failing an early and authoritative secaling down of her present demands in that direction, she will have her-' self to blame if she finds practically her. Britain has been her best friend, and she is rapidly alienating British sympathy

article.heading: GERMAN DIPLOMACY
article.snippet: Sir,—In his letter on the causes of the Great War Mr. Jones has made many inaccurate statements. He said, for instance, that the Kaiser
article.articleText:
GERMAN DIPLOMACY

Sir, — In his letter on the causes of the Great War Mr. Jones has made many inaccurate statements. He said, for instance, that the Kaiser aban

doned the policy of Bismark, which stood for European concentration, friendly alliance, and prevention by diplomacy of alliances between other countries. On the contrary, ihe Bis markian policy was one of deliberate and ruthless conquest. His famous de claration was that the destinies of Germany were to be worked out not by notes and speeches, but by blood and iron. His three successful wars in six years earned for him the name of 'The Iron Chancellor.' Mr. Jones says that during the Spanish-American war, the Kaiser ap proached England with regard to op posing the United States, and that England stood by America. But Mr. Usher, in his book, asserts that the Spanish-American war was instigated by England in order to prevent Ger many from acquiring the Spanish colonies. Both statements may be wrong. Again, Mr. Jones says that during the Boer War, Germany made over tures to France and Russia, suggest ing combined action against England, but that they refused. According lo historians Russia and France were pre pared to intervene on behalf of the Boer Republic if Germany would join, but she refused to do so. In 1899 the London 'Daily Mail' was full of praise of Germany. The Kaiser was hailed as 'a ' friend in need, and a gallant gentleman whose word is bet ter than many another's bond.1', Mr. Jones refers to General Bern hardi's book as proof of Germany's guilt, A book, exactly parallel to General Bernhardi's, entitled 'L'Of-

fensive Contre Allemagne' has been written in France by Colonel Boucher. Another correspondent, Mr. Watson, mentioned the Agadir incident, m 1911 French and Spanish troops had all leir spheres marked out for them by ' the secret articles in the Anglo-French agreement. France took the lead in threatening war. Germany sent 'The Panther' to Agadir as a protest. Why Mr. Watson should see in the building of the Constantinople — Bagdad railway more evidence of ihe German qloven loof when the whole world is hunt ing for railway concessions is beyond my comprehension.— I am, sir, &c, Morningside. - F. MALETZ

article.articleText: GERMAN MANOEUVRES. METZ, July 6.-The German army's summer manoeuvres in the Siegfried Line region have begun. Artillery and machine gun fire can be heard throughout the day and the Saar Valley is being lit by search lights at night time. Hundreds of planes have been heard near border towns.

article.heading: GERMAN'S
article.snippet: LONDON, Thursday.—Evidence is accumulating that fear of a British landing in Europe is becoming a nightmare to some
article.articleText:
GERMAN'S

LONDON, Thursday.—Evidence is accumulating that fear of a British landing In Europe is be- coming a nightmare to some Ger- man staff officers, whose preoccu- pation is shown in story after story coming uncensored from neutral correspondents in Berlin, where it seems to be taken for granted that the visit of General Marshall to London concerns the completion of final details.

A despatch from the "Daily Mail" correspondent at Stockholm links the appearance of a Hitlerite peace tout in Sweden with the German success at Vichy as evidence of German mis- givings for the success of the Spring offensive against Russia, and stresses that those activities aim at securing Hitler's rear against a British crea- tion of a second front.

The peace envoy was a wealthy Cologne banker of Jewish extrac- tion.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: I WISH to support the protest against the use of German at a recent public Jewish function. The occasion was a concert
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

I WISH to support the protest

against the use of German ai

a recent public Jewish function. The occasion was a concert organis ed by Jewish youth in Melbourne on

Sunday night in aid of the Israeli appeal. I do hot think our young people — and particularly its more intellectual wing — ought to coun tenance any truck with the German tongue. They ought to be among the first to recognise that the Jew ish people desires no association with German ‘kultur’ in any of its man ifestations, and particularly should they recognise that use of the Ger man tongue is calculated to arouse associations that are . painful in the extreme. If there are people that use the language in private that is their business, but we want none of it in our organised official life. The time has come for a determined stand on this matter. I think it true t ' say that the feelings of the over whelming majority of Jews are out rageu by public Jewish use of Ger man. That seems to me one good test of where the. proper course of conduct lies here.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: I WOULD ask the Jewish Students’ Study Group not to feel that I have been severe with them in the matter to which I referred last
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

fWUULU ask the Jewish -Stud

ents’ Study Group not to feel

that I have been severe with them in the matter to which I referred last week and about which they have written their letter in this issue. I thought I had dealt with the ques tion quite moderately. I do not want to labour the point, but in view of the correspondence this week per haps another word or two may be permitted. The further arguments adduced do not throw any fresh light on this controversy. One can not altogether escape the feeling— I may be quite wrong about this— that the students are defending a position into which, willy-nilly, they have been forced. I want to say to them a‘s gently as I can that, outside a tiny minority, they will find no support for their views anywhere in the Jewish world. The logical arguments with which for the most part defenders of German must make do cut no ice. It is a fact which anybody may ascertain for himself that Jewish public opinion wanted no countenance with anything German, whether it be the culture, language, or anything else. Against that justifiable sentiment all the ar gument in the world will not avail.

article.heading: GERMAN.
article.snippet: PUBLIC discussion has arisen in Sydney over the production by Jewish groups of plays in the German language. This is a problem
article.articleText:
GERMAN.

rUbLdC discussion has arisen in

Sydney over the production by

Jewish groups of plays in the Ger man language. This is a problem hedged round with considerable diffi culty. The cultural problem posed for refugees- is undoubtedly a real on^, but I do not wish to conceal the _ fact that my sympathies are against such productions. There are intellectual and emotional issues in volved. I know it is possible to make out convincing arguments in favour of these productions. Some such ar guments moreover are not easy to answer.' But the emotional factors

are, in my opinion, more important

However “innocent” the German language is, there is something about its associations which manv Jews find they simply cannot stom ach. It is quite unnecessary for me to rehearse all the reasons for this inability and I realise very well that some former German Jews may take a different view. But however that may be I think it better in the long run to frown on German-language productions. Time may produce an other mood, but this is still onlv 1948.. \ 1

article.heading: GERMAN TALES IN GERMAN
article.snippet: THE enterprise of the Melbourne in publishing Press in publishing "Five German Tales," intended as "attractive reading matter for pupils who have studied the language for at least one year," is
article.articleText:
GERMAN TALES IN GERMAN

THE enterprise of the Melbourne University Press in publishing "Five German Tales," intended as "attractive reading matter for pupils ' who have studied the language for at least one year," is praiseworthy, especially in war-time. The tales chosen are "from among the most charming Marchen in German literature," but it is questionable whether they make a suitable text-book for the readers the editor has in mind. German fairy tales are full of obsolete words and archaic constructions that may be attractive for the educated German reader, but are difficult for even well-advanced students. Moreover, German style has changed greatly since the time of the Brothers Grimm. The stark vigour of Luther's prose, the Gallic rococo of the early eighteenth century, the classic solidity of Goethe and Schiller, and even post-war German, differs widely

enqugh to be almost a different language. The sentence of seven lines (page 78) is characteristic of the time of Schiller and Goethe, but no intermediate pupil in Germany to-day would be allowed to write in such a style, any more than a modern English child would be encouraged to write in the language of Johnston or Goldsmith. We think that text-books for beginners should make the student acquainted with the living rather than the dead language by interesting him in stories of contemporary life. In practice, too, it would be better if the help provided at the end of the book (notes, vocabulary, etc.) were spread through the book at the head of chapters or at the bottom of the page. Five German Tales. By Professor A. Lodewyckx. Melbourne University Press. Price 2/3.

article.heading: German Commander's Death GERMAN ADMISSION
article.snippet: London, Feb. 21.—After having stated yesterday that Stemmerman, commander of the German Eighth Army, had been awarded
article.articleText:
German Commander's Death

GERMAN ADMISSION

London, Feb. 21.— After having - stated yesterday that Stemmer man, commander of the German Eighth Army, had been awarded oak leaves to the Knight's Cross for- having broken out of the Red Army's trap at Kanev, Berlin radio admitted to-day that Stemmerman had died 'a heroic death' inside

the Russian ring. The radio said that Stemmer man's death was announced to pressmen by his successor.' Russian reports yesterday told how Stemmerman's body had been found lying alone in the snow.

article.heading: GERMAN BROADCAST. Anti-German Propaganda.
article.snippet: LONDON, August 28.—A voice, speaking in German, broke into broadcasts from a Deutschland sender station last night with anti-German
article.articleText:
GERMAN BROADCAST.

Anti-German Propaganda.

LONDON. August 2S — A voice, speaking in German, broke Into broad casts from a Deutscbland sender sta tion last night with anti-German pro paganda. The voice was heard to sav: 'Against Hitler stands the world's greatest Industrial power— America, the greatest sea power— Britain and the greatest land force— Russia How now, can Hitler hope to win. Hitler will bring nothing but sorrow to you. Destroy Hitler and make the end of this senseless war. Germany cannot sund a two front war. Tou were told Germany was immune from air raid ing, but enemy planes are over Ber lin. Rblneland factories have been transferred to Slovakia and Austria. There will be no peace for the Ger man people while Hitler is in power.'

article.snippet: London, March 30.—Germany is conducting an offensive against Jugoslavia by means of propaganda through French, Hungarian
article.articleText:
German Propaganda

'ANTI-GERMAN OUTRAGES'

London, March 30^— Germany is. conducting an offensive against Ju goslavia by means of propaganda through French, Hungarian, Bul garian, Italian and its own radios,

emphasising 'anti-German out-, rages' in Jugoslavia. The Lufthansa has cancelled its air services to Belgrade. . : The Berlin radio alleged that the j Croats were refusing to collaborate with the Serbs and that Serbian civil guards were trickling into Zagreb to attempt to force the popu lation to join the new movement. . The Croats, it was stated, were ? awaiting further events and show ing determined resistance to par ticipation in any adventurous policy | in Belgrade. I
