article.heading: GERMAN JEWS AND GERMAN CULTURE
article.snippet: The Jews are endowed with surprising spiritual gifts. There is one domain of their own, the province of religious and moral ethics
article.articleText:
GERMAN JEWS AND

GERMAN CULTURE

By ARNO WITTEN

The Jews ai’e endowed with sur prising spiritual gifts. There is one domain of their own, the pro vince of religious and moral ethics where the great deeds of this small people have shaped the human history of millenniums. The spreading of the idea of the one, spiritual and • invisible God, the creation of the Bible, the mo rals and teachings of Moses, Christ, Spinoza and Marx have in fluenced mankind more than the art of the Egyptians, the geogra phical explorings of the# Vikings, the laws of the Romans,’the war deeds of Alexander or of Ghengis

Khan.

Although a people that has formed the shape and idea of human life throughout the civili sed world has certainly fulfilled ■the task which history has laid • on it the Jews have over that pro •duced miracles also in the sphere • of general human culture. And .specially so in Germany, the coun try that to-day denies them every valuable quality of mind and soul.

Their contributions to art and .science are almost inconceivable. The more so if we consider that

they have been kept away from any collaboration with, and even from the admission to, almost any form of cultural life since , time

immemorial. No one would expect people who had been forced to live in open country and to whom the doors have suddenly been opened to rush into the building, to pull down immediately the old walls and to erect better ones. They must first find out their way in the new surroundings and to accomodate themselves. (It is •only a little more than a centi.ry •since the Jews have been permit ted to join the European life with equal rights—and that indeed only formally, not even practic ally—-and this permission has al ready been revoked again, It is instructive to remember that cruel fact. We sometimes forget it).

Besides that, there is another reason why all those achievements must be classified in the highest ranks of human successes. For also after their admission to the European dinner-table' they were not served the same dishes. as their fellow-beings. If the Jews made the most valuable • contribu tions to the welfare of the civi lised society it was not certain at all that the . contributions were appreciated as they infallibly would have been with their fellow scientists and fellow-artists. If the Jews received any. rewards of their endeavours at all then there was almost always connected with it some humiliatins. Although they may have been winners of the Nobel-prize or they may have gained the admiration of the whole civilised world,' as for in stance Einstein, who changed the human outlook on eternity, or Freud who opened new perspec tives of men’s cognition, they were not regarded as digniifed enough to become ordinary tea chers at the university.

But in spite of those handicaps, which proved only that anti-Jew ish feelings never had practically ceased to exist, the Jewish fight ers for the development of man kind gave the best of their hearts for the benefit of the human so ciety, imbued with the ardent de sire to further the progress of the human race. And it Is almost in credible how marvellously they succeeded in nearly every cultural province.

At first thought it may seem not worth the while to remember what the Jews have achieved in Germany and for Germany. In deed the wheels of history will not be turned into any other direction by the statement how much the Jews have added to the benefit of German name and German fame. But it will buttress the proud and the certain feeling of the Jews themselves that one day when the waves of hatred will have been . calmed down Jewish accomplishments will be recognis ed again and that the world will give the Jews that place, in the council of peoples for which they

. are entitled to claim.

When the Jews in the beginning of the 19th century were—ac least formally—admitted as equal to the community of free men in Germany, it was as if a bulwark had been broken down and the water dammed up behind it had fallen like a torrent into the open land. So powerful was the mental energy that became free and ru shed down into every district of spiritual activity. Impossible to count down every Jew who has added stones to the edifice of Ger man art and science. We can give only a few names out of thou sands. But we can appraise the real significance of that powerful, stream of spii’itual fructification only if we consider that the Jews comprising but 1 per cent of the German population at once took part in the building up of the cul tural life by contributors out numbering 10 or even 20 times their actual proportion of the po pulation. An example may make it clear how this miraculous fact turned out to be of almost in credible . effects: The Jews for in stance brought forth 9 remarkable composers in a little more than one century; the Germans, in or der to keep pace should have had to muster 900 (!) equivalent ta lents or take another example: About 25 per cent of the German Nobel-prize winners were Jews, equal to five .times more than their proportion. And so it/- was in nearly every district of cultural

life.

At the beginning of that “Pe- , riod of Enlightenment”, stands the venerable figure of the poor hunch backed office clerk and great philosopher Moses Mendelssohn, the friend of Lessing. He was still deep-rooted in Jewish feelings and it was but in his adult years that

he learnt to write German. Pro found was his influence on Ger man philosophy. (The fate of his children is significant; it shows how quickly by the way of assi milation large and valuable parts of Jewry have been absorbed by the German people: Two of his sons, baptized, became the found ers’ of one of most famous Euro pean Banks. His daughter, also baptised, was renowned for her literary salon and played an im portant part in the history of Ger man literature. His grandson Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, baptised, was one of the greatest German composers. And many of his des cendents are reputed as artists and scientists). Besides Mendel ssohn there were many more Jew ish philosophers as for instance Salomon Maimon, Otto Liebmann, Herman Cohen, Gustav ^ Simmel, Gustav Landauer etc. Although, they were not the great lonely stars they influenced largely thoughts and ideas in Germany.

In the discipline of Physics, Mathematics and Physics near to the province of Philosophy, scores of Jews excelled. The one Einstein would suffice to procure the Jews a place of honour in the history of Science. Only the coming cen turies can judge fully his import ance. But he seems to be a genius the like of whom mankind pro duces only every some centuries to be placed in line with men like Ptolemy, Galileo, Giordano Bruno and Newton. And there are many others whose names can keep the field also besides Einstein. Hertz (theory . of electric waves), J. Frank (theory of atoms), David sohn (electro motor), Marcus (petrol motor), Berliner (micro phone), Haber (nitrogen), Frank (Kali), Caro (dyes), Willstaetter (Chlorophyl), Bayer, the son of a Jewish mother and the founder of the' mighty German Dye concern (indigo) and practically thou sands of famous names more.

Jews have always been prepon derant physicians and that may partly explain the fact that there was nearly no inventive medical achievement without Jewish guid

ance or at least Jewish assistance.

It is almost impossible an under taking to enumerate the names of the countless medical pioneers and only a few ones may therefore be mentioned who acquired wide pub lic fame. So Meyerhof (transfor

mation of energy), Zunz (physio logy), Ehrlich (Salvarsan), Was sermann and Morgenroth (both diagnosis of syphilis, Freud (psychoanalysis), Adler (indivi dual psychology), Minkowsky (diabetes), Boas (stomach di seases), Zondeck (internal di seases), Asehheim (pregnancy diagnosis) etc.

, But how much soever all these contributions have added to the famous reputation of German cul ture the public in general knew and appreciated better the Jews, who worked in the sphere of the arts.

In the first line it was the Jew ish musicians who, even in the

land of music proper” attracted

the eyes or rather the ears of their contemporaries. There • are the composers Mendelssohn, Mey ei’beer, Offenbach, Moscheles, Ru binstein, Joachim, Mahler, Schoen berg, Korngold, there are the con ducted Walter, Klemperer, Klei ber, there are the countless prac titioning musicians' of world-wide fame like Schnabel, Horowitz, Ser kin, Hubermann, Kreisler, Morini, Tauber and scores of them more.

In the art of painting it was Liebermann, Israels, Lesser Ury, Chagall, Feinger, Marees (a half Jew) etc. who helped to develop German artistic reputation. That seems to be indeed a very surpris ing fact. For since the Jews, pre

(Continued on page 6)

GERMAN JEWS AND GERMAN CULTURE

(Continued from page 4)

vented by religious prohibitions, had never excelled in the field of painting it was all the more mir aculous that they could hold their own without any existing artistic

tradition.

Always have the Jews been bear ers of a deep inner conscience and masters of the word. Since the days of the Prophets they have been the proclaimed and propa gators of teachings, doctrines and convictions. That may be the ex planation of the immense part played by Jews in the German literature. The way leading from Heinrich Heine to Stephan Zweig is short in time but overcrowded by writing, composing, teaching and admonishing Jews: Boeme and Weininger, Wassermann and Werfel, Kaffka and Heimann, Schnitzler and Hofmannsthal, Bu ber and Mombert, Toller and Weissi, Brod and Arnold Zweig, Doeblin and Beer-Hoffmann are only a few names casually picked out of the innumerable spiritual Jews who have influenced the thoughts and feelings of the Ger man people.

It is practically impossible even if the limited space would not prohibit it—to mention every do

main where the Jews had a share in the shaping of German culture. Industry and economicsi, sociology and agriculture, film and theatre dance and architecture, journal istics and playwriting, charity and

art-donations were but a few ones of the vast provinces of Jewish

collaboration.

How is it possible that in spite of all this cultural work done by Jews the terrible outbursts of cruelty against the German Jews could happen ? Probably because the people did not know how great

the share of the Jews- in all those cultural achievements had been.

For however magnificent the Jewish accomplishments were they did not reach the bulk of the people. The ideas of the Jewish writers' were too elaborate, too high-brow, to be understood by the masses. They became the spi ritual food of the intelligentsia with the exception of Heine whose

poems are recited and sung by the whole of Germany, . but . mostly without any knowledge who wrote those deeply touching songs. And again the composers although some of thefn being pacemakers of new musical ways did not pene trate into the people’s hearts, be side Mendelssohn whose songs went straight to the people’s feel ings. And even men who achieved the most practical successes like Haber who saved Germany from losing the world war in its first year, or Ehrlich who released the world from one of its deadliest plagues, were not popular because the simple-minded maxi, could not conceive their complicated con structive work.

Shall we wonder about it? No, for not even the Jewish ^masses knew it. Even now after the last years of Jewish persecution and reawakening of Jewish conscious ness a French Jew with whom I conversed recently had no idea that Bergson and Andre Maurois

were Jews and Anatole France half of Jewish parentage.

Must we therefore assume that all the cultural work done by Jews has been in vain? Certainly not. Material values can be lost, money, houses, diamonds can be destroyed but spiritual values that have been produced remain.. Books which have been printed can be burnt but their contents cannot be burned. Heads can be cut off.but thoughts which they had spoken out, the songs which have been sung, cannot been drowned, smoth ered, hanged. The cultural achive ments the Jews have produced in Germany will be remain alive and there will be again a time of peace when all that Einstein and Freud, Mendelssohn and Heine have thought, said, written and sung, will again be heard, read and sung, and when again will be thought of with deep and kind feelings of thankfulness those men who have served the progress of man with the best of their lives.

But something more will come out again of the marvellous riches of Jewish spirit. Those riches which have survived the centuries

of prosecution will remain in the same way alive in spite df the new pains that have come down over Jewry. The men who have pro duced all those miracles of their spirits have had to go again on their new travels throughout the world. They had to leave behind them their fortunes, their money, even their clothes. But they have taken along with thentselves their unbroken spirit. That spirit wher ever the Jews will be driven out

and wherever they ‘ will settle afresh will fructify again mankind for the benefit of the human race and to the honour of the Jewish

name.

article.heading: Russo-German War GERMAN LOSSES
article.snippet: London, May 20.—The Moscow "Izvestia" states that the Wehr-macht, in the first three years of the Russo-German war lost 70,000
article.articleText:
Russo-German War

GERMAN LOSSES

London, May 20.—The Moscow "Izvestia" states that the Wehr- macht, in the first three years of the Russo-German war lost 70,000 tanks on the eastern front and an additional 10,000 before the end of the war. At the outbreak of the war the Red Army had fewer

tanks than the Wehrmacht, which then possessed 14,000, but the Rus- sian tank production increased eightfold. The Red Air Force during the first three years of war destroyed 60,000 Luftwaffe planes. Russian fighters during the whole of the war carried out 3,000,000 battle flights. The speed of the Russian fighters increased 150 per cent. dur- ing the war.

article.heading: GERMAN JEWS AND GERMAN CULTURE

article.articleText:
GERMAN JEWS AND

GERMAN CULTURE

rne Jews are endowed with sur

prising spiritual gifts. There is one domain of their own, the pro vince of religious and moral- otnics where the great deeds of this small people have shaped the diuihari history of millenniums. of the Egyptians, the geogra phical explorings of the Vikings, the laws of . the Romans, the war deeds of Alexander or of Ghengis Khan; , ,

And specially so in Germany, the coun try that to-day denies them every valuable quality of mind and soul.

are entitled to claim.

water dammed up behind it had fallen like a torrent into the open land. So powerful was the mental energy that became free and ru shed down into every district of spiritual activity. Impossible to count down every Jew who has

added stones to the edifice of Ger man art and science. We can give only a few names out of thou sands. But we can appraise the real significance of that powerful stream of spiritual fructification only if we consider that the Jews comprising but 1 per cent of the German population at once took part in the building up of the cul tural life by contributors out numbering 10 or even 20 times their actual proportion of the po pulation. An example may make it clear how this miraculous fact turned out to be of almost in credible effects: The Jews for in stance brought forth 9 remarkable composers in a little more than one century- the Germans, in or der to keep pace should have had to muster 900 ( ! ) equivalent ta lents or take another example: About 25 per cent of the German Nobel-prize winners . were Jews, equal to five times: more :than their* proportion.' ’And -' so : ,it ■ was in nearly every district of cultural

life.-.' ! v".

the beginning of that “Pe riod of Enlightenment” stands the

article.heading: GERMAN DOPE FOR GERMAN PEOPLE
article.snippet: LONDON, Monday: in a review of the war events for November, the German official spokesman handed out some dope for German consumption.
article.articleText:
GERMAN DOPE FOB GERMAN PEOPLE

LONDON, Monaay: in a review ui the war event* for . November, the German official spokesman handed out some dope for German consumption. He claimed that the. Russian claims of successes on the eastern front was exaggerated. He added that the Russians had failed to gain any stra tegic advantage and that they had failed at every point, go far all Rus sian attacks had been. smashed; Even the BBC did not T»Ueve the highly --nlnred Russian .renorts of rvictorles.

Time would tell whether the'Russlans lial been as successful as they^^jad announced. ' ? tHPV Referring to the other fronts, the spokesman said that Rommel had retired before numerically superior forces to prepared positions where he was now better off' so far as sup plies nnd communications were con cerned. In North Africa, the Axis Powers were prepared for any attack that the Allied forces might make. Germany was stronged today In Europe than ever, and better prepared, a fact which the Allied Powers were now fully aware of.

article.heading: GERMAN RELIGION.
article.snippet: I am submitting for you to read what Professor Ernst Bergman has set before us as the catechism. Read it carefully, and then place it alongside
article.articleText:
GERMAN R0JGIQN.

By "Philo."

I ' I am submitting for you to read

what Professor- Ernst Bergman -lias set "before us a£ the catechism. Read it carefully, and then place it alongside what we observe as our religion. I may add that a large section of the German church has refused to bow to this new "God," some going to gaol rather than do so. Here is the text of the German religion

1.—The German has. his own re ligion, which flows- like the living water of his own -^perception, .feeling and" thought, and is rooted .in his species.'.- We call it the German Re ligion, or. the religion of the German people, and understand thereby a Ger

man Faith caressing the peculiarity i and the integrity of the race.

2.—The German religion -is the lorm of faith appropriate to our age, which we Germans would have today if it had been granted tb us to have our native.German religion developed un disturbed fo the present time.

3.—TheGerman of-today requires a healthy and; natural religion which; makes him brave, pious and strong in the struggle Jor people and Father land; such a religion is the German religion. '

Comments-—What is a healthy and natiural religion? is a religion: without the phenomena of disease and degeneration. . To this Christianity does not belong. . Christianity is in deed an unhealthy and unnatural .re ligion. which is at an end. For. it arose 2,000 years ago among sick, ex hausted and despairing men, who h^d lost, their belief in life, "who had des pised .-the world, and who waited" for

the return of; Christ and the destruc- j

tion of . the world.

.4.—The German religion recognises no dogma, for it is a religion.'

5.—The German religion is not a re ligion of revelation in the Christian sense, " it rests rather upon a natural revelation ,of the Divine forces in the world and in the human mind.

6.—The German religion is the re ligion of the people. It has_nothing to do" with free througlit, atheist pro paganda and the ^disintegration (Zersetzung). of reigion. We. who are genuine .followers of German religion talce our stand on the basis of a posi tive religion.

Comments:—Where Christianity stops, there..our religion, begins. Be

lief in a personal God, in revelation , and salvation is all superstition, not religion. The biologically educated man , seeks the solution of his moral and religious problems in the Cosmos,

in nature,- and the world of reality, in . blood and soil, people and home, na- j

tion and Fatherland. Our religion is

no longer the International Christ-.j

God which could not - prevent Ver- 'j sailles. * Our religion isr"-what grows I living within us> the great, sacred, glowing desire to wash away 1,000 years of German sorrow, and make good the sins of the Jewish-Christian alien religion against the German soul.

7.—The German religion is riot hos tile to a church. It seeks a German church on the basis of a religious people.

8.—God is a moral idea to which we are bound by the eternal creative force of nature which works in the world and man. Belief in another-worldly God is not of Indo-Germanic, but of Semitic origin'. This-kind of God-be lief is not a condition of true religion and piety

9.—In the lap of " the divine, living world the knowing being or mind grows. Mind, is a natural growth of

the . world of reality. It is not a finished thing at the height of world

development.

10.—To God's being belong will, un derstanding (verstand) and personal ity. These are, however, unique in man. Hence man' is the place (Ort)

of God in the~ world.

- 11.—Man is not God. But he is God's birthplace. God exists and grows in man. If God does not come in man, He never comes. Hence the German religion is the religion of high

faith in man.

12.—The German religion recognises no dualism .or conflict- between body and soul, any more'than duality and conflict between God and the world, and God and man. We think of the being, body-soul, as a natural unity and entity.

Comments—"Crucify thy flesh," was the demand of the Esthetic Chris tian ethics of decadence, which over looked that at the same, time the mind was crucified. For in a sick and tor tured flesh" dwells a. sick or tor tured mtad.; -In tSe National Socialist State this dualistic Christian anthropo logy is completely'but''of .date. . Who ever seeks to weed the - inferior and cultivate tlie gifted and tlie best of our ~ inheritance, whoever seeks a social-aristocracy, can be no longer Christian;, For Christianity is the re ligious form of Social Democracy. Both are international, "democratic and be lieving- in human. equality.

13.—-The living world is the Womb Mother of the high ' human mind. Knowing, being, and mind is. the foirtb 'of the-All-Mother.' The Mother-child

thought is hence the right indication of the God-world secret. We speak in a modern nature religion of the" Mind-child" God, who rests iii the

womb of the All-Mother.

14.—The feelings of "union, holiness and blessedness are the basic religious "■feelings. "The .Christian feelings of sin, guilt, and repentance; are not re-: ligious feelings at all. They, are arti ficially engendered complexes in man.

15.—The ethics of the German re ligion "condemns all belief in inherited sin, as well as the- Jewish-Christian teaching of a fallen world and "man. Such a teaching is not only. non-Ger manic and non-German, it is immoral and non-religious. Whoever preaches this, menaces the morality of the people.

16.—Whoever forgives sin,- sanctions sin. The forgiving of sins under mines religious -ethics and destroys the morale of the people.

article.snippet: A traveller from Berlin, who arrived recently in Sweden, says that 75 per cent, of diplomats and higher Nazi officials in Berlin fear a
article.articleText:
GERMAN FEARS.

A traveller from Berlin, who ar rived recently in Sweden, says that ?75 per cent, of diplomats and high er Nazi officials in Berlin fear a Gorman collapse within two months.

The Gestapo; as units, will con tinue fighting, because they think they cannot expect pardon from the victors. Hitler's crew, he adds, will also have to defend themselves against the anti-Nazis, who will find the time opportune to settle- old scores. Germans fear that war .prisoners and foreign slave . labour will run amok between .the German collapse and the end of the last Nazi resist ance.

GERMAN FRIGHTFULNESS

?'LONDON }-A^AP.).— T&rpical Ger man -frightf ulness dominates the lat est news of recent activities in 'Crete: The Germans' pursuit of the King, of Greece is followed by precedents al ready notoriously familiar to the world, while the ruthless bombing -of

article.heading: TEACHING GERMAN
article.snippet: Sir,—I have read that educationists d[?] not support Professor Osborne's state[?] ment "that the study of French [?] schools was waste of time, and that Ger[?]
article.articleText:
TEACHING GERMAN

Sir,-I have read that educationists do not support Professor Osborne's state, ment "that the study of French li) schools was waste of time, and that German should be taught instead, because it was much more easily appreciated and consequently its literature was available to a greater number." It is good to find that there is a leaning away from Germany in the realm of education, in spite of the professor's contention. We appreciate good Germans and fine lateral ture, but the beastliness in Europe makes even the name of German something to

be pitied and condemned Yours, &c.

ONLOOKER.

Geelong.

article.heading: GERMAN RETREAT
article.snippet: Naples.—There are strong indications that hurried German retreat from Rome is extending far inland towards the
article.articleText: GERMAN RETREAT Naples.--There are strong irdications that hurried Ger man retreat from Rome is ex tending far inland towards the Apennines. Allied units have overrun broken-down German tanks with engines still warm, and ammunition lorries only half-unloaded-indicating that they were suddenly abandoned. R.A.F. article.heading: GERMAN BARBARISM
article.snippet: With rumors of peace feelers by the Germans being widely circulated in both hemispheres, and questions arising concerning the political future of Germany. It is timely that official revelations should have been made of the almost unbelievable barbarity
article.articleText:
GERMAN BARBARISM

With tumors of peace feelers by the Germans being widely circulated in both hemispheres, and questions arising concerning the political future of Germany, It is timely that official revela tions should have been made of the Blmost unbelievable barbarity that has been openly practised by the Germans In countries which their armies have overrun. Such disclosures will also serve to counter any misplaced pity that may be felt at the increasingly heavy bombing of Berlin, nerve-centre and core of the whole vile creation of Naddom.

The Polish authorities have already unearthed evidence J' abundance of the wholesale slaughter of civilians in that desolate country. Stories of trainloads of men, women and children setting out for 'murder centres,' there to be deliberately and ruthlessly machine-gunned or forced into lethal chambers and gassed, have been told repeatedly by escapees and others. Such stories are too persistent and factual to be doubted. They be token an attitude towards human life and suffering that Is alto gether foreign to British civilisation— a foul philosophy of sadism which appears to permeate the whole German nation. Now the special Russian committee which is Investigating Nail atrocities in the Donets Basin has brought to Ugbt a series of atrocities equally as appalling, and entirely In keeping wltn the German practice in occupied countries. The bodies of thou sands of civilians have been dug up from coal pits and quarries, where they were buried by the Germans, while no fewer than 25,000 Russians were found buried near the Stalino prisoner of war camp. Horrible stories of torture have also been told, and the Bnsslan committee has ascertained the names of 90 military officers and Gestapo officials who win be held responsible for these crUnes, Equally appalling are the revelations that have just been made by the Inter-AIIied Information Committee concerning the German treatment of women in occupied countries. Women nave been reduced to the level of slaves. The Gestapo never hesitates to use its -expert tortures in an effort to make women lncriminate their menfolk, states the report. Trilling offences are made an

excuse for Imprisonment and deportation, ana sms «« abducted—a systematic policy of the German authorities. Not only has the German nation for the second Ume this century plunged the world Into a terrible war, eosting millions ; of lives all told, but It is waging the ore sent fa^11?lthAt^^ar Yt ™ that outclasses even that, of the celebrated Hun, AttiU. It dlffl-olt not to sympathise with views being expressed by repre sentatives of occupied nations at their discussions in tonaon tbat Germany's position as a major economio power should be destroyed for all time. Whatever Is done In this direction, how ever, there must be no flagging In the re-olve of the Cnited Nations to bring to book all Germany's war criminals, against whom evl denoe ha, £en piling up, and try them at the scene of 'heir crimes,

letter from a German soldier, saw: 'Tills is the worst war that Germany has had to fight. It Ss a war to win or to perish against soldiers who fight with desperate obstinacy. The war in Russia, more than elsewhere, is one of horror.'

article.heading: German Rubaiyat
article.snippet: During the last war a London paper published a parody of old Omar under the title. "The Rubaiyat of a Disillusioned Hun." With
article.articleText:
German Rubaiyat

During the last War a London paper published a parody of old Omar under the title, 'The Rubai yat of a Disillusioned Hun.' with a few alterations it fits the present case: 'Wake! For our hosts have scat tered into flight The French and English in their

fancied might. So runs the message in the Berlin news, And German wireless must of course, be right! Come, fill the cup - with water from the spring, Water's a slendid drink on which to sing, The bread we've got will go a little way And butter is an overrated thing. Myself, when young did frequently invent But those responsible for Gobbels show Go even further than I ever went Sigh for kings of England (still to come) Ach! Give me park and let the glory go I wish our Navy were not quite so dumb The planes that we expected so much from Are earning the contempt of Christendom They spend their fury on a fish ing smack And sell their reputation for a bomb Each morn a "German victory" they say, Yes, but where led the fight of yesterday?

And the first Spring days that bring the promised "push" May blitzkreif Hitler and his hosts away

article.snippet: BERLIN, March 31.--The Russian licensed newspaper 'Deutsche Volkszeitung' reports that sufficient food is available in the
article.articleText:
GERMAN FOOD

BERLIN, March 31.— The Rus sian licensed newspaper 'Deutsche Volkszeitung' reports that suffi cient food is available in the Rus-

sian zone to ensure no shortages before the new crops are gathered. This result is "a triumph of organisation," it says. Praising the help the Russians have given the Germans, the newspaper in stances the recent distribution by the Red Army of 40,000 tons of seed potatoes in Branedcnberg Province, thus saving a out In rations.

article.articleText:
GERMAN GUNS.

? o ? German field guns or howitzers of the last war have been impressed by Eastern Command. m The guns must be forwarded to the Deputy Assistant Director of Ord

nance Stores, Liverpool, within tour teen days. Freight will be paid by the Army. Calibres of the guns required are: 77 millimetre, 4.2, 5.9, and all anti aircraft guns. A military spokesman said Monday last that the order did not indicate to what use the guns would be put. In New South Wales there are hun dreds of captured guns, which have stood for years in park and school grounds.

article.heading: GERMAN TYRANNY

title.title: Daily Telegraph and North Murchison and Pilbarra Gazette (WA : 1920 - 1947)

article.snippet: The Germans have given two excellent illustrations of their attitude towards other people, whether victim a[?]ies or enemies.
article.articleText:
GERMAN TYRANNY

The Germans have given two excel lent .us-rations of their attitude toward- cthe: -people, whether vie- thr.i" a: ies -»r enemies. . Goerin-- na said that whatever hap pens to other people, no German would go hungry.

Hitler has said that while the Ger mans were suffering hardships on the eastern front, it was right that people of other European countries should not be spared — should be impressed -is soldiers or sailors or factory workers. He oniitted Jhe distinction that Ger mans fight under their own leaders for their own benefit. For their vic tims, the War is being can prevent them from being satred . to avert vengeance from enemies who destroyed their homes and murdered their families, and to prevent their own countries again finding indepsn dence. German has allies or vassails who have hopes of sharing in the loot. But Czechs have been made to fight or wok for the murderers of their fathers or brothers, the Dutch for those who, at Rotterdam, killed 30,00- ' /iviiiana in «n» Hav the Norwegian".

for the Quislings who betrayed their country. With these aids, however unwilling, the enemy will seek to maintain h s : output of ships and planes on the same level as that of the free nations His one immense advantage is that it is not necessary for him to transport, materials and products over great dh tances. But though all German supplies arc obtained from within the European ling, they fall short of the huge quart titles that the manpower and resour ces of Britain, America and Asia make available, and the -enemy has now failed in his. effort to conquer Europe before American output reach es its peak. In America and Britain people have the same interest. There is no man or woman in the factories whose home | and family would not be lost if the Allied cauw should fail.

article.heading: GERMAN CHARACTER.
article.snippet: There seems no escape from the conclusion that the German is not a good dissembler nor a good mixer, writes Mr. W. J. Blyton in the
article.articleText:
GERMAN CHARACTER.

There seems no escupe from the conclusion that the German is not a good dissembler nor u good mixer, wrlteB Mr. W. J. Blytou in the Quar terly Review. He must flay. In a

Aud what is iu his naive mind is something so raw und simple that more: experienced, civilised, and man nerly races cannot helieve Buch sim plicity exists. The toil on our part Is superrogatory. He is -what ho ap pears and means what hie says. The fairy god-mother has given to some, at the cradle, - evory gift save oue, tbe gift of llyhtg with others on n basis of co-operative equality, with give and take, suspension of one's optimum and wishes in view of fur ther gain, and' the knowledge tbat half a loaf given Is safer than a whole loaf snatched. If character Is deBtiny, so is some hole or. flaw in character. That flaw mattered little In the older Germany, which was not cut off by itself from foreign educa tive influence, und which had not a 'programme of domination. Germun strength lies precisely in the realms of thought, peace, Industry, and do mestic order; its weakness in -world- adventures among Ideas, types. hiiU forces which are' subtler, older and stronger.. We can be calm about the ultimate end of the. transient Third. Reich/ which doos not consist of po litical adults and Is not led by psy chological adults; It has reached n cul-de-sac. and ho/ met various things harder than itself—harder, maturer, subtler.

article.heading: German stowaway
article.snippet: So Mr. Calwell is going to deport Heinz Heinrich. As a man who has fought the Germans, might I suggest that we debunk
article.articleText:
German stowaway

So Mr. Calwell is going to de port Heinz Heinrich. As a man who has fought the Germans, might I suggest that we debunk wartime propaganda about the low standard of the average Ger-

man. - They are no better or worse than the people of other countries. As far as Heinz Heinrich is con cerned, I do not think he should be kept out of Australia merely because of his manner of getting here. £The average Australian admires courage, and would most certain ly prefer this type of migrant to the type who is being assisted out, and then rushes home without giving the country a fair go. If Heinrich is of good charac ter, then he . should at least be given an onportunitv to nrove

himself. -Arthur Henderson, St. Leonards.

GERMAN ATROCITIES

!Sm'Tl endorse the remarks of' Sir James Barrett (7/10/43). I I woulci also point ovit that thei Rt, Rev. R. w. Maca nicy's desig nation of "some Brent power whol will occupy Belgium, Holland and Norway" requires some definition.! It has been proved beyond doubt i ha t our ally Russia cannot be j

article.heading: GERMAN LEAFLETS

title.title: Papuan Courier (Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea : 1917 - 1942)

article.snippet: Leaflets, signed by General von Folkenhorst, the German General commanding in Norway, and dropped on Norwegian villages near the Swedish
article.articleText:
GERMAN LEAFLETS

Leaflets, signed by. General von Folkenliorst, the German General commanding in Norway, and dropped on Norwegian villages near the Swedish frontier, announce: "The German troops intend to defend Norway against the Western Powers. The Norwegian Government has refused to co operate. Therefore the Norwegian people must decide their own fate." And in order to assist the Norwegian people in coming to a decision adds the sinister warning:— "Every resistance will be met with the most ruthless measures. War tribunals will be.set up, and anyone found with arms will be immediately shot, Nothing will happen to those who are quiet."

article.heading: GERMAN ADMISSION
article.snippet: BY sealing off Cherbourg from the French mainland, the Allies had achieved a success which must not be
article.articleText:
GERMAN ADMISSION

"DY sealing off Cherbourg from the French mainland, the Allies had achieved a success which must not be belittled, admitted the German Overseas News Agency yesterday. The BBC said the comment was apparently made in an effort to prepare the Germans for the fall of Cherbourg.

The High Altar of St. Pauls Cathedral laid low by a German bomb. Of all the sacrilege German airmen have wroughton London, this is perhaps the worst for St. Paul's it one of the inspiring edifices man has raised to bis Creator on land that has for centuries been holy.

article.heading: GERMAN MORALE
article.snippet: One of the most encouraging developments of recent weeks has been the increasing reference to the decline in German morale. This is
article.articleText:
GERMAN MORALE

One of the most encouraging developments of recent weeks has been tne increasing reference to the decline in (iern.au morale. This is not the result of wishful thinking, or even inspired comment from neutral sources who might imagine that we are anxious to hear that German morale was declining. It comes from such authoritative a source as Dr. Josef Goebells himself. Dr. Goebells does not, of course, refer to it in so many words, but he does refer rather significantly to ' temporary weakness," and he reiterates with monotonous regularity the fact that 1918 "was a unique and tragic event in our history which will not, and cannot, be repeated." It will be remembered "-iuuuuuicu that mat in his nis ast Herr Hitler adopted the same lone, and very obviously the lears of 1918 are looming very large on the German canvas. As a matter of fact, the differences between the present time and 1918 are not so very marked. At this stage of the last war, both Turkey and Bulgaria had been forced out rather in the same way as Italy has been forced out this time. The crippling defeats which the German army is suffering on the eastern front were being emulated on the western front of the last war. And to this similarity must be added the increasing cost

of the U-boat campaign, which is, , lor all practical purposes, as great a failure loday as it was at the beginning, of 1918. But there is another and very important difference in the situation—tiie first, which favours the United Nations, is the fact that Germany is being iiit far harder from the air than was possible during the last war. The second, winch is in favour of Germany is the fact that the Nazis have a much more stringent and brutal dis- * lpunc of the civilian population than did the Kaiser's Government of Lie last war. Consequently, u would be foolish to anticipate au iitinn diate earl j collapse of the Cer mans, although this is by no means impossible. It must not, however, be expected. At the same time it looks very much as though the German leaders themselves are not too hopeful. This constant reiteration of PJLS is an indication of how much it is preying on their minds. No doubt, before the end, Ihe German people will de cide whether they prefer certain death from the air—or their men folks on the lighting fronts of Europe—or whether they prefer to risk death lighting their greatest enemy, ihe Nazi leaders themselves. Very obviously the position inside ! Germany is deteriorating very sub stajilially, and the task ahead o 1 the United Nations now is to see that lull advantage is taken of this declining morale, and that the offensive strength of the Allies is used Lo tile utmost lo smash down Lerinan tyranny, The fighting in Italy and in Russia is prov ing a tremendous dilliculty tor the Germans. The Party .> own activity m Yugoslavia is anothcr very important factor in Um whole campaign, and if, as PeioTa: Smuts predicts, the main aii-om

aiiack win be launched a! :1k- beginning of next year, it looks Ver\ much as iliougii Germany will b, unable !o survive for very long Ihe main ihing is that we should not become complacent, and that every ell oil should be maintained to keep up the How of supplies to enable that ceaseless battering to be maintained. The Kellerberrin sub-branch : the ILS.L. is desirous of ascertain!lithe names of men who enlisted from Baandee. Doodhikine. Kellerberrin and Tammin districts, and who are now prisoners of war in either Germany or Italy. Full particulars (regimental number, etc.) will be gladly received by either Mr. T. O. Chambers Kellerberrin or the branch secretary (Mr. A. Ross. Doodlakine). v v v v Al the Parent's A Citizen's Association's euchre party on Tuesda\ evening Messrs Percy Beynohls and Syd Johnson tied for the gent'.-, prize and Mrs. Fleming won the ladies'.

article.snippet: There was continuous fighting near Elverum, where the German planes machine-gunned an assembly of unarmed Norwegian soldiers. this

article.articleText:
GERMAN MORALE.

Allied officers said that Germans captured in recent; battles are cocky and so "hopped up with Nazi propa ganda" that it is unlikely they ever

will crack. There absolutely is no weakening of German morale," one

officer said. — U.S. United Press Lon don correspondent.

article.heading: German Retreat.
article.snippet: Though the Russian victories have frustrated a German victory, they have not yet insured a German defeat. In fact, the German retreat, which started
article.articleText:
l!lllllllllllllllll!IIIIIIIIIIIIilllliillIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIilllllllltlllllllllllllll|lllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllll!l German Retreat.

Though the Russian victories have frustrated a German victory, they have not yet insured a German defeat. In fact, the German retreat, which started

much earlier than Napoleon's, has ap parently saved .their armies intact. They still seem prepared to put up a strong defence at their chosen line. They have been working on their "East Wall" for years. Their occupa tion of Bulgaria, coupled. with increas ing terror, not only in the conquered lands, but also at home, is further evi dence of their - determination to con tinue to fight. In that light, the re treat in Russia is, indeed, part of the new German strategy, which the Ger mans now admit has been dictated, in part at least, by the collapse of Italy, and which compels them to mass forces against the Allies in the. west. —

N.Y. "Times."

article.heading: GERMAN GOVERNMENT
article.snippet: With the formation of Dr. Adenauer's right-wing coalition Government, the West German Federal Republic has
article.articleText: GERMAN GOVERNMENT With the formation of Dr. Adenauer's right-wing coali tion Government, the West Gernman Federal Republic has now been launched and the Occupation Statute, which de fines the rights of the western Allied Powers pending the con clusion of a peace treaty, has simultaneously come into force. The new republic, founded on the democratic parliamentary principles of the Bonn Consti tution, is not yet a fully sove reign State, for it is subject to discretionary Allied control. Nor is the structure of the Re public complete, for it has not been possible to include the Russian zone. But, within those limits, a self-governing Ger?jp State has been brought into being by the Western Powers. It is a fateful experiment. The willingness and capacity of the German people to make a re presentative parliamentary sys tem work, which has already failed once in the destruction of the Weimar Republic by Hitler's Nazism, is again being put to the test in a very difficult post war stage. The outcome, politically and economically, will have a profound influence on the future of Europe and the task of Dr. Adenauer as the first Chancellor, is one of the gravest responsibility. The return of germany to a proper place in the European and world community has been facilitated by the Western Powers. But there will be need for sound evidence of German attachment to peaceable demo cratic practice and of a genu inely cooperative spirit to justify the next step, which would presumably be admis sion to the Council of Europe. The greatest danger, as always in German politics, must come from the lack of any ingrained parliamentary tradition and the struggle of extremists on the right and the left to overthrow the moderate democrats and seize authoritarian power. A stabilising factor, however, is that the two major parties-the Christian Democrats in office and the Social Democrats in opposition-stand firmly for constitutional and democratic principles. The Christian Democrats, although the larg est party in the Federal Lower House, have only 139 seats out of 402. Under Dr. Aden auer's leadership they de clined to seek a Government with the Social Democrats (131 seats) because of deep divisions on economic policy. Dr. Aden auer therefore looked to the smaller parties on his right and he has formed a coalition with the conservative . Free Democrats and the strongly nationalist German Party. It is a coalition, however, which has an extremely narrow ma jority. Dr. Adenauer's pro blem, in which the Western Powers have an acute and ap prehensive interest, will be to resist dictation from the right and to hold in check the re vival of nationalism which was so strongly marked in the elec tion.

article.heading: GERMAN ELECTION
article.snippet: LONDON, September 16.—In the German local elections Hamburg Independents topped the poll in the British stone with 947,751 votes
article.articleText:
GERMAN ELECTION

LONDON, September 16.-In the German local elections Hamburg Independents topped the poll in the British stone with 947,751 votes followed by Social Democrats 470, 962, Christian Democrats 378,134, Centre" Party 41,061, Free Demo-

crats 40,366, and Communists 16,018.

Social Democrats are leading in the American zone and Christian Democrats in the French.zone, in each of which Communists polled

the least votes.

The following were the final re- sults in the Russian zone: Social- ist Unity 820,600 Christian Demo- crats 359,038, Democrats 238,387.

article.heading: GERMAN REPARATIONS
article.snippet: LONDON, Sunday.—Many questions are being asked in London as to the precise meaning of the reparation proposals, says the "Times" diplomatic correspondent.
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPARATIONS

LONDON, Sunday.-Many questions arc being asked in Loudon as to the precise -meaning of the reparation proposals, says

tho "Times" diplomatic correspondent. Allied experts in assessing tho amount of equipment to bo removed have to decide , ?what is German peace economy and what

is thc average European standard.

It seems that German economy and in- dustrial production will bo reduced below thc 1927-29 level. When tho intensive in- dustrial development during Hitler's four year plan is recalled, and the no less in- tensive drive during thc war, it is seen that a considerable part of thc existing equipment will be removed.

Tho Soviet authorities arc anxious to rebuild from thc eastern zone.

Gorman industry will not be completely

shipped, and the German« will be left with enough lo work their way forward in peace.

article.heading: GERMAN MUGS !
article.snippet: Driver Watts, well known in Mordialloc and Mentone, who is a prisoner of war in Germany, in a letter to his people, requested them to tell his
article.articleText: GERMAN MUGSI Driver Watts, well. known in Mor dialloc and Mentone, w-ho is a priso ner of war in Germany, in a letter to - his ,people, requested them to tell his brother, who is also in the army, that "we can give these mugs ten on and beat them." The joke about it is that his letter, written from Salzberg, was, of course, censored by the German au thorities, evidently not well versed in Australian coloquialism; they prob ably thought he was talking about beer mugs. Well, what mugs! In his letter Driver Watts mentions having met a chap named Solomon, also a prisoner of war, who formerly worked for Bert Priqe.

article.articleText: GERMAN ATROCITIES LONDON (A.A.P.).-Reuters corres pondent in Moscow says the Soviet Government has released a new report on German and Rumanian atrocities, alleging that more than "5,000 men, women and children were burnt aliie luring the occupation of Odessa. The victims, it is stated,, were herded into huge warehouses, over which oil was pumped and. set on. fire.

There . was more fierce fighting yesterday ? in the Vistula bridgehead west of Aranov. Massed Soviet forces at tacked between the Bug and the Narew, but break-through attempts were foiled.'

London, June 26. — A terrific ex plosion shook Cherbourg yesterday afternoon, indicating that the Ger mans had begun the demolition of the harbour facilities. The ex plosion covered an area of several blocks and unquestionably did ex tensive damage. tVia d- p v m n. n nnriprernnnri

article.articleText:
German Report

London, June 22. — A Berlin com munique states: 'We smashed enemy attacks against our encircle ment ring east of the Orne River. The enemy groped his way forward with strong reconnaissance forces

against the land iront. of the fort ress of Cherbourg but was re pelled.' London, June 22.— The German Newsagency says that, the Ameri can attempts .from the south and south-east to ., penetrate Cher .bourg's outer defences yesterday were thrown back with . heavy losses. ?

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: London, Jan. 23.—A Berlin communique states:—"Russian resistance has increased south of Budapest. The enemy again
article.articleText:
German Report

London, Jan. 23. — A Berlin com munique states: — 'Russian resist ance has increased south of Buda pest. The enemy again unsuccess fully attacked in Budapest. We held our positions in Upper Silesia

on the north-eastern fringes of the industrial area against numerous attacks, which made some new breaches. We held the '? Russians east of Oppeln and between Ams lau and Ols. The Germans pre vented a Russian break-through in the streets of Insterburg and be fore the Gel River. Fierce fighting continues.' London, Jan. 23. — The German Newsagency's commentator, Von Hammer, reporting the Russian advances, said that a Russian re connaissance detachment had ad vanced into the area east of Posen, but was being held. Attacks in the south against Torun had been re-. pelled. A new tank battle had flared up south-west of Lodz and the Germans were engaged in' Uegivy defensive fisUting at* Kalisz.

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: London, June 5.-A Berlin communique states:-"British counter-attacks in North Africa have been repulsed. "We captured an order of the 4th
article.articleText:
German Report

London, .June 5.— A Berlin communi que, states:— 'British counter-attacks in North Africa have been repulsed. 'We captured an order of the 4th British Tank Brigade stating that prisoners . must not be allowed food, water or sleep, or receive facilities or concessions of any kind, unless they have been interrogated by the appro priate authorities. The German High Command therefore orders that from

noon to-morrow British troops taken prisoner in the course of the present battle are not to receive food or drink until this despicable and inhuman order is revoked, and the revocation brought officially to the notice of the German High Command. 'The Luftwaffe last night bombed harbour works at Sunderland.'

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: mand reports:—"Our planes during armed reconnaissances over England attacked armament factories, fuel depots, railway works,
article.articleText:
German Report

mand reports : — 'Our 'planes dur ing armed reconnaissances over England attacked armament fac toriesi fuel depots, railway works, aerodromes and troop camps, especially in Sussex, Norfolk and

made on aerodromes in Southern England, and harbour works and large tank depots on the south and south-west coasts of England. 'Enemy 'planes last night bombed residential quarters of various towns, several civilians being killed or injured and a number of houses destroyed. Five enemy 'planes were shot down. Two of ours are miss ing. 'A U-boat sank the armed mer chantman Ampleforth (4578 tons), and another U-boat sank 6680 tons of merchant shipping. A third U-boat sunk altogether 40,000 tons of merchant shipping,3^ ..

article.heading: GERMAN REPORT
article.snippet: London, June 2.—The Berlin radio says that the niopping-up operations are continuing in Crete according to plan. Remnants of the British units
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPORT

London, June 2. — The Berlin. radio says that the mopping-up operations are continuing in Crete according to plan. Remnants of the British units,

under the pressure of Italian and German troops, are trying to leave the island by any available means. 'German troops, operating on the south coast, are witnessing drama tic scenes as British, Australian and New Zealand troops, in their wild flight, are trying to get away in small schooners, fishing boats and rowing boats. Only a small number could be taken on board the British warships, which were forced to leave the waters around the island, be cause of the incessant bombing at tacks. Numerous fishing boats, car rying British soldiers, had to return to Crete and gave themselves' up,'-'

London, July 17.— London news papers are featuring photographs il lustrating efforts by German camou flage experts to mislead R.A.F. raiders. Two lakes exist in the heart of Hamburg. The inner one. called

Lake (Binnen Alster, is camouflaged with rafts, representing blocks of buildings, and with roads. The Ger mans have built a replica of the Lombard bridge 600 yards north of the original structure. This faked bridge crosses a larger lake, Lake Aussen Alster. The plan is an en deavour to mislead tne R.A.F. into think that part of Lake Aussen Al ster is Lake Binnen Alster. article.articleText:
German Denial

Berlin, June_ 19. — Official spokes men flatly denied foreign reports that Germany had already begun to invade Russia, or that clashes had occurred in the Germano-Soviet border.

article.heading: GERMAN REPORT
article.snippet: London, June 6.—The Berlin radio stated that the Luftwaffe effectively bombed the harbour of Alexandria, starting fierce fires among important
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPORT

London, June 6. — The Berlin radio stated that the Luftwaffe effectively bombed the harbour of Alexandria, starting fierce fires among important military objectives. An oil depot was set on fire and the flames spread rapidly in all directions, the glow being visible far at sea.

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: London, Sept. 27.—The Berlin radio says that a German detachment at Sollum surprised a British column and captured prisoners
article.articleText:
German Report

London, Sept. 27.— The Berlin radio says that a German detach ment at Sollum surprised a British column and captured prisoners, arms, ammunition and vehicles. It added that heavy German artillery shelled the Tobruk harbour works.

article.heading: German Statement
article.snippet: London, Nov. 29.—The Berlin war commentator stated:—"The Germans and Italians. are engaged in bitter defensive fighting in North
article.articleText:
German Statement

London, Nov, 29. — The (Berlin war commentator stated :— 'The Ger mans and Italians . are engaged in bitter defensive fighting in North Africa. The British lost several hun dred tanks, hundreds of other ve hicles and many prisoners. The Bri tish, it is expected, will bring up new forces.'

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: London, Dec. 16.—The Berlin radio claims that Lieut.-General Montgomery has abandoned the attempt to reach Rommel's forces
article.articleText:
German Reoort

London, Dec. 16.— The Berlin radio claims that Lieut.-General Montgomery has abandoned the at tempt to reach Rommel's forces frontally along the coastaj road and sent out yesterday motorised. forces with tank support to make a sweeping movement from the south to reach the Axis flank or rear. Iti adds that all attacks proved un successful, and the British by even ing ceased the attempt after losing 22 tanks and some heavy weapons

article.heading: GERMAN TACTICS
article.snippet: London, Sept. 12.—The "Daily Herald" correspondent in Moscow describes the street fighting tactics the Germans had to employ to take Novorossisk. "The
article.articleText:
GERMAN TACTICS

London, Sept. 12— The 'Daily Herald' correspondent in Moscow describes the street fighting tactics the Germans had to employ to take Novorossisk. 'The Germans advanced in small rushes with the nervous, crouching gait of men seeking imaginary safety under fire,' he says. 'The Germans did not

leave a aoorway oenma witnout; toss ing in a volley of grenades or search ing stairs and rooms with a prelude of tommy-gun fire. Occasionally despite this caution, a German figure would crumple with a bullet in the back from a Red army soldier concealed in a house which the Germans had passed.'

article.heading: German Claims
article.snippet: London, Jan. 21—A German High Command communique states:—"In Tunisia we held our positions against strong counter-attacks. The
article.articleText:
German Claims

London, Jan. 21— A German High Command communique states : — 'In Tunisia we held our positions against strong counter-attacks. The

Axis forces at some points consid erably improved their positions. The Luftwaffe attacked a convoy off Algiers. Two merchantmen were sunk and nine damaged.'

article.heading: GERMAN REPORT
article.snippet: London, Sept. 4.—The Berlin radio states that the Luftwaffe raided military works at Bognor, blowing up several buildings.
article.articleText:
': GERMAN REPORT

London, Sept. 4. — The Berlin radio states that the Luftwaffe, raided mili tary works at Bognor, blowing up several buildings.

article.heading: German Report
article.snippet: London, April 1.—A Berlin High Command communique states: "Strong enemy thrusts towards the northern front of the Kuban
article.articleText:
German Report

London, April 1. — A Berlin High Command communique states: "Strong enemy thrusts towards the northern front of the Kuban bridgehead were repulsed with heavy casualties. There is only local activity in other sectors of the Russian front. German units alone between March 21 and March 31 destroyed or immobilised 456 tanks."

article.heading: GERMAN REPORT
article.snippet: London, March 25.—A Berlin High Command communique states: "German fighters shot down 11 planes when single enemy
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPORT

London, ? March 25.— A Berlin High Command communique states: 'German fighters shot, down 11 planes when single enemy planes flew over North-west Ger many on Wednesday, causing in

significant damage. 'Luftwafle fast bombers made daylight attacks on a traffic junc tion at Ashford and directly hit the railway station and supply in stallations. Heavy bombers last night attacked war objectives in the Firth of Forth and along the English north-east coast. German naval submarine-chasers, employ ing, new weapons, have sunk five British submarines in the Mediter ranean within a few days.'

article.heading: German Reports
article.snippet: London, March 2.—The Berlin radio states that the R.A.F. raid on Berlin was militarily ineffective owing to the daring opposition of
article.articleText:
German Reports

London, March 2. — The Berlin radio states that the R.A.F. raid on Berlin was militarily ineffective owing to the daring opposition of German night fighters and well directed fire from countless anti aircraft guns. Bombs were dropped of. rn.nrlnm mainirr in fho r-if.v qvpsi

causing fires which were quickly under control. A considerable number of raiders were shot down. Stockholm, March 2.— The Ber lin correspondent of the 'Alle- handa' states that details of the raid on Berlin cannot be revealed owing to military reasons. With the aid of the population the fives were soon under control. All Ber lin's ground defences and many squadrons of fighters were in ac tion. The R.A.F. lost a great many planes, many of them near Berlin.

article.heading: German Comment
article.snippet: London, Dec. 14.—The Berlin newsagency says that differences of opinion on internal policies caused Laval's retirement.
article.articleText:
German Comment

London, Dec. 14. — The Berlin newsagency says that differences of opinion on internal policies caused Laval's retirement.

article.heading: German Claims
article.snippet: London, July 26.—The German overseas radio states:—"The R.A.F. raided the Ruhr last night. We shot down a total of 61 planes
article.articleText:
German Claims

London, July 26.— The German overseas radio states: — 'The R.A.F. raided the Ruhr last night. We shot down a total of 61 planes yesterday and last night, including 52 four-engined bombers. ? The German overseas radio

the air defences engaged in heavy and successful defensive fighting along the North Sea coast from Holland to Heligoland Bight. Over 10 per cent, of one enemy forma tion was shot down by fighters in the Dutch coastal area.

article.heading: German Reports
article.snippet: London, July 29.—A Berlin communique states: "The Germans on several parts of the Orel salient throughout yesterday were
article.articleText:
German Reports

London, July 29.— A. Berlin com munique states: 'The Germans on several parts of the Orel salient throughout yesterday were en gaged in heavy defensive battles. They repelled all Russian attempts to break through and inflicted con siderable losses. The Russians in one sector north of Orel alone lost

100 tanks and 303 planes. There were only local Russian attacks on the remaining sectors of the front, which were repelled in hard fightr ing. A total of 186 Russian tanks were destroyed.' London, July 30.— A Berlin com munique states: 'In the Orel area we again repulsed fierce infantry and tank attacks. The Russian offensive south of Lake Ladoga has further slackened. Local Russian attacks, strongly supported by tanks and fighters, were repelled with losses for the enemy. Our naval forces again shelled enemy positions on the Mius front.'

article.heading: GERMAN CLAIMS
article.snippet: London, Oct. 4.—The Berlin radio states that German landing forces, which attacked Kos, had captured all military installations
article.articleText:
. GERMAN CLAIMS

London, Oct. 4.— The Berlin radio states that German landing forces, which attacked Kos, had captured all military installations by yesterday.

The German newsagency to night claimed that German forces attacking from landing craft had captured all important military in stallations on the island of Kos. It added: 'Over 200 British troops have been captured and a number of others killed. Part of the British forces fled to the mountains. Re sistance was encountered at only a few points.' . ~

article.heading: German Claims
article.snippet: London, Sept. 16.—A Berlin communique states: "There was bitter fighting yesterday in the area around Salerno and Eboli. Several
article.articleText:
German Claims

London, Sept. 16. — A Berlin com munique states: 'These was bitter fighting yesterday in the area around Salerno and Eboli. Several enemy battle groups were wiped out and bridgeheads further nar rowed. The Americans lost many killed and taken prisoner during the storming of Attavilla.'

London, Sept. 16. — The Berlin radio claims that the Germans stormed and captured Ersano, at the mouth of the Sele River yes terday, and took considerable booty and 700 prisoners and des troyed or captured 17 American tanks. London, Sept. 16.— The Paris radio states that seven Allied divi sions in the Salerno area are in a desperate position. German at tacks have cut up the force into several groups— one in Salerno proper and the others south of the town. The German overseas radio says that the numerical strength of the Allied formations at Salerno is far greater than was originally be lieved, and they are still desperate

article.heading: German Reports
article.snippet: London Dec. 9.—A Berlin communique states:—"The Germans repelled strong enemy forces attacking, under cover of fog
article.articleText:
German Reoorts

London Dec. 9. — A Berlin com munique states:— 'The Germans repelled strong enemy forces at tacking, under cover of fog, south west of Dnepropetrovsk. The Rus sians south-west of Kremenchug attacked repeatedly all day long yesterday but the Germans shot

up numerous tanks and warded off the attacks. We gained ground north-east of Jitomir and south of Korosten. where the Russians are resisting stubbornly. The Rus sians have achieved small breaches between the Pripet and Beresina Rivers and south-west of Richev, but their attacks were mainly un successful.'

article.heading: GERMAN REPORT
article.snippet: London, Nov 11.—The Berlin radio states that General de Gaulle's troops have occupied Beirut
article.articleText:
GERMAN REPORT

London, Nov 11.— The Berlin radio states that General de Gaulle's troops have occupied Bei rut.

GERMAN MIGRATION

In his address about German

migration to Australia, Mr. £in

feld stated that the Committee

of Management has continued its representations to the Gov ernment in opposition to the

continuous intake of Germans as favoured migrants to Aus tralia. It is regretted that the Government seems determined to continue. with this policy, and it is distressing to learn that 2638 Germans have been admitted to Australia in the first quarter of 1954.

I have learnt that the Gov ernment expect approximately 9000 Germans . who are to be skilled artisans to come to Aus

tralia during the next twelve

months.

In regard to German migra

tion we had been told that no more than 3,000-4,000 Germans would be admitted—but accord

ing to the report the position has changed, as the Government will bring' 9,000 Germans to this country. What are the plans of the Committee of Management? Are you going to acquiesce or should we do something about this new situa tion.'We want an objective as

sessment of the situation and

guidance for our policy.

The delegate from S.A., Mr. Hines, expressed the desire that the immigration of some unsuit

able elements of other nationali

ties (Poles, Lithuanians, etc.)

should also be included in the orbit of our attention.

Mr. H. B. Newman (N.S.W.)

defended the policy pursued by the Committee of Manage ment in this delicate political

issue.

Mr. Wolfensohn referred to

the fact that inquiries were made on the point raised by Mr. Hines, but no answer has come from the competent authority.

An interesting debate de veloped on the discrimination inflicted on a company which wanted to deal with $audi Arabia and invoked the

E.C.A.J. intervention with the

Australian and British Govern

ment against such discrimina tion. The prevailing opinion was that an approach to the

Crown should be made only it|. a matter of vital policy.

Answering Mr. Ben Green,

Mr. Einfeld stated that the Committee of Management was not idle, but has repeatedly

intervened with the Govern*

ment from September, 1953, on this issue and it has finally been settled by the combined efforts of N.S.W. and Victoria.'

As to the dissatisfaction re,

German migration, Mr. Einfeld said with emphasis: “I d know of any new method how to fight German migration! If you will show me such' new method, we shall apply it in our effort to stem; the, influx of

Germans.” ' i .'i':

article.heading: GERMAN MIGRATION
article.snippet: A chronic difficulty in Australia's immigration and development programme has been to obtain a sufficient
article.articleText: GERMAN MIGRATION A chronic difficulty in Aus tralia's immigration and de velopment programme has been to obtain a sufficient pro portion of skilled agricultural workers. This is an import ant factor to be reckoned with in the urgent and complex problem of revitalising food production. Even if Britain were not herself engaged in a vigorous drive for more out put from the land, the com petition from other overseas countries is such that Austra lia would still have to turn to Europe for agricultural mi grants. There, too, post-war rehabilitation has reduced the small proportion which farm workers represent in the pool of potential migrants. But there is a surplus of landless farming people in West Germany for special rea sons emphasised by the mem bers of the West German Federal Migration Board now visiting Western Australia on an exploratory mission. The Commonwealth Govern ment's move towards accept ance of a quota of selec ted Germans under a negotia ted migration agreement like that with Italy-gives Australia a chance to recruit agricultural workers. For West Germany it offers some relief in the problem of pro viding for an influx of nearly 10,000,000 people who are either victims of Communist expulsion from the Russian dominated territories or fugi tives from Communist terror. Nothing but prejudice need stand in the way of working out an arrangement for mutual advantage. If we have to go outside Britain for population we naturally look first along the Western European seaboard for assimilable racial stock most akin to our own. In the aftermath of the war there have been great changes in Germany and also in the Western attitude to the Ger man people and their future in the free world. An at tempt is being made to build up a friendly and peaceful cooperation and, at the same time, circumstances have pro duced a new period of Ger man readiness to migrate. In South Australia, particularly, there is experience of how an earlier generation of German settlers showed a capacity to identify themselves with the life and institutions of their adopted country. Any German migration now could amount to only a micro scopic percentage of the Australian population and, should any political or other undesirables slip through the screen, they could always be sent back on proof of subversion or misconduct. There would be no need for costly land settlement ven tures. Concentration on Ger man farmers or farm-workers willing to take agricultural jobs-perhaps under some limited contract-would im pose a minimum strain on housing. Employed on farms they could gain experience of Australian conditions and work towards small farms of their own.

article.heading: GERMAN PROBLEMS
article.snippet: Despite the grant of wide self-governing powers and economic and to Western Germany, it is doubtless too much
article.articleText:
GERMAN PROBLEMS

Despite the grant of wide self-governing powers and economic aid to Western Ger many, it is doubtless too much

to expect that relations be tween this and other Euro jpean States should be con sistently harmonious. British policy and British actions have I often been unjustly criticised by the Adenauer Government. Upon Britain has fallen the brunt of the attack relating to the Allied policy of disman tling certain German indus tries. Most of the industrial plants marked for demolition were in the British-controlled zone; and, as fresh cases of violence this week have I shown, German workers threatened . with unemploy iment are inclined to ascribe I their troubles to those near at hand. |j In the matter of disman tling, however. Western Ger Ijmany has not been treated liwith undue severity by the II Allies. In the past year, de

molitions of major plants have! seen curtailed. Some observers.! indeed, feel misgivings overj :he decision to raise the an nual ceiling for German steelj production to eleven million | :ons. Such unemployment! roubles as face the Adenauer Government, are due chiefly :o the waves of refugees trom :he cast. Latest official figures show that there are now 8,500,000 registered (and many unregistered) refugees' in Western Germany, com pared with 1,558,469 unem-j ployed. Density of popula-l tion in the State having been increased by 30 per cent., in-i iustry simply cannot absorb! the labor available. I Even so, conditions in Western Germany have enor mously improved through the help of Marshall Aid; and it is hardly surprising that, apart from dismantling, there is now 'little sign of popular disaffection,' but rather a, feeling that life is 'returning! to normal.' This internal pro gress seems to have raised hopes that the country can achieve greater equality with her neighbors, and perhaps strengthen herself against threats from the east. Dr. Adenauer, with his long ex perience as administrator of Cologne, has actively en couraged the idea of closer German collaboration with the French. In view of the re cent clash over the Saar coal mines, and the difficulties met in drafting a trade agreement, however, it seems scarcely timely for Dr. Adenauer to propose a Franco-German union.

article.heading: GERMAN OPINION.
article.snippet: BERLIN. Mar. 4 (A.A.P).— West Berlin's Mayor (Herr Ernest Reuter), once a collaborator of Stalin, said to-day
article.articleText:
GERMAN OPINION.

BERLIN. 'Mar. 4 (A.AJ3.). West Berlin's Mayor (Herr Ernest Reuter), once a col- laborator of Stalin, said to-day that the Russian leader's death would provide the Western world with a big chance for Dew diplomatic moves toward the Soviet Union. Herr Reuter, Who abandoned Communism in 1921. said of Stalin: "I never liked bim."

Herr Reuter said that the end of Stalin, "which we can presumably expect in a few days or at the outside a few weeks," will signal the begin- ning of a big change. It will also provide a big chance for the Western world to use. "I mean this in the sense of pro- viding a new political climate favouring the West in which a new diplomatic offensive, or some new approach to solving the global problems of Korea, Germany, Austria and the Far East could be launched," he said.

Herr Reuter joined the Rus- sian revolutionaries after his release from a World War One

prison camp in Russia. In 1918 and 1919, as Soviet Commissar for the German Volga Repub- lic, he was in close touch with Stalin.
