article.heading: GERMAN JEWS.
article.snippet: Generalisations are always dangerous and the generalised attack [?] German Jews made by our corr[?] spondent is exposed to just that
article.articleText:
GERMAN JEWS.

Generalisations are always danee, ous . and the generalised attack ! German Jews made by our eor* spondent is exposed to just that cil cism. It is impossible to sustain SUcl a charge against the German Jews », such in our midst. You will find manv of .them in the synagogues, ami jn l number .of departments, of the com. munity’s life. Why, then, is the charge made? It is made not only by our correspondent but, from time to time, by others too. I attended the exhibition at the Kadimah on the occasion* of the tenth anniversary 0i the Warsaw Ghetto revolt. I ieaVn afterwards that hardly a single Ger man Jew had attended during thi more than ten days it was open. ] look back upon more than fifteet years since the first immigration o| the refugees from Germany and | cannot help feeling some regret that these potentially valuable elements djj not in fact play a greater part in om development. What was the reason! Was it their apathy or opr failure t? give them the proper encouragement! Surely both factors operated. Bui in just what proportions it is not easy to say. Argument on the' subject can continue endlessly. You will find some people who will tell you that the assimilation for which German Jews were notorious will always make them indifferent to the community’s problems. But against this it is pos sible to cite many examples of devoted Jewish service by German Jews. The argument to-day ought to be directed differently. It should be aimed at enlisting the service of this valuable section into active work for the com munity. 1 don’t share .the view of the pessimists. Given the right approach we coiild recrpit 4 powerful force into our rapjcs.

article.heading: GERMAN “PROPOSALS.”
article.snippet: THE West German Chancellor has been vocal again, not without some effect. The world’s press has given, over much space to comment
article.articleText:
GERMAN “PROPOSALS.”

rgnHE West German Chancellor has JiL. been vocal again, not without some effect. The world’s press has given, over much space to comment on Dr. Adenauer’s plea that Ger many should be strengthened again to serve as a buffer between the West and Russia. Somewhat less space to these important matters has been given in the Australian news papers where pre-occupation with other issues has crowded the German news out. The impudence of German “statesmen,” boundless as always, permitted Adenauer to insinuate into his plea the suggestion that a re established Germany could “avert an otherwise inevitable explosion.” It is good to see that for the most part Adenauer’s proposals have been re jected with contumely. The Christian Science Monitor said that to rearm Germany would simply place in Ger man hands the balance of power in Europe, an arrangement which might suit diabolical German plans very well, but which would effectively destroy any prospect of world peace. The warnings against these German manoeuvres must be sounded from one end of the world to the other. Germany still remains the greatest menace to world peace, said Lord Wavell, whose lamented death oc curred only a fortnight ago. We should do well not to forget this great soldier’s warning.

* * *

article.heading: German Elections
article.snippet: The points of view any of us may hold will tend to colour our appreciation of the significance of the results of the recent German elections. The resounding defeat of both Communist and
article.articleText:
German Elections

Tire points of view any of us may hold will tend to colour our appreciation of the significance

of the results of the recent German elections.

The resounding defeat of both Communist and Neo-Nazi forces in open election may mean noth ing more than a distrust of extremism at this stage of national resurgence.

. It may also mean a more deepseated opposition to dictatorship and all its works born of the ex perience of past decades.

There is almost endless room for speculation about it. But one thing is clear, it will not mean the «nd of Neo-Nazi activities, but may mean in stead a stepping up in force of the political ma chinations of the, new/Hitlerite brigade.

. . .Whatever is underground will continue the whiteanting process, whatever is aboveground will continue propaganda in an endeavour to win ad herents and through them power.

What emerges, then* is the warning against complacency or taking the results of last Sunday’s election to mean that democrats can sit back in ease because Nazism is a spent force. There never has been a time when vigilance could be relaxed with safety, and this applies here as much as else-i where, because of the large number of Nazi-in doctrinated people who have come to these shores.

•Vigilance must be maintained at high pitch against- any form of dictatorship encroachment, because whatever may be the political slogan used, dictatorship itself is the scourge of the peoples of the world, the slogans serving but to camouflage the fact that unscrupulous men gain power over other men, and are determined to keep that power, even using murder, and assassination to do so.

article.heading: GERMAN MIGRANTS
article.snippet: A large party of German migrants has arrived in Western Australia and its members are bound to be wondering
article.articleText: GERMAN MIGRANTS A large party of German migrants has arrived in West ern Australia and its members are bound to be wondering what kind of reception they will be given in this large and remote part of the Bri tish Commonwealth. And although West Australians have become accustomed to European migration, doubt less many of them will be a little curious about these new Australians whose homeland has altered the course of world history and may do so again. There need be no misunder standings. Australia is not exactly an earthly paradise but the Germans who have come to our shores are fortunate people and we, in turn, should be glad to-have them. We can afford to forget past animosi ties and Hitler's misdeeds but, if we cannot completely .erase them, we should take a broad view of history and recollect that Wellington prayed for Blucher's arrival at Waterloo. Australia, after all, is not so remote from the world's great populations and if it is to accept the challenge of the new Asia it will have need for the German qualities of indus try, fortitude and discipline. In our factories, mines and laboratories and on our farms there is also a place for Ger man intelligence and in genuity. South Australia has good, reason to be thankful to its early German settlers and it should be our hope that, in years to come, we shall be able to look upon a comparable German contribution to the vr..n?ress of Western Aus tralia.

article.heading: EAST GERMAN
article.snippet: Berlin, Wednesday: Russian tanks patroled East Berlin tonight, restoring order after the two-day riots, which cost four lives and left 60 people injured.
article.articleText:
EAST GERMAN

HATRED OF REDS.

Berlin, Wednesday: Russian tanks patroled East Berlin tonight, restoring order after the two-day riots, which cost four lives and left 60 people injured.

Unrest has spread to other East German cities -^Magdeburg, Halie, Erfurt, and Leipzig-where discontent pt the actions of the Communist Govern- ment is growing.

Soviet tanks tonight had sealed all the main ap- proaches to East Berlin from .the West.

Five tanks, their guns pointin» toward West Ber- lin, took up positions in Un- ter Den Linden, to reinforce lorry loads of steel-helmeted machine-gunners. *

Two anti-tank guns were also deployed in Unter Den Linden, facing the British sector through the Bran- denburg gate.

Battalions of East. Ger- many's barracked police force, which is trained and equipped like an army, guarded the entrances to East 'Berlin and barred everyone without an East Berlin I identity card.

Two of the four dead in the riots were run over . by Soviet tanks.

A 21-years-old man, shot in front of an East German Government building died in the West Berlin Hospital. The fourth man. killed was a

West* Berliner, who was shot

in the head.

Earlier some 40,000 angry East Berlin workers .hurling stones, smashing windows, starting fires and yelling dé nuhciatfons bf the East Ger- man Communist Leaders marched through the streets. They demonstrated in front of the Government buildings and party headquarters and outside the prisons, calling for the release of political prisoners.

All German Affair

It had become an all-Ger- man affair throughout yes- terday, when the strikers , forced the East German

¡Government to withdraw an . iprder- to do more work for

Çkie same pay. After this Victory the temper and size .of the demonstration grew.

It was directed against the East German Govern- ment and, on the advice -of ¿he workers* leaders, avoided any attack on the Soviet jragime.

Soviet soldiers at first stood by, but the East Ger- man police were powerless. (Twenty police were tramp- led down, in Unter Den Linden.

Then thc Russians has- tily dug in round the Go- vernment quarter and or- dered tanks and armored cars into action.

The serious, bloody events have, again made Berlin a flashpoint.

Revelations of the serious .unrest may influence Rus- sia's : pl?. # ; about the unifi ,, cation of Germany.

The Soviet authorities tiave put 1,800,000 people under martial* law, imposing « curfew from 9 p¿m. until 6 a.m. Public assemblies ol' more than three people have been banned.

Changes are

Likely

London, Wednesday: It is felt political . changes ni East Germany are ceiTtiin

following the rioting. The

Vital fact emerges that Rus- sia can no longer be certain that the East German Com- munist ¡Party can keep East Germany subservient to the:

Kremlin's will-still less that it could dominate an all-German Government.

The East Berlin riots came shortly after a series of riot- ing in Czechoslovakia: also on the basis of the workers' economic condition.

Political observers in West Germany believe that the riots will almost certainly lead to an end of the East German Government as at present constituted.1-^

The West German Chan- cellor (Dr Adenauer) told the Bundestag in Bonn to- day that his Government "feels with the women and men of East Berlin, who have expressed their desiro for liberation from oppres- sion." ^

He said events in East. Berlin found a strong echo in West Germany and thc entire world.

Tlae Chancellor reiterated requests recent!" made bv the Bundestag for free elec- tions in all Germany, for- mation of a free all-German Government, a freely nego- tiated peace treaty with a united Germany, the settle- ment of all "remaining fron- tier problems, and freedom of action for an all-German Government. German apology

BONN, Thursday. — The W est German Government has apologised to the French High Commissioner for a re-

cent "war vindication" speech by J ustice Minister Thomas Dehler. In another peace gesture, Chancellor Adenauer ap pealed, to German party lead ers for calm and patience on the Saar question. The French protested that Dehler's speech was "shock ing" and "amounted to a justification of Adolf Hitler's policy at the expense of France." Dehler had said it was un true that Germany was guilty of starting all aggression in the last 200 years. ' v He said that Hitler was to a great extent the result of the Versailles Treaty and the pusillanimity of France. —

article.articleText:
German Migrants

Sir,—General Eisenhower is reported as having told the Ger- mans that he bears no resentment whatever against Germany as a

nation, still less against the Ger- man people.

"Governments," he said, "our national prejudices, our national prides, sometimes just our national ignorance, bring us into conflict, and it is always a pity."

From my personal experience of German P.O.W.s, I would say that the average German (if you can average the human race) is no different from the average Britisher; perhaps a little more courteous and industrious.

ERNEST A. JONES. Grafton.

article.heading: German Immigration
article.snippet: MELBOURNE, Tues.-- The Government had made no commitments on German immigration.
article.articleText:
German Immigration

MELBOURNE, Tues.— The Government had made no commitments on German immigration.

ttttlAT was stated by the Minister for Immigration, Mr. Holt,- at a meeting of the University Liberal Club.

nuui ussiwg me siuruiy meei- ing, Mr. Holt said that the only Germans in this country who had fought against us came under a temporary two-year exemption permit. The displaced persons scheme was almost finished and the Government had to- look else where for migrants. Germany, Holland and Austria were the best possibilities, he said. For the first quarter of an hour of the Minister's address there were boos and hisses, mingling, with cheers. Mr. Holt was asked if he knew that some migrants at Bonegilla camp had S S. marks on their arms and had statues of Hitler and Belsen camp whips in their possession. He said that he would inves tigate the reports, but added that in the past such allegations had been, found to be empty. He was told that one of the persons who selected German migrants was a prominent Nazi during the war, and was asked r.o see that the man was sacked immediately.

article.heading: GERMAN MENACE
article.snippet: THE likelihood of West Germany receiving her. sovereignty and the right to rearm if France fails to ratify the European Defence Community Treaty must be as alarming to Russia as it is to
article.articleText:
GERMAN MENACE

'THE likelihood of West Germany receiving her. 1 sovereignty and the right to rearm if France fails to ratify the European Defence Community Treaty must be as alarming to Russia as it is to France.

Both nations have good reason to fear a resur gence of German militarism. France has been over run by the Germans three times in less than 90 years, and in the last world war Germany nearly defeated Russia. while fighting half the rest of the world. - The Germans laid waste European Russia, killed about 10,000,000 Russian soldiers and about 20,000,000 civilians and reduced Soviet industrial production by nearly half. So it is easy to under stand why it became a basic aim of Russian policy, as soon as victory began to emerge, to see that de feated Germany was not left to herself or driven into the arms of an anti-Communist Western alliance. The Russian rulers have made a sorry mess of their efforts to achieve these aims. In less than a decade the probability has arisen of a sovereign Germany becoming a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and a full ally of the West. Reports of the revival of Nazism in high places in West Germany are among the reasons why the West as well as Russia should feel far from happy about this probability. Russia has proposed another meeting to dis-

cuss European security and the future of Germany. Britain and America are said to favour rejection of this proposal, but the French Premier (M. Mendes-France) is understood to wish the door, to be kept open. While the history of East-West con ferences does not encourage hope that anything use ful would come of such a conference, it is possible that Russia is now so deeply perturbed about the" likelihood of a rearmed sovereign Germany that she would at last be prepared to' offer genuine co operation in an attempt to remove the dangers her foolish policies have done so much to create. :je ' , # sk Pifrxr fvancnnrf Tle Plan for the trans- fer of the Hobart public transport system from the ownership and control of the Hobart City Council to a Government trust seems to be well on the way to realisation. Some time ago the Government intimated that it would be willing to discuss taking over the Laun- cestori transport system as well as that of Hobart, but the Launceston City Council decided, wisely no doubt, to wait a while and see what happened in Hobart. The Hobart plan is now sufficiently .well defined to provide a basis for preliminary investi gation and discussion by Launceston. Launceston has a transport rate of lid. which could be abolished if the Government became re sponsible for the losses. There have been country objections to the idea of city transport losses being met from state revenue, but it is likely that this opposition will be disposed of in Parliament by an assurance that the money will not come out of the pockets of Tasmanian taxpayers but from an addi tion to the annual special Commonwealth grant. The "Grants Commission is understood to have adopted, in relation to South Australia, a principle which assures Tasmania of this additional assis tance. However, there are other aspects requiring careful consideration. One of the. most important is that of ensuring the necessary measure of local control of the operation and development of the Launceston system. Control by a trust situated in Hobart would be altogether too remote.

article.heading: GERMAN MIGRATION.
article.snippet: PROGRESS continues to be recorded in the fight against German migration. New meetings are contemplated in several Australian
article.articleText:
GERMAN MIGRATION.

Jj- iROGRESS continues to be rec

orded in the fight against Ger

man migration. New meetings are contemplated in several Australian capitals and on other levels undim inished activity is proceeding. All in all the results to date are encourag

ing and can only serve to strengthen the determination of Australian Jewry to prosecute the campaign with utmost energy. Developments in the national capital will be watch ed with interest insofar as they may have any bearing on the problem. During the present state of affairs it would be important if the commit tee of management of the E.C.A.J. would again consider our earlier sug gestion for a fullscale interstate conference on German migration. Such a conference, in my view, should have been held some time ago, but more than ever today its desira bility should require no elaboration. The committee of management in Melbourne will be wise if it ai'ranges something at once.

article.heading: German intellectual
article.snippet: "Hans," by Michel Boutron (Derk Verschoyle). There have been many books on Germany and the Germans, but few have had the sensitivity
article.articleText:
German itellecual "Hans," by Michel Boutron (Derek Ver schoyle). There have been many books on Germany and the Germans, but few have had the sensitivity and penetreating insight of' "Hans."

It is a long short story rather than a novel, and it deals with one German, Hans Bernhard, formerly conductor at the Frankfurt Opera House. As a prisoner of war Hans decides to accept work on a French farm. Here he comes under the influence of Madame Rose and her son Louis, who has been maimed and tortured by the Germans while fighting as a maquis. Louis hates Hans with a downright, peasant hatred. Hans regards Louis as a terrorist who has received his just deserts. Madame Rose, with simple kindli ness, tries to reconcile the two, and bring some relief to Hans' tortured mind. For the German is

racked by conflicting emotions. While not a Nazi, he is one of those willing millions of Ger mans who made Nazism possible. While conscious of Ger many's guilt, he cannot rid himself of his master race complex. In the end Hans finds the peace he seelks-only to be killed in a completely Wagnerian, utterly Ger manic display of futile heroism. A first novel, this is an exquisite piece of writing by a man who has won several important French literary prizes. - John Quinn.

Friday, January 9, 1953

article.heading: GERMAN ATTITUDE

title.title: Dungog Chronicle : Durham and Gloucester Advertiser (NSW : 1894 - 1954)

article.snippet: Just a brief word on the attitude of the German military caste towards war. Colonel H. Foertsch in his book
article.articleText:
GERMAN ATTITUDE

Just a brief word on the attitude of the German mili tary caste towards war. Colo nel H. Foertsch in his book

The Art of War— Today and Tomorrow,' wrote (a fairly liberal translation) 'All life is a struggle. The strong shall conquer live and reproduce, the weak, however, will suc cumb, die and not return. ; Eternal peace is a dream and never a beautiful one — war, however, is a part of God's world order. Only the weak need fear war, the strong have no fear, by the mere fact that they are strong. To ex perience war— in the deepest sense of this much used word — is a joy and a pleasure.' The changing attitude of the Germans as the war progress ed was clearly noticeable — I exclude, of course, the SS and the Gestapo — and their fear of the Russians was most pronounced. It is hard to say to what extent they were be hind the Hitler regime — the majority were, of course, de laying that they were ever good Nazis at the war's end. But I strongly suspect that they were reasonably ardent supporters of the regime af ter the earlier victories of 1940. With most people, after all, results alone count. At least one German of my ac quaintance, was pessimistic enough to sing in the compa rative safety of our .barrack washroom 'Deutschland ist kaput' in early 1944. On the whole the Luftwaffe treatoi us fairly and adhered to the Geneva Convention. The two air forces had a mutual re spect for each other and the average German civilian, at least in the country centres, was not as antagonistic to

wards air crew, particularly bomber command, as we might have expected. It was a different story in the larger cities, especially the target area, but that is understan dable. To conclude I would like to quote^rom Winston Church ill's book, 'My Early Life.' 'Prisoner of War— that is the least unfortunate kind of prisoner to be, but it is ne vertheless a melancholy state. You are in the power of your enemy. You owe your life to his humanity and your daily bread to ' his compassion. You must obey his orders, go where he tells you, stay where you are bid, await his plea sure, possess your soul in pa tience. Meanwhile, the war is going on, great events are in

progress, fine opportunities for action and adventure are slipping away. Also, the days are very long. Hours crawl like paralytic centipedes. No thing amuses you. Reading is difficult; writing impossible. Life is one long boredom from ('awn till slumber. Moreover, the whole atmosphere of pri son, even the most easy and best regulated prison, is od ious. Companions in this kind of misfortune quarrel about trifles and get the least pos sible pleasure from each oth er's society. If you have never been under restraint before and never known what it is to be a captive, you feel a sense of constant humiliation in being confined to a narrow space, fenced in by wire, wat ched ,by armed'men and web bed in by a tangle of regula tions. I certainly hated every minute of my captivity more than I hated any other period in my whole life . . . looking back on those days I have al ways felt the keenest pity for prisoners and captives.' -

German Migrants

Sir,-I read with increasing be- wilderment that some people are advocating mass migration from Germany ("Herald," September

16 and 20).

Have they forgotten, or have they never known, what disaster was brought by German settlers during the last war on all the countries around Germany?

When, at the beginning of the German onslaught on Holland, para- chutists were dropped at Rotterdam, German fraulcins led them to mili- tary targets. When Dutch' troops started to retake the airfield, they were machined-gunned from the surrounding houses by "peaceful" German settlers.

Hungary and other countries had similar experiences.

Do you really think that people who are imbued with the belief that they are of a superior race will be content here to take jobs that nobody

else wants?

A. FEKETE,

Former Nazi concentration camp prisoner. Chatswood.

article.heading: GERMAN OPINION.
article.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (A.A.P). The German vice-Chancellor (Dr. Franz Bleucher) said to-day that he believed that the
article.articleText:
GEBMAN OPINION.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (A_APJ. -The German vice-Chancellor (Dr. Franz Bleucher) said to-day that he believed that the.Rus- sians would keep' their armed forces under control' in Eastern Germany. "It does not matter whether they are called Russian troops or labelled with any other name," he said. "You are all familiar with the' fate of the people in south-East Europe," he told a Press conference.

He said the question of the withdrawal of .western occupa- tion forces from Germany could not seriously be considered at present, since the Russians would want to maintain their influence in Germany. . It would not be necessary for the Bonn Govern- ment to ask the Western Powers for security guarantees, against: Russian aggression, as the West- ern Powers had repeatedly andi solemnly declared that they had1 undertaken all obligations for

their occupied territory. |

article.heading: German labor
article.snippet: BONN. — German labour must from the very beginning have a share in the physical and spiritual
article.articleText:
Germ® si labour

iJ BONN. — German labour must from the very begin ning have a share in the physical and spiritual crea tion of the German armed forces, the Federal Minister

ior aii-uerman Aiiairs uvir. Jakob Kaiser) said in Bonn recently. Mr. Kaiser was emphatic in discounting all possible anxiety that re-armament in Germany could again lead to militarism. He -said he did not share the anxiety of people who feared the re vival of militarism — : al though he would not, in view of what had happened in the past, deny anyone the right to be apprehensive. Mr. Kaiser said German Labour was one of the groups which suffered un der~ the Hitler regime. But one should guard against putting the Hitler Regime and the German Army on the same level. Re-undfication of Ger many would be made easier if the Federal Government could give the Allies a guar antee that it could — at least within limits — be responsible for the German Republic's security. ?

article.heading: German Migrants
article.snippet: Sir,—In reply to Mr. W. S. Kent Hughes, M.P. ("Herald," Feb. 23), I wish to state clearly my views on the question of
article.articleText:
German Migrants

Sir,-In reply to Mr. W. S. Kent Hughes, M.P. ("Herald," Feb. 23), I wish to state clearly my views on the question of Ger

man migration.

I have never condemned, nor would any other sane person con- demn, a whole race on account of the excesses of a few. As my brother surely knows, 12 million (some put the figure as high as 20 million) in- nocent people cannot, even with Nazi efficiency, be massacred by a few; even so, it has never been a question of condemning the whole

German race.

1 and others who are opposing this plan to bring 100,000 young Ger- mans to this country in the next four years, do so because they will be the ones who received their whole education under Hitler-the disastrous effects of which I saw as early as 1936 and 1937-and so would be a threat to our Australian democracy.

I wonder what Mr. W. S. Kent

Hughes's reaction wouldj be if the proposal was to bring 100,000 young Japanese to this country?

When a new generation has arisen in Germany, free from Hitlerism, then it will be time enough to re- open the question of German migra- tion. To date, there has been no effective de-nazification in Western I Germany.

(Miss) M. KENT HUGHES. Rose Bay.

article.heading: German cake
article.snippet: One lb. flour, ¼ lb. sugar, ¼ lb. butter, 3 eggs, cup milk, ¼ teasp. cinnamon, ½ teasp. salt, lemon
article.articleText:
German cake

One lb. flour, ¼ lb. sugar, ¼ lb. butter, 3 eggs, cup milk, ¼ teasp. cinna- mon, ½ teasp. salt, lemon essence, cup yeast, little

mace, currants and sul- tanas. Mix flour, sugar, cinnamon, salt and mace together, then add melted butter and milk, slightly warmed and well beaten eggs. Add currants and sultanas well washed and dried, and lastly, the yeast. Knead well and put away to rise. Roll out about ½ inch thick on a greased baking sheet and let rise again. Brush over with melted butter and put top on it, prepared as follows: Half lb. flour, ¼ lb. sugar, ½ teasp. cinnamon, ¼ lb. 1 butter, little mace. Crumble all with the hand and sprinkle thickly on cake. Bake 15 to 20 minutes in good oven.

article.heading: German orphans
article.snippet: THE HERALD reports the sad plight of the homeless orphans of Germany (13652). I feel that this report should be the subject
article.articleText:
German orphans

'PHE HERALD reports the sad plight of the homeless orphans of Germany (13/6/52). I feel that this report should be the subject of protests from bodies all over

Australia to the United Nations Organisation. I am especially shocked at the admission in the last sentence, and the implications that must surely go with it " . . . efforts are being made to find emplc -ient for child ren able to work." When the money and energy that we now use for planned de struction are applied to the ad vancement and rehabilitation of humanity, then the world will be a place fit for children to live in, —

— ELEANOR MASTERS, Baker s Parade. West Brunswick.

article.heading: German Migration
article.snippet: Percipient members of the Australian Jewish community were not surprised by the statements in the press that the Minister for Migration (Mr. Holt) had signed an agreement with the West German Government for the mass migration
article.articleText:
German Migration

Percipient members of the Australian Jewish community were not surprised by the statements in the press that the Minister for Migration (Mr. Holt) had signed an agreement with the West German Government for the mass migration of ten thousand Germans a year.

The sign has been in the sky for a long time, despite protestations to the contrary, and statements suggesting that Australian necessity made the practical implementation of a paper scheme impossible of realisation.

Now the sign is growing larger than the warning hand. The ABC news session on Wednesday] morning reported Mr. Holt as stating that he examined the screening system in Germany and he was very happy with it, it was function ing perfectly. He had seen the files on Nazis and their completeness astonished him.

Mr. Holt did not state whether the screening of migrants was based on the weeding out of Nazis* or other people. It is one thing to have the files, another to use them against Nazis.

However, he went on to say, or is reported as having done so, that the Dutch would make the more desirable migrants.

Why, then, is he allocating first place to Germans? The filing system he praised so highly would surely list only the outstanding workers for Nazism* the gauleiters and the smaller fry who bossed the towns and villages.

This filing system surely did not list all those Noting people who had been taken by the Nazis and moulded to Nazi doctrine during their most impressionable years... people who are now of the eligible age group to come here.

Nor would any screening system, however efficient, be able to cope thoroughly with so many applications that would involve the acceptance of ten thousand a year, and at least a token rejection of a few besides.

What will the Executive Council of Australian Jewry do now, to acquaint the general community with the dangers involved, and the need for constant vigilance if the demo cratic institutions We have evolved out of much tribulation are to be transmitted to our successor generations?
